title: Talbot Board of Ed OKs Contracts for EHS Auditorium, Chapel Elementary Windows
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Ed OKs contracts for EHS auditorium, Chapel Elementary windows

 October 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 256
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot Board of Education on Wednesday approved contracts for two upcoming projects: auditorium lights at Easton High School and windows at Chapel District Elementary School.New auditorium lights at Easton High will be installed in the summer of 2026, Director of Operations Kevin Shafer told board members. The $1.1 million contract was passed unanimously.
Shafer said some preliminary work will be done this spring before school ends. The school play and other concerts or events won't be impacted, Shafer said.
Over in Cordova, the under-renovation Chapel District Elementary School will receive glazing for its new windows. The window glazing is a security film, Shafer said, a safety measure that "prevents easy access to the school building."
All other schools in the district have the window glazing.
Chapel District Elementary is currently under renovation, a multimillion endeavor expected to be done sometime in 2026.
The contract is through a Maryland Center for School Safety grant in the amount of $132,000 for the window glazing. Shafer said the district couldn't move forward with it during construction of the renovated school building due to cost limits during the bidding process.
Shafer said he hopes the window security upgrades can be completed this summer. The board unanimously approved the contract.
Board President Emily Jackson added that she has "slight hesitations about privacy" as it relates to windows in classrooms and libraries at Chapel District Elementary and other schools.
Jackson asked that the board hear more about potential school safety grants in the future, particularly "in the privacy arena to provide more screening for our students."

title: Talbot Board of Ed Digs into Student Discipline Trends
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Ed digs into student discipline trends

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 561
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County Public Schools officials grappled with the state's guidelines on student discipline during a Board of Education work session Monday.Reviewing the district's data on suspensions, expulsions and more, Darlene Spurrier, director of student services, explained that according to state regulations, administrators must indicate an "imminent threat" in order to expel a student.
Expelling a student is a last resort, Spurrier said, adding that standard came as part of a "sweeping change" of the regulation around 10 years ago.
In the last three full school years and so far this year, there have been no expulsions of Talbot County students, according to data presented Monday.
"It is a very difficult standard to meet," Spurrier said. She said that at times it can feel like a crystal ball is needed to determine whether a student poses an imminent threat.
Suspensions can range anywhere from one to 44 days, Spurrier said. Any mark at 45 days or above is considered an expulsion.
Out-of-school suspensions have been largely steady. Data presented by Spurrier showed there were 334, 355 and 344 such suspensions in school years 2022-2023, 2023-2024 and 2024-2025, respectively. This year, there have been 46 out-of-school suspensions so far.
In the same three-year span, TCPS had 60, 52 and 51 student arrests, and 12, 14 and 32 reportable offenses. Arrests are on school grounds either delivered by paper warrants or physical arrests, while reportable offenses occur off-school grounds and result in action by the school district.
Compared to neighboring counties, Spurrier pointed out that TCPS has a relatively low rate of students suspended or expelled. In 2023-2024, 5% of Talbot students were suspended or expelled. Queen Anne's County came in at 3.1%, while Caroline (6.4%), Kent (7.1%), Dorchester (16.2%) and Somerset (17.4%) were all higher.
Bullying reports have hovered around the same mark in recent years: 72 in 2022-2023, 73 in 2023-2024 and 65 in 2024-2025.
Board President Emily Jackson asked if the district is encouraging students and families to fill out the bullying reports when appropriate.
"I know for a while there was both an understanding in the community and kind of a prevailing attitude of, don't fill out the report," Jackson said.
Spurrier said the district never wants "to discourage a family or a student" from filling out the report paperwork. Jackson agreed.
"Even if it doubles our numbers, even if it looks bad," she said.
Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi asked Spurrier if the state has certain red flags when assessing disciplinary data. For the most part, Spurrier said the state does not, though she noted the state does track if there is "disproportionate disciplinary practices," especially for Black students and students with disabilities.
The student services director said the district is aware it needs to "make sure that we are being equitable in how we're imposing discipline."
Board Member Ann O'Connor expressed some concern.
"Isn't it just a matter of who's breaking the rules and who's not?" she said. O'Connor later added: "I just hope we are not not disciplining students because it looks like we are disciplining more of the Black or underserved (students)."
Jackson emphasized it's important for the district to consider its discipline interventions for underserved students and whether more funding should be allocated to those groups to proactively solve disciplinary issues.
Spurrier said it comes down to making sure two different students in two different subgroups are receiving similar discipline.
"Are we responding differently to students who have the same offense?" Spurrier said.

title: Caroline County Board of Education/ Oct. 7, 2025
author: Ahmad Garnett
content:
CAROLINE COUNTY BOARD OF EDUCATION/ Oct. 7, 2025

 October 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 380
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — At the Oct. 7 Caroline County Board of Education meeting, the following actions were taken:Bill Mengel, director of operations for Caroline County Public Schools, presented the FY26 Comprehensive Maintenance Plan. The plan, required by the Interagency Committee on School Construction, aims to provide an effective learning environment, minimize disruptions, preserve school property value, maximize facility efficiency, and provide a foundation for risk management and preventive maintenance. The school system has 17 buildings, totaling nearly 960,000 square feet, valued at approximately $678 million. The construction cost per square foot for FY26 is $537, an 11.5% increase from last year. This increase is attributed to inflation and rising labor costs. Tariffs are a looming concern that may further impact costs. The board approved the maintenance plan.Robert Willoughby, director of administrative services, conducted the first reading of the Operation School Nutrition Programs Policy 9910. The policy is an update to a policy from the 1980s, changing the name from "school lunch program" to "nutrition program" to reflect the inclusion of breakfast. It also clarifies pricing for meals under the Community Eligibility Provision and for a la carte items.Willoughby presented the first reading of Policy 55080 on service animals. The policy aims to comply with ADA regulations and defines a service animal as an animal trained to perform a task for a person with a disability. It explicitly states that emotional support animals and therapy animals are not service animals. By law, service animals are typically dogs, with miniature horses considered under very specific circumstances for mobility issues. The policy outlines considerations for miniature horses, compliance with the law and the development of regulations for implementation.Superintendent Derek Simmons presented the Citizens' Advisory Committee nominees for 2025-2027. The committee is made up of parents and community members who provide feedback to the board. The committee was approved by the board.Kirk Howie, director of student services, provided an unofficial September enrollment update. The current unofficial enrollment is 5608, down about 40 students from last year, which is within the average 3% transition rate for Maryland. Elementary enrollment saw an increase of 53 students, while middle schools had a reduction of 51 and high schools a reduction of 61. Home school/instruction enrollment has increased, with 537 students this year, up from 466 in 2022-2023.

title: MACo Leaders Meet with Talbot Officials to Discuss 2026 General Assembly
author: Konner Metz
content:
MACo leaders meet with Talbot officials to discuss 2026 General Assembly

 September 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 536
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Leaders from the Maryland Association of Counties shared predictions for a calmer legislative session in 2026 during a meeting with the Talbot County Council on Tuesday.Michael Sanderson, MACo's executive director, and Jack Wilson, the association's president and current Queen Anne's County commissioner, met for an annual check-in with Talbot officials.
Sanderson reminded the council members of last year's volatile General Assembly session, during which legislators and Gov. Wes Moore (D) had to reckon with closing a $3 billion gap in the state's fiscal year 2026 budget.
Some savings came through cost shifts placing more burden on county governments, the MACo leaders said. But they added that the upcoming 2026 session, and the fiscal year 2027 budget that goes along with it, likely won't be as dire.
"Relatively calm, probably not a big crisis," Sanderson said of his projection for this year's session, which officially kicks off Jan. 14 in Annapolis.
He said the large budgetary concerns are likely to reappear in 2027 as legislators put together a plan for fiscal year 2028.
"The story from last year is gonna repeat itself, but with a year off," Sanderson predicted.
Specifically, the executive director said Maryland's expansive education funding formula, The Blueprint, will influence the 2027 session. And in the short-term, some counties are already coming to grips with increasing cost shares for education.
"Every county is either in the midst or a year or two away from seeing a year where the increase in school spending required under Blueprint requires all the money or even more money than your county's likely to gain in revenue for that year," Sanderson said. "It's an obvious squeeze at the local level."
Talbot County's fiscal year 2026 budget included $55 million in education funding required by The Blueprint's formulas. On top of that, the council approved an additional $600,000 in funding to fill new positions.
That mark had been scaled back twice from the original ask the Talbot Board of Education made of the council — first requesting $5.5 million in supplementary funds, then $1.1 million.
County Council Vice President Pete Lesher, who supported the district's $1.1 million request earlier this year, said it was "short-sighted" for the county to only fund the district's request partially, given that Blueprint requirements are only set to increase in future years. But other council members opted to hold back on dedicating the full request as the county aimed to even out its spending hikes seen in years prior.
Sanderson said on Tuesday that housing legislation will be at the forefront this winter. Recently, Moore signed an executive order that aims to speed up the permitting and building of affordable housing projects.
"I anticipate that being a big fight," Sanderson said. "Whether it's a big fight in the more rural jurisdictions is yet to be seen."
Council Member Lynn Mielke asked how Easton fits into state plans to tackle the housing issue.
Sanderson said there's an opportunity for MACo to advocate for provisions so a potential housing package doesn't "overwhelm" local jurisdictions. He said the association can help push for certain changes to help counties and towns that lack authority in certain areas, such as the variation of impact fees on developers.
"At the same time, we generally want to keep land use decisions local," he added.

title: Talbot School Board Dives into Test Score Trends
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot school board dives into test score trends

 September 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 695
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot school officials took a deeper look at state test scores last week, indicating upward trends in math and English for some grades and dips in others.At a work session on Sept. 15, Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, presented to Talbot Board of Education members breakdowns of 2024-2025 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program scores by grade and student group.
The presentation showed increases from the previous year in English proficiency for third and fourth grades, but drops for fifth and eighth grades. Math proficiency spiked year-to-year for fourth, sixth and seventh grades, but the number of students proficient algebra significantly fell.
The deeper dive came after the state released test score data for the 2024-2025 school year last month. While proficiency rates increased statewide, Talbot County students saw mixed results. English proficiency dropped to 45.4%, 16th in the state and the largest year-to-year decrease (1.9%) of all districts.
In math, 18.9% of students were proficient, 18th in the state and nearly even with the previous year's mark. Other counties, such as Dorchester, saw notable gains, rising spots in the statewide rankings.
Two days after the Sept. 15 work session, Talbot Board of Ed Member Deborah Bridges said at a monthly meeting that the district's results kept her up at night.
"After our work session on Monday night, I couldn't sleep," Bridges said. "Our scores, it upset me so much. And I wondered, what are we missing? What is going on in our schools?"
Board members largely agreed that the results aren't a matter of pointing fingers at teachers or staff. Instead, they are focused finding solutions to fix some of the problem areas.
Board President Emily Jackson said at the work session that she hopes school officials can begin to pinpoint some reasons behind the data trends.
"If I look at us, and we're going down, whereas a neighboring county who has a similar population of kids and they're going up, I want to know why," Jackson said.
Einhorn said while the state tests are an "important measure," it's one of many ways to assess academic achievement and growth.
"This is one assessment given at a single period of time, which does not always accurately reflect what students know and what they're able to do overall," Einhorn said.
ENGLISH
Fifth and tenth grades suffered the largest proficiency drops of 5.6% and 10%, respectively. But fourth grade proficiency rose to 50% in the most recent results. And while third grade proficiency dipped from last year's 47.9% mark, it's still at 43.6%, an improvement over a 35% rate two years ago.
"This really speaks to the work that this board has invested in early literacy, and starting to see that trend move up," Einhorn said at the work session.
Meanwhile, most student groups followed the district's overall trend of slightly decreasing in English proficiency. Asian students fell from 68.9% to 51.2%, while Talbot's multilingual learners dropped from 8.7% to 5.1%.
MATH
One of the sharpest drops came in Algebra II proficiency: 32.8% of students passed the state test in 2023-2024; only 7.1% passed in 2024-2025.
Einhorn acknowledged that as an "area of need." She noted that new math standards for K-8 will go into effect next school year. And in two years, the district will begin integrated algebra courses, infusing geometry concepts, she said.
Fourth grade rose nearly six percentage points to 32% proficiency this past year, while seventh grade had a similar hike from 11% to 17%.
By student group, one result stood out: Black students in the district remain under 5% proficient in math. Einhorn admitted the shortcoming.
"The less than 5% is indicating that we are still underserving our Black students and that we still need to continue looking at strategies that better prepare them to show what they know and are able to do in mathematics," Einhorn said.
Board Member Dyshekia Strawberry said she'd like to see the district work with community partners to specifically tackle the gap in math proficiency for Black students.
Board members thanked Einhorn for presenting the detailed trends, acknowledging that there's work to be done to get some of the numbers going in a positive direction.
"We have to do better, and we're open to hear how we're going to do that," Jackson said.

title: Caroline County Officials Learn About Early Head Start Cut
author: Ahmad Garnett
content:
Caroline County officials learn about Early Head Start cut

 September 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 401
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — On Tuesday, Charles Huester, executive director for Maryland Rural Development Cooperation, discussed Early Head Start funding cuts with the Caroline County Commissioners.MRDC, which runs the Early Head Start programs in Caroline and Cecil counties, announced on Aug. 27 that the Early Head Start program would be ending effective Sept. 2 after it did not receive funding from the Office of Head Start.
The free program supports pregnant women and young children's learning and development.
Huester said they were surprised to hear the program did not receive the necessary funds given that that the MRDC hasn't officially heard back from Office of Head Start about its grant application. Huester said their competitors for the funding told them they didn't receive the grant.
"I'm not really sure the practice of Office of Head Start not replying to anyone. We found out through a third party, direct competitor for funding actually. Maryland Family Network let us know what was going on," Huester said.
Huester explained the funding was cut because of a decision to apply as a direct recipient instead of a subrecipient.
"We have over $1 million in funding. We applied for $3 million in funding, so essentially what we learned is if we continued as a subrecipient with Maryland Family Network, we probably would have had funding, it would have been no issue, but because we chose to apply as a direct recipient, we didn't receive funding," Huester said.
The decision to apply independently was made by the organization's board, but Huester said if MRCD knew that applying as a direct recipient would impacted its funding, MRDC would've made a different choice.
Huester said that MRDC reached out to Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md., 1st), who sent a letter to the Office of Head Start. Harris said he has not received a response.
Addressing concerns from residents about the program's end, Huester said MRDC has explored options to provide for the toddlers of Caroline County.
The options include introducing a Patty Center model, which aims to help the family as a whole, allowing parents to come on site for services like resume building and job searching while their children are looked after. There is also fee structure option, which consist of exploring what residents could afford to pay to keep a center open at spaces in Greensboro and Federalsburg.
Huester also discussed converting existing Head Start spots and a collaboration with the Maryland State Department of Education for classroom models.

title: Queen Anne's Denies Charter School Application
author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's denies charter school application

 September 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 896
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — In a 3-2 vote, the Queen Anne's County Public Schools Board of Education voted to uphold the superintendent's recommendation and deny application for what would have been the first classical charter school in Queen Anne's County Sept. 10.Presenting a final report and an overview of the Queen Anne's County Public Schools Charter School Application Review Committee process, charter school liaison and supervisor of instruction Micheal Bell said the committee recommended denial of the Queen Anne's County Classical Charter School application Sept. 3, "due to significant and substantiated deficiencies in academic planning, operational capacity, and demonstrated need."
According to Bell, "the application lacked evidence of innovation, financial and governance readiness, and failed to articulate how it would meet the diverse needs of Queen Anne's County students."
The extensive review process is aligned with Maryland Charter Law, the Code of Maryland Regulations, and precedents established through the Maryland State Board of Education guidance, he said.
Noting the district had not received the in-depth responses necessary, Interim Superintendent Matthew Kibler's recommendation mirrored the Committees citing "major gaps remained despite multiple opportunities to cure deficiencies," including: insufficient evidence of operational readiness, staffing, and facility acquisition planning; a pre-K program plan that is not feasible without Maryland Accreditation and EXCELS Level 4 status; financial assumptions that lack contingency planning for enrollment shortfalls, grant delays, or facility overruns; limited and underdeveloped plans for serving students with disabilities, English learners, and other student groups and an instructional program that remains underdeveloped and not adequately aligned with Maryland College and Career Ready Standards.
The committee acknowledged the charter school's group enthusiasm for the classical charter model, timely responsiveness in communication, and a strong commitment to the idea of school choice, Bell said.
"But the team also noted authorizing a charter school is not simply about approving an idea, it's about assuming full responsibility for students, staff, and the community under our umbrella," Bell said, a level of responsibility that requires readiness, compliance, and sustainability, "none of which were determined to be sufficiently demonstrated within their application."
Following the turbulent meeting Sept. 3 filled with heated discussions in the face of the application's proposed denial, the Queen Anne's County Classical Charter School group returned to the Board Sept 10. to present answer questions and allow for an in depth application review for the Board's decision.
Lead by a Board of Directors with expertise of former teachers and education professionals, the motivation to establish the classical charter school arose to provide options to parents and enhance the current system upon seeing current dropping proficiency rates, founder Audrey Scott said.
Charter Committee Board of Directors President Ashley MacLeay noted that although seeking autonomy through waivers, the proposed classical charter school would ultimately be a public school part of the QACPS system that the Board of Education would oversee.
Student enrollment would be based on a lottery system.
The charter committee claimed it was not afforded opportunities for collaboration and was provided little assistance in certain application aspects, like identifying facilities.
If approved by the Board of Education, the charter school would continually seek collaboration with QACPS in establishing a charter agreement, as "one holistic school system," she said.
To start, the charter school would need six teachers and has already received far more resumes than that of interested teachers, Scott said.
The group claimed interest has been overwhelmingly positive from the community including partners like the Giving the Edge Foundation and letters of support from the Queen Anne's County Commissioners.
While not initiated yet, the committee received support from the county to direct mail to every county home to serve as a first general introduction to parents, Scott said.
While letters of support have been received from the community overall, the QACPS Board of Education questioned student sustainability and a "demonstration of need" and claimed a lack of parent voices interested in enrolling students.
Charter committee officials stated they have personally spoken to multiple families in full support of the program, just without time to write letters of support or a hesitancy to speak up at Board meetings.
With a potential program so monumental looming for the county, Board of Education member Mathew Drayer questioned how parents couldn't find the time to voice their support.
A broad petition of county residents as well as outside of the county collected "well over two hundred signatures," that included parents, MacLeay said.
Although limited with polling data, the committee said it was happy to perform more surveys and was confident in the need.
The charter committee would ensure future marketing to all 8,000 students across the county's districts, Targeting families with elementary age children including homeschooled, the charter school would welcome reaching where families are, including libraries for an active presence and share what the potential school would entail, MacLeay said.
"We are trying to ensure we have viable schools with the right teachers and support and staff and everything they need to be successful," Board of Education President Shannon Bent said, and needed to hear from the community if there were additional needs to address.
Scott credited the above and beyond thoroughness forth by QACPS staff and Board of Education in reviewing the application.
"We are all in this for the children," Kibler said, and encouraged the committee to strengthen their application and resubmit next year.
The applicant retains the right to appeal to the Maryland State Board of Education or to resubmit during the next application window.
The QACPS Board of Education will next meet Oct 1. at 6 p.m.

title: Girls Lose Gains in Math and Science Post-Pandemic
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Girls lose gains in math and science post-pandemic

 September 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Headlines 
 
 894
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Recent data from the Stanford Education Data Archive and the National Center for Education Statistics revealed that girls were making major gains in subjects like math and science before the pandemic. Since, the national trend shows girls declining in these areas at a faster rate than boys.Maryland experienced one of the largest drops in girls' math scores compared with boys'. Between 2019 and 2024, girls fell behind, on average, the equivalent of 49% of a grade level more than boys, according to data analysis from The Associated Press.
"There's a lot of cyclical things happening in education," Maryland's 4-H STEM specialist Mark DeMorra said. "It's kind of like a pendulum in the fact that we swung so far to one side."
Girls on Maryland's Eastern Shore were no exception to the decline in math skills. Talbot, Caroline and Dorchester County all followed this trend, but some districts stood out more than others.
The study compared 2023 National Assessment of Educational Progress test results to the 2019 national average. The results represented grade levels three through eight. A score of 5.5 is equivalent to the national average in 2019. Each whole point represents the equivalent of a grade level.
In Maryland, girls declined 0.92 points, almost an entire grade level, while boys dropped 0.47.
Prior to the pandemic, girls throughout the country were outperforming boys in math and science on average. But AP's analysis found that in 2023, boys outperformed girls in nine out of every 10 school districts.
This was the case in Talbot County, where prior to the pandemic, girls were outperforming boys by 0.24 points. In the 2023-24 school year, boys outperformed girls by 0.17 points.
But girls still outperformed boys in two Mid-Shore districts. In Caroline County, girls scored a 4.51 in 2023-24 while boys scored a 4.44. In Dorchester County, girls scored a 3.14 while boys scored a 2.95.
Dorchester County saw the worst decline of the three counties, with girls dropping 1.05 points, while boys dropped 0.85 points. In Caroline County, girls declined by 1.18 points while boys dropped 0.81 points. Talbot County saw girls declining by 0.96 points and boys by 0.55.
According to the Stanford Education Data Archive, no districts in Maryland have fully recovered their pre-2019 math levels.
The Star Democrat provided the data to local school districts two weeks ago. Talbot County Public Schools and Caroline County Public Schools did not respond to The Star Democrat's requests for comment. District representatives from those two districts requested specific questions, which were provided but not answered.
Dorchester County started at a lower baseline than the other two Mid-Shore counties, falling well below Maryland's state average. Comparing Dorchester County to the average found in the study, both boys and girls are roughly 2 to 2½ grade levels behind in math.
The district's Assistant Superintendent of Academics and Student Services, Jodi Coleman, wrote in an email to The Star Democrat: "While our girls' math scores dipped slightly more than boys' since the pandemic, the overall gap between genders is small. Both groups showed similar trends, and our overall performance has remained fairly consistent with pre-COVID results."
Dorchester County is working to make gains across the board with its "23 no more" initiative. The initiative aims to move Dorchester County Public Schools from 23 out of 23 counties in the state to 15th.
One year after the initiative was introduced, the county has successfully moved up two spots overall in the state rankings and improved from 23 to 19 in English learning arts and from 23 to 20 in math.
"The larger issue is that most of our students — girls and boys — are not yet proficient, which is why our 'Believe in Us: Advancing Our Potential Together' strategic plan focuses on improving achievement for all learners. Addressing any gender differences is embedded in that broader effort," Coleman wrote.
Dorchester schools are zeroing in on teacher training, small-group math support and expanded STEM opportunities, while also boosting dual enrollment and career pathways for female students. Coleman says these steps aim to close learning gaps and raise math and reading achievement.
Coleman wrote that Dorchester is seeing early signs of success.
"Preliminary benchmark data suggest stabilizing math scores for both genders. Schools reintroducing environmental literacy trips, small-group tutoring and STEM enrichment last spring noted increased engagement," Coleman wrote.
Girls' enrollment in advanced math and science are returning to pre-2019 levels, according to Coleman. Some extracurricular programs, like robotics and coding clubs, are still rebuilding but trending upward.
Coleman wrote that opportunities were affected by in-person restrictions during the pandemic. Hands-on enrichment like robotics, STEM field trips and some environmental experiences were paused or scaled back. This was the case for many school districts.
DeMorra, the 4-H STEM specialist, said framing math and science in an approachable and inclusive way is critical to engage students, particularly girls.
The core philosophy of 4-H is "learning by doing." DeMorra said hands-on STEM activities help students, especially those who don't self-identify as "STEM people," realize they are already using math and science through applied projects.
Maryland 4-H partners with schools and community organizations to fill some of the hands-on learning gaps, DeMorra said. However, he said it is critical for all educators to work together.
"We all have the same basic goal. We should helping each other. And that's in general for 4-H too. We are trying to help each other and continue to do the best that we can for our children, our future," he said.

title: Sheriff: Youth Justice Laws Add to Crime
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Sheriff: Youth justice laws add to crime

 September 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Crime 
 
 539
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — In the past week, there have been three juvenile arrests related to violent crimes in the City of Cambridge.Dorchester County Sheriff Jimmy Phillips said this level of violent crime is "not normal" and officers feel their hands are tied by the current juvenile justice laws Phillips said lack accountability.
On the second day of school at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School last week, two students were arrested after assaulting the school safety monitor. Phillips described the scene as a "melee."
Phillips said three sheriff's deputies were spat on and the school safety monitor was taken to the hospital. Two boys, ages 14 and 15, were arrested following the incident.
The 15-year-old boy, Jaheem Mortaz Brown, was released to his step-father's custody. Three days later, the Brown allegedly shot his step-father in the face. The extent of the step-father's injuries has not been disclosed.
In addition, Phillips said Cambridge police received a call this weekend that juveniles around 11 years old were shoplifting from the Wawa on Sunburst Highway.
"They're shoplifting because they know they (the juvenile system) can't do nothing with them," Phillips said.
Phillips said the problem of juvenile crime will continue until the "broken juvenile justice system" is changed.
"The juvenile justice system in the state of Maryland is broken; it's not working," he said. "We're not holding anybody accountable."
The former Secretary of the Department of Juvenile Services, Vincent Schiraldi received intense backlash from Mid-Shore sheriffs, including Phillips. The Maryland Sheriffs Association sent a letter to Gov. Wes Moore calling for Schiraldi's immediate resignation last year. Schiraldi stepped down from the position in June.
"Consistently in Maryland, juveniles have been charged with serious violent crimes," the letter states, "only to be turned right back over to a parent or guardian, and back out on the streets to commit more crimes."
After an in-person community meeting with the secretary around two years ago, Phillips said "He had the audacity to tell us, 'The data that I'm receiving doesn't support your claim of increased juvenile crime,'" Phillips recalled. "And our reply to that was, 'Well, obviously the numbers are going to go down because you're not allowing us to charge (them) anymore.'"
In 2022, the Maryland General Assembly passed a juvenile justice reform bill stressing rehabilitation rather than punishment in addressing juvenile behavioral issues, according to its proponents. The reform took effect in 2024.
In August, the Cambridge Police Department presented its quarterly report, which revealed that overall crime decreased, but there were concerns regarding homicides, robberies and juvenile violence.
Homicides, assaults, larceny and motor vehicle theft all increased from the second quarter in 2024. The homicide rate rose 200%, with two homicides that both led to arrests. One of those homicides was committed by a juvenile.
Phillips said this level of violent crime in Cambridge is not normal.
"I mean, it's not normal anywhere, but I think the biggest contributing factor we had last week is the failure of our juvenile system," he said.
Last school year, students in Dorchester County saw 1,682 long- and short-term suspensions with 1,232 of those suspensions related to violence, according to Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson.
In an attempt to curb suspensions, Dorchester County Public Schools launched a violence prevention initiative course for students, teachers, parents and staff to ensure there is community participation.

title: Dorchester Schools Climb in State Rankings After First Year of Ambitious Reform Plan
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Dorchester schools climb in state rankings after first year of ambitious reform plan

 August 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 509
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last year, Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson set out on a mission to change the school district's current ranking of 23rd out of 24 in the overall Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program evaluations. A year later, the results are in, and they look promising.The "23, no more" initiative is a three-year plan to move DCPS from the 23rd spot to 15th. Testing data released by the state this week shows the county has successfully moved up two spots overall, and it improved from 23rd to 19th in English Learning Arts proficiency.
While DCPS' climb in the rankings may not be massive, district leaders say it shows notable progress.
"So we looked at the numbers as to what it would take for us to get to the middle of the pack, and we said, 'Okay, 15. If we move this amount of kids every year, we can at least get to 15. And then if we go higher than 15, that will be just added bonus,'" Thompson said.
The superintendent said key strategies to get to 15 include setting a clear vision, conducting quarterly walkthroughs, focusing on instruction, rallying the team around a goal, supporting teachers, differentiating learning, simplifying processes and putting structures and systems in place.
The district's strategic plan, called "Believe in Us," guides these efforts and emphasizes core values such as joy, putting children first and accountability. This plan has four key priorities: advance academics, optimize operations, pursue partnerships and cultivate conversations.
For Thompson, it is crucial that the community outside of the school system is involved in this process for it to work.
"I think that education is a community issue because I don't think there will be one person that would say that they don't want kids to be educated," Thompson said. "That's the emphasis, that's the nucleus, right there. Everyone wants kids to be educated, so it's everyone's responsibility to ensure that the kids are being educated, not just the school system."
Thompson hopes the school system can act as a catalyst for countywide transformation through incremental progress and innovation.
Efforts are underway to recruit more certified teachers and administrators to improve the attractiveness of Dorchester County Public Schools to parents and families in the area.
Though these early results are promising, Thompson knows there will still be challenges to accomplish his ambitious goal. He said these do not deter him. "There's no challenges that I don't think we can overcome as a district and community working collectively together that can be a hindrance for us to move to 15," he said.
As long as community members are willing to come up with creative solutions, Thompson firmly believes that there is no challenge they won't be able to overcome.
"We're not turning anybody away and we want everyone to be involved in the process because I think at the end of the three year journey, I think people will be happy about our progress as a school system," Thompson said. "But I don't want them to be happy as innocent bystanders. I want them to be happy as active participants in the process."

 Centreville — With numerous proposed local projects dedicated to opioid awareness and limited federal funding, Queen Anne's County Commissioners prioritized public schools and the department of health educational support programs for opioid restitution funding Aug. 12.The county's Local Opioid Abatement Plan included several proposed projects to utilize local opioid restitution funds provided by the state to combat the opioid crisis. The county only has about $677,000 available in funding, and all the projects outlined total over $1 million, according to County Administrator Todd Mohn.
Queen Anne's County Public Schools Opioid Education Partnership will utilize $209,025 of the opioid restitution funds in preventing youth opioid misuse through a school-based program and student-led awareness campaigns. It also aims to educate the broader community through public events, and distributing data-rich materials.
Queen Anne's County Department of Health Educational Support programs will be provided $89,251 to strengthen overdose education, prevention, and response.
This project also includes a re-entry program for individuals released from the detention center and an expansion to the court-assisted recovery program to provide alternatives to incarceration.
The commissioners reached a consensus to reconsider other programs at a future time as additional resources and partnerships become available.
Counties were awarded Maryland's opioid restitution funds to have autonomy to create plans on how to address avoiding addiction in communities, according to County Health Officer Brice Strang.
Programs that were traditionally funded have been denied funding this year, including the public school program, he said.
Strang is now recommending the Board of Health create a county evidence-based mechanism to support current programming and showcase how it is working in the community, such as the school based programing. Strang recommended using the funding to backfill the programs, and "wait and see" on federal and state funding.
A constant messaging to youth in particular is important, he said, and the commissioners praised the works of the Drug Free Coalition, the Student Ambassadors, and county partnerships.
"One of the things we already know is prevention is cheaper than treatment," Strang said.
Remembering when programs initially began, Commission President Chris Corchiarino noted just how far the community has come in regard to opioid awareness and preventing overdoses.
To continually keep overdose numbers down, Corchiarino said, new initiatives are always needed to keep awareness moving forward and make sure preventive programs stay at the forefront.
"And that forefront is in our schools, for sure," Commissioner Phil Dumenil said.
More information about Queen Anne's County Drug Free Coalition can be found at qacgoespurple.org.

title: Cellphone Pouches Are Back in Caroline County Middle Schools
author: Ahmad Garnett
content:
Cellphone pouches are back in Caroline County middle schools

 August 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News

 DENTON — Caroline County Public Schools will be bringing back cellphone pouches in middle schools for the second year.Cellphone pouches were introduced in the 2024-25 school year as a pilot program aimed at keeping students off their phones. Students carry locked pouches during the entire school day, with their phones inside and not accessible.
Each student has their own pouch, which travels with them daily from home to school. Phones are locked into the pouches at the beginning of the school day and unlocked at the end using a magnetic device. If a student leaves the pouch at home, they put their phone in the school office for the day.
According to CCPS, year one of the pilot program was a success.
"We saw it was a good first year with it," said Caroline County Superintendent Derek Simmons.
"The recommendation ... the board accepted was to give it another year at our middle schools. One year does not mean a trend. We saw good good results, but we want to track it for another year before we make any determinations about if we were to move it forward to the high school level."
The cellphone pouches were created by the company Yondr and were tested in both Caroline County middle schools last school year.
During the June Caroline County Board of Education meeting, district staff presented statistics for the school year. Compared to the year prior, CCPS saw 30.6% fewer referrals last school year, with 130 fewer attacks, threats or fights and about 200 fewer instances of disrespect and disruptions.
According to Simmons, student and parents have been receptive of the cellphone pouches.
"Last year it was minimal resistance," Simmons said. "You bring in something new, people are going to have some concern. They ask questions, administrators at the building level handle the questions really well. By and large, everything went well with compliance. It's funny, we've had hardly any asks this year going in the middle because it just has become the expectation."
After one more school year at the middle school level, CCPS will revisit the topic and potentially incorporate the cellphone pouches to the high school level.

summary: On August 29, 2025, the Caroline County Board of Education voted to restore cellphone pouches in all four county middle schools, beginning the first week of September. Superintendent Derek Simmons said the policy, which requires students to place phones in locked pouches during class and permits use only during breaks or emergencies, balances safety with reduced distractions. title: State Test Scores: Mid-Shore School Districts See Mixed Results
author: Konner Metz
content:
State test scores: Mid-Shore school districts see mixed results

 August 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 694
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland Department of Education released English and math test scores Aug. 26, revealing a major jump for one Mid-Shore school district and mixed results for others.Test results from the 2024-2025 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program, or MCAP, show that statewide, students made slight gains in both subjects. English proficiency is at 50.8%, up from 48.4% the previous year. Math proficiency is at 26.5%, up from 24.1% last year.
The Mid-Shore's five counties — Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot — didn't always follow those state trends.
In English, Dorchester County outpaced all other counties in year-to-year gains. Dorchester's English proficiency saw the largest increase statewide — up 7.6% to a 41.3% proficiency rate, which ranks Dorchester 19th of 24 districts.
Dorchester Superintendent Jymil Thompson said in a press release that the improvement is a sign the district's work to climb the state rankings is paying off.
"These results show that belief leads to action — and action leads to results," Thompson said. " ... Today, we can proudly say Dorchester is on the rise."
Caroline tied for the fifth highest year-to-year improvement in English proficiency at 3.5%. The district's new English proficiency rate of 49% now ranks it 14th in the state.
Meanwhile, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties were three of only four districts in Maryland with lower English proficiency rates than last year.
Queen Anne's is still above the state average at 57% proficient, ranking ninth despite a 1.5% drop. Kent dropped 0.5% to 40.7% proficiency, ranking the district 20th statewide.
Talbot is 16th in the state with a 45.4% proficiency rate after a 1.9% year-to-year decrease, the largest decrease in the state. In a statement, Talbot County Public Schools Director of Communications Debbie Gardner said the district is in the process of analyzing MCAP data and will make a presentation to the Board of Education in September.
PROGRESS IN MATH
All 23 counties and Baltimore City are seeing progress in math. No district decreased in its math score from 2023-2024, and over a quarter of Maryland students are proficient in the subject.
Dorchester, again, saw the biggest hike of the Mid-Shore counties at 4.1%. The county is still just 20th statewide at 16.4% proficient. Kent follows at 21st with a 16.3% rate, up 3.7% from last year.
Kent County Superintendent Mary Boswell-McComas said in a statement that the district has worked on professionally developing school principals in math.
"We're seeing the payoff in how our principals coached teachers in developing students' mathematical reasoning and how our teachers incorporated that in their classrooms," the statement read.
Queen Anne's remains the Mid-Shore county most proficient in math at 31.6%, a 2.9% hike from one year ago. The district ranks eighth in the state.
Caroline jumped 2.5% to hit 22.2% proficiency, which ranks the district 15th.
Caroline Superintendent Derek Simmons wrote in a statement that he's "very encouraged" to see the district's growth rate outpace the state's.
"Our sustained focus on what matters, and consistency around evidence-based approaches will continue our growth," Simmons wrote.
Talbot math proficiency remained almost even, going up 0.6% to 18.9% this year. The district ranks 18th in proficiency. Only two other districts had year-to-year changes worse than Talbot.
UP AND DOWN IN SCIENCE
Proficiency rates from the fifth and eighth grade science tests show Queen Anne's schools are well above the rest of the five Mid-Shore counties. In fifth grade, Queen Anne's is 10th of 24 districts with 29.3% proficiency, according to data on the Maryland Report Card.
But Talbot saw the state's second-highest yearly increase, climbing 5.9% to 22.8% and 15th overall.
Kent comes in at 16th in fifth grade science at 20.9%. Caroline is 18th with 19% and Dorchester is 20th with 17.4%.
In eighth grade science, Queen Anne's lost its first-place ranking from last year as other districts made significant jumps. But the county is still third in the state at 44.3%, down slightly from last year.
Caroline's eighth graders were 16th in the state at 23.8%, a 4.5% jump. Dorchester increased by 4.6% to 19.9% proficiency, landing it at 18th.
Talbot tied with Queen Anne's for the worst year-to-year change at -0.8%. It is ranked 19th now with 19.3% of eighth graders proficient on the science test.
Kent comes in at 16.8% proficiency, up from 13.4% last year.ENGLISH SCORES

title: As Students Return, Chapel District Elementary Begins Next Phase of Renovations
author: Konner Metz
content:
As students return, Chapel District Elementary begins next phase of renovations

 August 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 513

 Read News Document

 CORDOVA — Renovations at Chapel District Elementary School are well underway as the school prepares to welcome students next week.This summer, construction teams completed the second phase of the project, which includes the school cafeteria and some classrooms. Talbot County Public Schools Director of Operations Kevin Shafer updated the Board of Education on the project at a work session on Monday.
"We did squeeze a lot of work into a very small amount of time, which was a bit risky," Shafer said. "But the team has pulled it together, and things look fairly good."
As crews worked inside and around the building, teacher and staff moved in for the school year earlier this week.
"Staff returned today and it was very smooth according to (Principal Kari) Clow," Shafer said Monday.
The renovation is a multimillion-dollar effort that includes around $27 million in county funding as well as state funds from Maryland's Interagency Commission on School Construction. Construction is led by the Whiting-Turner Contracting Company.
The project is fully renovating the existing building, adding around 16,000 square feet. The Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers site located in the building was redone as part of phase one. Construction is expected to finish in 2026.
Chapel District Elementary is one of five elementary schools in the district. It was built in 1952 and last renovated in 1994.
Shafer acknowledged a few concessions had to be made in order for the school to welcome students back in time. Some hallway flooring hasn't been replaced, but he said it will still be safe in the meantime.
The school's gym won't be ready on the first day, either. It should reopen by the end of September, Shafer said. For now, PE will be held outside or in select classrooms.
Furniture for the first two phases arrived on time, Shafer said. The district had to rework its furniture plan, placing orders this spring before tariffs took effect and drove up prices, Shafer told board members at previous meetings.
Furniture for the third phase was ordered at the same time and is being kept in warehouses by the supplier at no cost to the district, Shafer said.
Drivers passing the elementary school on Cordova Road will likely see significant construction work obstructing the front of the building. That's the third phase of construction, which includes renovations to the administrative offices and some classrooms. A new media center is also being added to the school.
A temporary front office is located at the back of the building where the Critchlow Adkins Children's Center is located, according to a recent school newsletter. Parking will remain limited during construction.
"By the time students come next week, everything should be in good order," Shafer said on Monday.
On Thursday, Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi shouted out Chapel District Elementary administrators, teachers and staff.
"They are going to be teaching through the sounds of loud noises, construction, dust," Pepukayi said. "They packed up their rooms at the end of the year. They just unpacked their rooms this year. And they are still managing to assemble classrooms to be ready for our students to walk through the door on Monday."

title: Dorchester Schools Restricting Cell Phone Usage
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Dorchester schools restricting cell phone usage

 August 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 443
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Dorchester County Board of Education passed its new student policy on the use of electronic equipment, internet safety and portable electronic communication devices at the final board meeting before the school year begins.The new policy is harsher than previous years', banning the use of personal electronic devices during the entire school day. Students' devices must remain off and stored. Consequences will vary case by case, but violations may lead to confiscation and discipline, with severe penalties for recording or sharing inappropriate content.
"I recognized that there probably will be a learning curve for students and parents with this policy," board President Sheri Hubbard said during the Aug. 21 meeting.
Hubbard shared that during her time at the National School Board Convention, she attended a presentation from a high schooler who said not having her phone during lunch has made her class closer because they truly talk to one another now.
"And students, I just wanted to give you that little glimmer of hope, that all is not lost," Hubbard said. "Your life will not end because your cell phone is in the locker."
Peter Singleton, who has been working within Dorchester schools for 53 years, urged the board to vote in favor of the harsher policy. He said he's seen the negative effects of students being on their phone during class or walking down the hallway.
When the board passed the policy, Singleton quietly said, "Thank you, thank you, thank you, God."
Board members did not make this decision hastily. A majority of the members acknowledged the 115 comments they received from the public, wanting commenters to know their responses did not go unread or unheard.
"I want to make it clear, I read every single one of them. And I want that message out there to the public because there were a lot of people who responded with copies of their own research, and I've done a bunch of research as well as we've shared among the board, and I see the different perspectives on it, and I was really pleased to see, number one, that many people responded and two, with very real impact to them," board member Chris Wheedleton said.
The responses showed 38 responders were for the new policy, 59 said yes with some suggestions, and seven people opposed it, Wheedleton said. He said the remaining individuals had questions surrounding some of the policy's language, which Dorchester Assistant Superintendent Michael Collins said the board addressed in this iteration of the policy.
"They need to learn how we converse with each other," Singleton said after the meeting. "That's what life's all about."
The new policy will be in effect for this upcoming school year, which starts Sept. 2.

title: Talbot School Officials Discuss AI Guidelines for Students, Teachers
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot school officials discuss AI guidelines for students, teachers

 August 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 659
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County school district leaders aren't only focusing on how to moderate student use of artificial intelligence — they're looking to teachers, too.New guidelines discussed at a Board of Education work session Monday encourage teachers and staff to use AI responsibly. But AI shouldn't be used as a replacement for lesson planning or decision-making, said Robin Werner, the district's director of teaching and learning.
"It should be enhancing our instruction, but human oversight is imperative," Werner said. "We are not using it to replace any positions or staff members, but it is really a guiding tool that can help teachers."
On Monday, Werner presented an AI guidelines document to be observed this school year. While not a formal policy, the document lays out how the district's schools, teachers, staff and students should use AI.
Staff are encouraged to be transparent, and Werner said students should be comfortable asking when they can use AI tools.
AVOIDING THE 'GRAY AREA'
A committee of Talbot County teachers and administrators began researching AI last fall and developed the guidelines this winter. They visited the district's middle and high schools this spring to consult with teachers.
"Our goal is to ensure that AI empowers students and staff while maintaining academic integrity, equity and human oversight," Werner told board members.
Board members on Monday weighed whether to rely solely on the guidelines or consider adopting official policy changes. Policies and administrative regulations must be approved by the board.
Talbot County Public Schools' work to regulate AI comes as Werner said the State Department of Education is lagging behind other states in creating AI rules.
TCPS academic integrity and plagiarism policies are tied to state rules, which hasn't been updated to include new AI provisions, Werner said. Revising Talbot's official policies before any state updates wouldn't be prudent, she said.
"My suggestion would be that we wait until the state updates their code of conduct, and then we could avoid having to update it more than once," Werner said.
But Board President Emily Jackson said that while she understands AI is ever-evolving, a policy could spell out the standards more clearly.
"If we don't have solid policy to lean back on … I find it gets stickier and into that gray area," Jackson said.
Board member Dyshekia Strawberry agreed, and recommended the board adopt an AI policy, even if broad in nature, as the district waits for clearer advice from the state.
"Just to set some safety standards, such as not uploading any confidential information," Strawberry said.
Jackson suggested the policy committee bring back an AI policy or administrative regulation to the board at a future date.
STUDENT RULES
Despite not being an official policy, the guidelines highlight some specific rules that students and teachers should follow.
AI is prohibited when used to plagiarize or bully, Werner said.
Werner said the district will be piloting a rubric scaled from 0-4 this year for students. Teachers, if they wish, can notate certain assignments in one of the following categories:
0, AI cannot be used.1, AI can support ideas and brainstorming. Disclosure statement on how it was used is required.2, AI can assist in editing but not creating new material. Disclosure statement and link to AI chats must be included when work is submitted.3, AI can complete a specific task approved by the teacher. AI chats must be disclosed, and AI-created content must be properly cited.4, AI can be fully used as a "co-pilot" with human oversight. AI chats must be disclosed, and AI-created content must be properly cited.
Werner said staff appreciated the rubric, which was adapted from guidelines in North Carolina.
The district is encouraging that misuse of AI be "teachable moments" instead of automatic jumps to discipline, Werner said. That will give the students a "clear understanding on how AI can be used to enhance their education, not replace it," she said.
This year, members of Talbot's AI committee will be visiting elementary schools. Werner said it's "imperative" to stay on top of the issue and provide the best guidance to the district's youngest learners.

title: Court Rules Digital Ad Tax Violates First Amendment
author: Bryan P. Sears Maryland Matters
content:
Court rules digital ad tax violates First Amendment

 August 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BRYAN P. SEARS Maryland Matters | Section: State News 
 
 461
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A provision in Maryland's digital ad tax is an unconstitutional restriction on free speech, a federal appeals court ruled Friday.The 2021 law — the first of its kind in the nation — imposes taxes on large tech companies for the digital ads they sell within the state. But it prohibits those companies from passing the tax on to consumers as a surcharge, fee or line item on their bills — what a three-judge panel of the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals saw as a ban on telling customers about the new added tax.
In a ruling that invoked American protests against the Colonial-era Stamp Act, Circuit Judge Julius Richardson wrote that, as then, "complaining about taxes remains a grand American political tradition." And the court said Maryland lawmakers went too far by adding language to the tax bill that was intended to shield them from public criticism.
"Perhaps fearing such complaints, Maryland paired its tax with another rule," Richardson wrote for the court. "Companies that make money advertising on the internet must not only pay the tax, but avoid telling their customers how it affects pricing: No line items, no surcharges, no fees.
"If companies pass on the cost of the tax, they must do so in silence — keeping customers in the dark about why prices have gone up and thereby insulating Maryland from political responsibility," he wrote.
The ruling reverses a 2024 decision by U.S. District Judge Lydia Kay Griggsby, who agreed with the plaintiffs — a group of tech firms and business associations — that the law created some First Amendment issues. But she let the law stand because the offending provision had "many constitutional applications."
Friday's circuit court ruling sent the case back to Griggsby with instructions to determine an appropriate remedy for the plaintiffs.
The ruling is a blow to officials who looked to the unique tax to help pay for expensive K-12 education reforms contained in the Blueprint for Maryland's Future. Expenses associated with that law continue to rise and are potentially budget busting — even if the digital ad tax survives the onslaught of legal challenges.
The 2021 law — sponsored by Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City) — targets big tech firms including Apple, Meta and Google.
Under the law, companies reporting $100 million of gross global annual revenue are subject to a 2.5% levy. The tax increases in increments of 2.5% to a maximum rate of 10% levied against companies reporting more than $15 billion in gross global revenue.
The state could collect as much as $250 million annually from the digital ad tax, according to a legislative analysis. The funds are earmarked for the education reform program.
Neither Ferguson nor Comptroller Brooke Lierman (D), the defendant in the lawsuit, immediately responded to requests for comment on the ruling Friday.

 Author/Byline: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 396

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline County Board of Education members unanimously voted in favor of the North Caroline High site for the new location for Lockerman Middle School.The approval came at the board's meeting Aug. 5. The site puts the new middle school right next to North Caroline High School, giving the county its second location with a middle school and high school on the same property.
The North Caroline High site will allow 15.52 acres of space for the build of Lockerman Middle. The exact location of the building on the site has not been determined yet.
At the previous Board of Education meeting in July, multiple reasons came forward on why the North Caroline High site was recommended over a Double Hills Road site that was also being considered.
"Some of the highlights that came out throughout the analysis and the surveys was, again, the infrastructure. If you're not spending a lot of money on that, the site readiness, the educational alignment, a lot of really exciting ideas came out during the community meeting of ways that you could really have mentorships and things like that with the older and the younger students being on one site," said Robyn Toth, architect for the new school, in July.
Reason included the ability to share space for events at North Caroline High.
"There's clear paths for the indoor and outdoor activities," Toth said. "There's no crossing of streets, lots of capabilities there also because you are sharing more spaces… There were some concerns about large events and right now, if they're at Double Hills or if they're at Lockerman now, where do we go for these large events? That don't happen that often and you don't necessarily need to build more space that the state's not going to support. Well, you've got a high school right there that's got a large auditorium. ."
Bill Mengel, director of operations for Caroline County Public Schools, said the only concern with the North Caroline High site is the solar array on the property. The county has been in conversation with Tesla to purchase the solar array. No official purchase has been made yet.
To purchase the solar panels on the property, it would cost about $180,000, which doesn't include the cost of relocation.
Board members said the decision on the location was a very early step in a marathon of decisions before the new school will be built.

title: Seconds Count: The Country School Hosts Active Shooter Training for Law Enforcement, EMS
author: Konner Metz
content:
Seconds count: The Country School hosts active shooter training for law enforcement, EMS

 July 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 591
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — With schools starting back up next month, police and first responders gathered at The Country School in Easton on Thursday to partake in active shooter training.Four separate drills took place Thursday. Officers entered the school to take down a mock shooter. They joined with paramedics and EMTs to locate mock students in classrooms, assess their injuries and evacuate them from the building in a safe manner.
Responders often communicated with one another on how to follow the proper incident command tactics, at times acknowledging the improvements they could make to their decisions during the drill. Caroline County Cpl. Kenny Tull said the drills will help improve all aspects of emergency response if a school shooting occurs on the Mid-Shore.
"It's a learning experience for everyone," Tull said.
In previous years, active shooter training took place at schools in Talbot and Caroline counties.
Recently, the drills have included a team of both law enforcement and EMS personnel called the Rescue Task Force. Once a hallway or area is cleared, officers will protect unarmed EMTs and paramedics in "warm zones," where danger may still exist even if the main threat is eliminated.
That practice is life-saving in a real situation, Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said.
"Before, (EMS personnel) didn't go in until the building got cleared, which caused more deaths," he said. "The quicker we can get treatment for people, the quicker we can get paramedics in there with us, the more people that hopefully will survive."
Still, the top priority is eliminating the shooter or main threat.
"The initial driving force is stop the killing, because the statistics will show you that an assailant can kill more people than you can treat," Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said.
"Their driving force is stop the dying," Lowrey said of EMTs and paramedics. "You toggle between those two driving forces."
Gamble said first responders have taken FEMA-required incident command training, which serves as a common baseline for members of different agencies.
"A lot of this stuff spawned out of 9/11, getting fire, police, paramedics everybody on the same page. Square up communications," Gamble said.
Having so many agencies on hand Thursday was an opportunity for first responders to acclimate with one another and become more comfortable working together during an emergency response, agency leaders said.
Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker emphasized that local agencies already share a solid rapport.
"You'd be surprised how much there is interaction between counties and agencies," Baker said.
Plus, the geography of Mid-Shore counties sometimes means Caroline County police may be first on the scene to a Talbot County emergency, or vice versa.
"For something that happens at Preston Elementary, Talbot County will be the first ones there," Talbot County Maj. Steve Elliott said. "If something happens at Chapel Elementary, Caroline County will be the first ones there."
Tina Kintop, EMS division chief for the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services, said it's most important for EMTs and paramedics to be disciplined and properly trained to participate in the rescue task force with police.
On Thursday, the drills didn't stop when the mock shooter went down. First responders secured students, assessed the severity of their injuries and evacuated them from the building. The job doesn't end there, Kintop said.
Police and EMS focus on locating a site for reunification of families. Gamble said different schools already have plans in place for reunification spots, some of which have been used for fire drills or bomb threats in the past.
By practicing these processes Thursday, agencies worked to create a streamlined plan they hope they will never have to use.
"It's all about organization and accountability," Kintop said.

title: Talbot, Kent See Rise in Student Homelessness
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot, Kent see rise in student homelessness

 July 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 674
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — State numbers show youth homelessness on the rise in parts of the Eastern Shore. Local shelters aiding families and single parents are noticing similar trends.Data from the Maryland State Department of Education shows Kent and Talbot counties had the largest year-to-year increase, by percentage, of students experiencing homelessness.
In the 2022-2023 school year, Kent County reported 66 homeless students; in 2023-2024, it took a 55% jump to 102 students. Talbot County's increase rate was 39%; 233 students experienced homelessness in 2022-2023, and 324 students in 2023-2024.
Counts for 2024-2025 haven't yet been released — the most recent data was published in February — but leaders of nonprofit shelters have been seeing the increases in recent months.
"We are definitely seeing an increase in calls for families needing shelter," said Julie Lowe, executive director of Talbot Interfaith Shelter.
Last school year, Easton-based Talbot Interfaith housed 31 children, Lowe said. That's a "steady increase," she noted, though the shelter is limited on how many families it can help due to high demand, requirements for shelter residents and bedroom sizes.
Just three of Maryland's 24 districts saw a year-to-year drop in student homelessness, state data shows. The counts are collected as required by the federal McKinney-Vento Act, which ensures students experiencing homelessness receive an education.
A reason for the increase in Kent County is that school staff are better trained to identify the students defined as homeless under the McKinney-Vento Act, according to Kent County Public Schools spokesperson Dan Divilio.
"Homelessness in Kent County looks different from the common perception of someone living on the street or in a car," Divilio wrote in an email. "Unhoused students often still have a roof over their head at night, but it may belong to an extended family member or a family friend."
Divilio added that in addition to free school meals and the efforts of social workers and counselors, the district maintains partnerships with local organizations that serve families and children in need.
Talbot County Public Schools officials say the pandemic has played a role in the increased count.
"The number of students experiencing homelessness is generally a reflection of the current economic climate in the nation, state, and region," a statement from the district read. "The increase from SY 22-23 to SY 23-24, which is evident in the data for nearly all Maryland School Districts, was largely due to economic challenges faced by many families following the COVID-19 pandemic."
In Talbot, around 7% of students are homeless under the McKinney-Vento report, per state enrollment data. Nearly 6% of Kent County's 1,700-plus students experienced homelessness.
Those marks in other Eastern Shore districts like Dorchester (3.6%), Queen Anne's (2.9%) and Caroline (2.2%) are lower, but the need to help the youth still remains, nonprofit leaders say.
Stefanie Johnson, executive director of the Denton-based shelter His Hope Ministries, has seen an increase in families and single parents seeking assistance, too.
The McKinney-Vento data for Kent County doesn't come as a shock to her. And Divilio, the KCPS spokesperson, noted that the district's count for 2024-2025 is 108 children, including children enrolled K-12 and toddlers in the district's early learning programs.
"Absolutely a lot more calls coming to us from Kent County, so I'm not really surprised by that unfortunately," Johnson said.
Shelters on the Eastern Shore are moving to assist homeless youth, but helping that age range comes with its own unique set of obstacles.
Johnson said a specific challenge in the 13- to 18-year-old range is that her shelter can't take on children without some sort of guardianship or family present.
"With that 18 to 25 (age range), it's a little easier to kind of help them navigate," Johnson said.
Lowe said the Talbot Interfaith Shelter serves many single parents — some of them with two or three kids. The shelter offers life skills and job readiness assistance, as well as a transitional program for people to begin paying partial rent before being able to graduate to full payments.
But with the murky affordability of rentals in the area, Lowe said it's not always easy for families to make that transition.
"Homelessness is a housing problem," she said.
