title: 'Closing Gaps': TCPS Data Shows Some Literacy, Math Improvements
author: Konner Metz
content:
'Closing gaps': TCPS data shows some literacy, math improvements

 July 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 586
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Test score data from last school year is showing key math and English improvements for some Talbot County students, according to school officials.Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi presented data sets to the Board of Education last week. She's especially pleased with jumps for the district's Black and Hispanic students.
"We are closing gaps and moving the needle on the subgroups," Pepukayi said in an interview.
School data from the Measures of Academic Progress, or MAP, testing program shows 68% of kindergarten students scored in the 50th percentile or above in math in the 2024-2025 school year. That's up from 54% the year prior.
The percent of students, sorted by grade, meeting or exceeding that 50th percentile for the math and ELA tests mostly increased across the board. Dips were seen for third and fifth graders in ELA performance.
And in subgroups, there were many green arrows for Black and Hispanic students. For instance, both Black and Hispanic third graders saw a 31% year-to-year jump in testing at the 50th percentile mark or above in math, and a 21% year-to-year increase for that same mark in ELA.
"I'm really glad to see such improvement in the Latino and Black community. That's huge," said Board Member Deborah Bridges at the July 16 meeting.
Pepukayi attributes the hikes, in part, to improved curriculum and the dedication of Talbot County's teachers.
"I can't pinpoint to say that was it, but I think we're on the right track of students learning skills that are aligned to standards," Pepukayi said. "And we're looking at students being proficient on standards versus just getting a grade."
The tests discussed at last week's board meeting included MAP testing and the Dynamic Indicators of Basic Early Literacy Skill test. Statewide test scores typically are released in August or September.
DIBELS scores weren't drastically different from the year prior. A higher percentage of rising first and third graders tested above the literacy benchmark in 2024-2025 than 2023-2024, but second graders above the benchmark dropped by 5%.
In the MAP testing, the percent of fifth graders meeting the 50th percentile for ELA dropped by 6.6%. That decrease was mirrored by ELA drops for fifth graders in the following subgroups: Hispanic students, students with disabilities, multilingual students and students on free and reduced meals.
Data also shows this year's incoming sixth-grade class performed 4.1% worse in ELA in fifth grade than they did in fourth grade.
"Fifth graders are the kids that didn't get to finish kindergarten because of COVID," noted Board Vice President Amy Dodson.
Pepukayi said the next step is to fix those trends by focusing on the elementary-to-middle transition. She said in an interview that TCPS is vying to fill open reading and math coach positions for the middle schools — roles that have been beneficial at the elementary schools.
"That's what we're working on," Pepukayi said. "I would say that's probably the challenge, of getting our staff and finding the staff to really do the interventions needed in the middle-school levels."
She emphasized that schools are collecting data on a smaller, classroom scale in order to know what's working and what's not.
"While we still have work to do, I think we do have to celebrate the small wins," Pepukayi said.
Board President Emily Jackson thanked Pepukayi and administrators for diving deeper into the year-to-year trends.
"We have been asking for these kind of results for a long time," said Jackson, who's served on the board since 2018. "And the way that you showed up with the full transparent picture of what is happening in our schools, I think is really important."

title: Dorchester School Board Adjusts Spending in Wake of Federal Budget Cuts

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County Board of Education met Thursday for the first time since hearing about massive U.S. Department of Education budget cuts.According to the Maryland Department of Education, the Department of Education informed them that they will not be receiving the $360 million that federal officials had allocated to the state.
Dorchester share of the funding cuts will be about $642,000.
This comes at a time when Dorchester County Public Schools are already struggling financially, having dealt with a $10.19 million deficit in January that forced the county to make hard decisions like cutting afterschool and summer programs.
However, the the board was able to make several approvals with only one program cut during Thursday's meeting.
Board members approved the following:
The board approved a five-year writable contract for grades 6-12, which is critical for writing instruction and assessments tied to state standards. The entire $50,000 cost is covered in this year's budget.Approved a five-year IXL learning contract for grades 3-12, which is budgeted at $23,000 for the current year and future payments must be budgeted in subsequent years.Approved Math Curriculum Consumables, which is paid from this year's textbook budget.Approved the annual contract with the Dorchester County Health Department school nurse contract.Approved the Facilities Master Plan Update which is necessary for capital improvement eligibility.
Board members did not renew or approve Lexia, a widely used computer-based literacy program designed to help students improve their reading skills, because of concerns and issues with its effectiveness like inaccurate data, lack of instructional alignment among teachers and staff, and its high cost.
The board will meet again in August to discuss policies regarding digital devices, AI and dress codes.

title: Superintendent and Commissioners Discuss Lockerman
author: Ahmad Garnett
content:
Superintendent and commissioners discuss Lockerman

 Author/Byline: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Caroline 
 
 474

 DENTON — The Caroline County Commissioners and Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons discussed Lockerman Middle School at the County Commissioners meeting on Tuesday.At the last commissioners meeting, the commissioners discussed their role, responsibilities and preferred location for the new Lockerman Middle School.
The superintendent came to the commissioners meeting to discuss the approval of its fiscal year 2026 budget. After the discussion the commissioners talked about Lockerman Middle School and the next steps.
"I think it'd be good for us to say that we are working together on the Lockerman Middle School construction," Commissioners President Travis Breeding said. "We were asking questions about what role the commissioners officially play in siting and construction, they were just questions that we were asking. It wasn't like the Board of Ed's going to run all over us and make crazy stupid decisions and we're going to be stuck with it. It was just what influence do we have over the process."
Breeding explained the consensus the commissioners have come to on their personal choice for the new school location.
"I think we talked about it, and our consensus is that the most logical place to put it is probably next to North Carolina High School for us," Breeding said. "We understand that there's a whole process that has to be going through, fact finding, the Board of Ed will review that and make their decisions based off of that. But we were just saying that that questioning what influence we actually had over the process."
Simmons clarified they understand the commissioners wanting understanding of their role and told the commissioners how the process will go.
"Board of Education selects the site," Simmons said. "The feasibility study, which was presented to the board on July 1st, indicated North Caroline High School was the better of the two locations. We did review the two sites that we were asked to review that were basically the county-owned, which is cost efficient way to do it.
Simmons said the board received the feasibility study that night and should be making its decision on a site at the August meeting. He added the site selection does not include picking what the design of the building will be.
After looking over potential designs for the new Lockerman Middle School, Breeding suggested having athletic facilities have their own location and not sharing fields.
"One of the major things that stuck out with me was, relocating the athletic facilities around there," Breeding said. "If we can get dedicated facilities so we're not sharing space like we have been doing forever, where lacrosse or soccer is using the outfield of the softball and the baseball field, if we can actually get dedicated space, that would be a priority of mine."
He noted that facilities in surrounding counties should be studied.
"We've got one bite at the apple here, let's get it right," Breeding said.

 Dorchester County Public Schools are projected to lose over $642,000 in federal funding after the Trump Administration suddenly announced the decision to withhold $6.8 billion in federal education cuts, according to DCPS communications specialist Casey O'Bier.The U.S. Department of Education cut 28 K-12 programs saying "states and localities, not the Federal government, are best suited to determine whether to support the activities authorized under this program or similar activities within their own budgets and without unnecessary administrative burden imposed by the Federal government," or stating the program has not been proven effective, or that cutting funding is to restore fiscal discipline in the states.
In an email to the Star Democrat, O'Bier said those cuts will impact a variety of programs including teacher training, internal and external student experiences, and English Language Learner programs.
"DCPS would need to reallocate existing funds to sustain programs that were originally funded through some of these federal grants or eliminate various programs in a worst-case scenario," O'Bier stated as one of the district's central concerns.
The federal funding cuts to education come at a time when Dorchester County Public Schools are already struggling financially.
In January, DCPS faced a budget deficit of $10.19 million, which they reduced to $5.59 million in March. To further reduce the deficit, DCPS got rid of their after school and summer programs.
The county had to reduce staff sizing, but Superintendent Jymil Thompson said he wants to keep class sizes small and retain teachers at all costs.
The Board of Education has been making concerted efforts to move DCPS from 23rd out of 24 school districts — including Baltimore City — in state education ranking, but the federal funding cuts make those efforts more difficult.
"Moving forward, we will be proactively looking closely at unique ways to reallocate pre-existing funds to support the inclusion of these federally funded programs which are a major asset to Dorchester County Public Schools and the enrichment of its students," O'Bier said.

title: Ed Spec Committee Recommends North Caroline Site for New Lockerman Middle
author: Ahmad Garnett
content:
Ed Spec Committee recommends North Caroline site for new Lockerman Middle

 July 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News

 DENTON — The Caroline County Board of Education is one step closer to picking a new location for Lockerman Middle School.At the monthly Board of Education meeting Tuesday, the Lockerman Middle School Ed Specs Committee said that after the feasibility study and community input, the recommended location for the new school is on the same property as North Caroline High School.
Board of Education members decided not to formally vote on a location after receiving almost two hours of information from the Ed Specs Committee. The board decided to push the decision back to the August meeting.
Multiple reasons came forward on why the North Caroline High site was recommended over the Double Hills Road site.
"Some of the highlights that came out throughout the analysis and the surveys was again, the infrastructure. If you're not spending a lot of money on that, the site readiness, the educational alignment, a lot of really exciting ideas came out during the community meeting of ways that you could really have mentorships and things like that with the older and the younger students being on one site," said Robyn Toth, architect for the new school.
Reason included the use for indoor and outdoor activities and the ability to share space for events at North Caroline High.
"There's clear paths for the indoor and outdoor activities," Toth said. "There's no crossing of streets, lots of capabilities there also because you are sharing more spaces… There were some concerns about large events and right now, if they're at Double Hills or if they're at Lockerman now, where do we go for these large events? That don't happen that often and you don't necessarily need to build more space that the state's not going to support. Well, you've got a high school right there that's got a large auditorium. It's got a large gym."
With the North Caroline High location, development prices will be about $500,000 cheaper. The site development for the North Caroline High location will be $10 million, while Double Hills Road would cost $10.5 million.
Although in the community meetings multiple builds were shown, the new middle school, regardless of the location, will be a two-story building with a two-wing design.
According to the Ed Specs Committee Powerpoint, the new anticipated project budget would be $103.82 million with state funding coming in at around $80 million and local funding covering the remainder.
The only concerns brought up about the North Caroline High site were the solar array on the property and the traffic Central Avenue could receive from a new school being added to the location.
To purchase the solar panels on the property, it would cost about $180,000, which doesn't include the cost of relocation.
The Board of Education will take all the information received and make a decision on what location will be picked at its August meeting.

title: Melas til Monday Director Recognized for Efforts to Feed Children in the Summer
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Melas til Monday director recognized for efforts to feed children in the summer

 June 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 435

 CAMBRIDGE — MidShore Meals til Monday's Executive Director Pam Allen was recognized as one of 11 Summer Hunger Heroes by No Kid Hungry on Tuesday."I don't do what I do for recognition," Allen said {span}in an interview following the rollout event for Meals til Monday's summer program, where she received the award.{/span} "I understand that there's a need in the community, and it's not about myself. As I said Tuesday, this is about Meals til Monday as a whole, but it really felt good to be honored."
Allen began working volunteering for Meals til Monday during the pandemic. She then obtained her community health worker certificate to help people access services like Medicare and Medicaid. Allen said this naturally aligned with her work at Meals til Monday.
Her recognition comes after a yearlong process of filing for grants, receiving donations and working with community organization partners to buy a refrigerated van, which allows Meals til Monday's summer program to reach more children in Dorchester County and expands the program's capabilities.
"It's not necessarily about how many more kids that we're reaching as much as it's about what else we can give the kids," Allen said. With the van, Allen said they are able to pick up large bins, also known as gaylords, of produce and frozen foods that would otherwise go bad.
Summer is identified by Food Action and Research Center as the hungriest time for kids because they lose access to free school meals. In Dorchester County, students are provided free daily breakfast and lunch through a federally funded program called the Community Eligibility Provision.
This provision is available if 25% or more of the student population participate in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, Temporary Assistance for Needy Families, the Food Distribution Program on Indian Reservations or Medicaid, according to the United States Department of Agriculture's website.
"We have partnered with Dorchester County Public Schools and we are delivering two meals for seven days to anyone that registers for children 18 and under," Allen said.
Allen said Meals til Monday is still providing regular weekend meal bags for anyone who needs them, and emergency food services are available with options for pick-up or delivery by appointment.
Allen encourages anyone who wants to volunteer to sign up on the website. "One of the things that we're trying to do as we continue to grow as an organization is to have the appropriate policies and waivers and things like that for our volunteers." Those can be found at midshoremealstilmonday.org.
"It feels absolutely wonderful. I am just so honored," Allen said about receiving recognition from No Kid Hungry. "Our primary mission is to feed children."

title: Caroline Commissioners Weigh Potential Locations for New Lockerman Middle
author: Ahmad Garnett
content:
Caroline commissioners weigh potential locations for new Lockerman Middle

 June 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 666
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — During the Caroline County Commissioners' open comment report Tuesday morning, Commissioners Vice President Larry Porter brought up the discussion on Lockerman Middle School's proposed locations.Porter said he preferred that the new middle school go on the North Caroline High School property, one of two locations being considered during the design processes for the building begin. The other location, near the county sheriff's office on Double Hills Road, presents several challenges, Porter said.
"I think at this point I would like to say that I am in favor of the North Carolina location as opposed to being built in town," Porter said.
Commissioners Frank Bartz agreed with Porter and cited traffic and safety concerns on Route 404.
The commissioners also had discussions about the school's location at their meeting two weeks ago.
At that meeting, County Administrator Kathleen Freeman presented the two location options. Commissioners President Travis Breeding sparked a conversation about how much sway the commissioners have over the school's location.
"How much influence do the commissioners actually have over where the school gets constructed?" Breeding asked two weeks ago. "As part of the funding of this, other than a survey, we haven't really been consulted."
Breeding then explained the issues they would run into with each potential location.
"From what I gather, it seemed like a lot of people really preferred the Double Hills location. But, with Double Hills, we've got to work out a ton of details with the Town of Denton as far as sewer, water allocation for that to work, potentially pump station upgrades," Breeding said.
He then mentioned traffic issues on Route 404 with beach traffic towards the end of the school year and students from northern county towns like Marydale, who would have to take the bus a long distance to the potential Double Hills location.
Porter, said he didn't recall that "the county did not have a lot of input" on the design of new county buildings in the past.
Freeman assured Breeding that the county will be involved with the full feasibility study for both sites to determine which site makes the most sense.
Breeding also brought forward discussion of how much influence the commissioners will have for the design of the school.
"Then also, how much input do we have over the the design?" Breeding asked. "I mean, we don't want a situation where we're building something that's way more expensive than it needs to be or making it as functional as we can and keeping the cost as low as we can."
Bartz raised an issue where if the county has to build a new detention center, a school on the Double Hills Road site would cause a problem. The Caroline County Sheriff's Office is located near that Double Hills Road site, making the location logical for a detention center, he said.
The county is in talks with Queen Anne's County about a new 388-bed regional detention center that would house all Caroline, Queen Anne's and Kent county prisoners. After conversations about control and cost of the center, discussions between the three counties have slowed down.
Lockerman name
Porter pointed out conversation that are being had about the Lockerman's name staying at the location of the current building instead of being attached to the new school.
Though the existing building will no longer be used as a school when the new school is built, Porter said he was in favor of keeping the Lockerman name attached to the facility in the interest of honoring its history.
"I think it's going to be important that the history of the school and the name of Lockerman be retained," he said. "I don't know what the future use is going to be for that building, but it's important, I think, from the alumni standpoint, from the community standpoint, that the history be be kept there for whatever use is going to be done in the future."
Breeding suggested drafting a letter of intent to the Caroline County Board of Education stating that it would be the commissioners' intention to retain the name of the building.

title: Dorchester County Council to Submit Five Legislative Initiatives
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Dorchester County Council to submit five legislative initiatives

 June 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 379

 Dorchester County Council Members are planning to submit five recommendations for the Maryland Association of County's 2026 legislative initiatives.MACo will select four initiatives based on feedback and suggestions from Maryland's county jurisdictions and Baltimore City to prioritize during the state's General Assembly beginning in January.
MACo's 2025 initiatives focused on local revenue structures, infrastructural funding, the Blueprint for Maryland's Future and clean energy. Dorchester County's recommendations for 2026 do not differ too much.
The Dorchester County Council's five recommendations are:
To consider a pause or suspension of the Blueprint for Maryland's Future education plan to allow counties to catch up financially.To rethink or review existing rules or policies that override local control over solar energy regulations.To improve infrastructure related to transportation and water drainage in Dorchester County.To introduce an initiative regarding safety concerns of solar battery storage and concerns regarding the sufficiency of the decommissioning bond that covers the cost of removing solar infrastructure once it's no longer in use.To continue to reform juvenile justice. This recommendation came after a 15-year-old resident shot and killed another resident in the 900 block of Cornelia Street on June 8.
County Council Vice President Mike Detmer said juvenile justice laws need serious reformation to make Dorchester County a safer place.
"Whether you're below 18 or over 18, you have to get some feedback for your actions," Detmer said. "Your terrible actions aren't in a vacuum; we all live here."
The purpose of MACo's recommended initiatives is to address problems counties are facing with state legislators. County Council President Lenny Pfeffer said the organization collects concerns and information from counties to assist them in navigating the legislative process at the General Assembly.
Detmer said that these initiatives don't always align with Dorchester County due to the county's unique set of problems, and this misalignment has caused some tension with the state. "You know, things are complicated," he said. "I would say the tension really stems from the policies and laws that the state is enacting."
Elected officials from Maryland's 23 counties and Baltimore City can submit legislative proposal initiatives on behalf of the county as an elected body, generally at an open meeting or via a voting process, or not on behalf of the county, but as an individual.
Nominations can be submitted online through June 27 on the MACo website.

title: Talbot County OKs $161 million budget
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County OKs $161 million budget

 May 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 685
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County made good on its promise to deliver a flat, conservative budget for fiscal year 2026. The County Council unanimously passed a $161.1 million spending plan Tuesday.It comes in at nearly $3 million under last year's budget amid what County Manager Clay Stamp calls "uncharted waters."
"The economic landscape out there is a bumpy ride right now," Stamp said. "This year, we knew that we needed to flatten the budget out, we needed to live within our means."
Stamp and other officials have emphasized Talbot County's continued financial commitments toward public safety, whether through capital projects such as an EMS station in Cordova or support for correctional officers.
In a draft version of the budget that only received a few adjustments Tuesday, the council is expected to allocate the following funds for public safety:
$11.5 million for emergency medical services.$10.5 million for the Talbot County Sheriff's Office.$7.6 million for the Department of Corrections.$5.4 million for emergency management.$3.3 million for volunteer fire departments.
Council members thanked Stamp, Finance Director Martha Sparks and Assistant Finance Director Kaitlin Foster-Clark for their work during the budget process.
"This was the most challenging budget that I've ever sat through," council member Keasha Haythe said. "The decisions were very hard on some items."
"It was definitely a heavy lift this year, but everyone bucked down, and we made it happen here," council member Dave Stepp said.
The county's property tax rate will remain largely steady at 79 cents per $100 of assessed value, though residents will see a supplemental tax of just over 1 cent per $100 of value on their tax bills.
EDUCATION FUNDING
That supplement stems from education funding OK'd by the county. While most line items were ironed out through deliberations, workshops and meetings, Tuesday's discussion centered on funding amendments for Talbot County Public Schools.
The budget already included $55 million in education funding as required by The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's initiative to fund and improve education. County Council members were left to consider how much the county would contribute above that mark.
In a 4-1 vote Tuesday, the council approved an additional $600,000 in funding for schools, aimed at filling nine positions, including multilingual and special education roles. Council member Lynn Mielke was the sole no vote.
The approved budget change came after an amendment to fulfill the district's entire $1.1 million request — which had been scaled back from $5.5 million earlier this budget cycle — failed narrowly. Vice President Pete Lesher and Haythe favored the $1.1 million, but President Chuck Callahan, Stepp and Mielke did not.
Lesher argued it is "short-sighted" to not fund the full request. He said it'd be prudent for the county to gradually increase its education funding as even higher Blueprint projections loom in future fiscal years.
"This would be a small step in that direction," Lesher said. "And frankly, it will make next year, an election year, a lot easier for all of us up here."
"I think we should be going farther," he said of the $600,000 mark. "But this goes some distance."
Callahan sponsored the amendment to partially OK the district's request, citing the significant need for teachers. The $500,000 not approved by the council was requested by the district to increase teacher and instructional assistant salaries.
"I would ask that the school board use the money that we give you for (hiring) teachers," Callahan said. "I would like to see that, and not for something else."
Mielke said she was initially on board with Callahan's amendment. But she said she needs "more security" that the district will put the $600,000 toward the nine positions.
"I'm not advised that it necessarily would be," Mielke said. "So for that reason I couldn't support it."
A spokesperson for Talbot County Public Schools said in a statement to The Star Democrat that the district stands behind the $1.1 million request but understands the "challenges faced by council and staff in meeting the funding needs of Talbot County in these uncertain times."
"We are grateful for their support for educators' pensions and for the additional staff needed to serve our students," the statement read.
This story has been updated to include a statement from Talbot County Public Schools.

title: Robbins YMCA Opening Reading Hub to Tackle Childhood Illiteracy
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Robbins YMCA opening reading hub to tackle childhood illiteracy

 May 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 500
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Robbins YMCA is stepping up after Dorchester County Public Schools faced significant budget cuts this year.The school district started this budget season with a $10 million deficit. Addressing that deficit meant Dorchester County schools lost after-school and summer programming.
The cuts to education come at a time when the county ranks 21st out of 24 school districts (including Baltimore City) in third grade literacy and 22nd out of 24 in overall English Language Arts proficiency in the state.
The Y is partnering with the John and Janice Wyatt Foundation to create a space for the Dorchester County Campaign for Grade Level Reading, a campaign that aims to target childhood illiteracy.
{span}The campaign was inspired by the movie "Sentenced," which was produced and narrated by NBA champion Stephen Curry. The film explores the epidemic of childhood illiteracy and its lifelong impacts.{/span}
"Dorchester County has, for a long time, been ranked very low in the state of Maryland," said Matthew Peterson, executive director of the John and Janice Wyatt Foundation. "And so interestingly, now concurrent to all the work that the Y is doing, that we're all doing together, Dorchester County Public Schools is undergoing a strategic plan to go from 21st, to 15."
The Dorchester County Campaign for Grade Level Reading plans to approach this goal from multiple angles and with multiple partnerships.
Because third grade is a pivotal marker for childhood learning development, the campaign's target population are children from birth to age 5, so they are better prepared to enter kindergarten, and are less likely to fall behind.
"So we're trying to grab moms as prenatal because we're gonna do infant groups, we're gonna do, you know, toddler groups, mommy and me groups, so we want to bring awareness at early childhood," said Tynice DeShields, director of mental health at the YMCA of Chesapeake.
The campaign's partners include county schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson, the Dorchester County Public Library, United Way of the Lower Eastern Shore, Operation Pathways and volunteers from the community.
"There's a number of agencies we've been working with over the years. You know, as any organization, some were more engaged than others, and so bringing everybody on board, finding out where that alignment fits best, and then trying to leverage that, to do the best we can, is what we've always tried to have," Peterson said.
The reading hub will be a space that is open to the public and YMCA members alike.
"We're building this reading hub as a meeting place where we can have a resource center, we can have meetings with the community, we can have sessions with the parents to teach their kids how to read, how to look at letters and numbers, and not just throw a book in front of them," said Bryant Wittington, director of the Dorchester County Campaign for Grade Level Reading.
Peterson, DeShields and Wittington are excited to engage with the community and hope to build a strong foundation of volunteers at the reading hub.
"We want to build that unity in the community," Wittington said.

title: Talbot Council Mulling $1.1 Million Request from School District
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot council mulling $1.1 million request from school district

 May 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 706
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — With less than two weeks until the Talbot County Council adopts its budget ordinance for next fiscal year, education funding hangs in the balance.Talbot County Public Schools is seeking $1.1 million in additional funds for fiscal year 2026 — $600,000 to fill nine new positions and $500,000 for teacher and staff salary increases. The former would add to the district's multilingual and special education staff, while the latter aims to inch the district closer to state-mandated $60,000 teacher salary minimums by fiscal year 2027.
District leaders say it's a "scaled-back" request from its $5.7 million ask of the county earlier this budget cycle.
"We recognize the financial pressures you face," Board of Education President Emily Jackson said at a May 6 budget hearing. "This ask is lean, deliberate and rooted in what's most necessary to keep moving forward."
In the county's budget already is $55 million for TCPS as required by The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's overarching education improvement framework.
Council members are left to mull the best option as they prepare to vote on final amendments to the county's draft $161 million budget. So far, there's no clear decision.
Council Vice President Pete Lesher supported fulfilling the district's full $5.7 million request last month and maintained that stance for the pared down ask at a budget deliberation Tuesday.
"We're going to have to do it sooner or later," Lesher said. "I think it makes sense to do it this year and reduce the pain next year."
President Chuck Callahan said he feels comfortable with honoring the $600,000 part of the request to cover the new positions.
Council members Keasha Haythe, Lynn Mielke and Dave Stepp have all indicated they need more time to consider options.
Any additional funding granted would result in an education supplement to the property tax rate, which is 79 cents per $100 of assessed value.
Talbot County is already mandated by the state to pay $440,000 for teachers' pensions, which will be collected through a supplement of less than half a cent per $100 of assessed value.
Three potential scenarios for tax supplements have been laid out by county staff:
Teachers' pensions only: 0.0045 per $100 of assessed value.
Teachers' pensions and $500,000 for salary increases: 0.0096 per $100 of assessed value.
Teachers' pensions and $600,000 for new positions: 0.0106 per $100 of assessed value.
Haythe said Tuesday she's trying to balance helping the school system with preventing tax increases for residents on fixed income, such as seniors.
"I am in no way, shape or form trying to discount the great work that the school system does and what the teachers do in the classroom," Haythe said.
At last week's hearing, teachers and parents advocated for the council to include the $1.1 million. Lisa Hayes, a parent of three TCPS graduates, said past education investments are paying off now as her children enter the workforce.
"You cannot not fund a budget for our children's education because there is nothing more important than that," Hayes said.
Andy Burke, president of the Talbot County Education Association, which functions as the teachers' union, made his case.
"We continue to see too many educators migrate away to the higher wages and salaries paid in neighboring public school systems," Burke said.
In an emailed statement, TCPS Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones said the district made "very difficult choices" to reduce its request to the county.
Jones noted staff will present the Board of Education with a budget amendment package in June, which will adjust the $86 million unrestricted budget the board OK'd in February.
"We will eliminate most of the new positions we had requested," Jones wrote. "We will scale back our requests and defer programs that will have the least direct impact on our goals for our students."
A final decision by the county on the $1.1 million in question, as well as the entire FY26 budget, is expected at the council's May 27 meeting.
While no clear choice was made during Tuesday's deliberations, county and district leaders did agree that state mandates and formulas are creating the tricky fiscal situation.
"It's just become screamingly clear that there's a disconnect at the state level between the requirements that they're putting on local schools across the state, and the funding formulas that are articulated to county governments to pay for their education," said County Manager Clay Stamp.

title: Lockerman Middle School Committee Previews Two Sites for New Location
author: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Lockerman Middle School Committee previews two sites for new location

 May 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 560
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Lockerman Middle School Committee held its first community meeting on the potential new Lockerman Middle School location and specifications Thursday.The meeting featured two potential locations for a new school and a third option of staying at the current location.
The first location would be behind North Caroline High School, and the second would be on Double Hills Road in Denton.
While locations are being looked at, the committee made it clear that the current Lockerman Middle School location would still be there, though it may not remain a school.
The community meeting gave committee members and architects the opportunity to hear the publics thoughts on what historic value should be implemented into the new Lockerman school and on the locations selected.
"We're going to be gathering it, reviewing it," said Robyn Toth, owner of TCA Architects and architect for the potential new Lockerman Middle School. "Then as we go through the site design, we'll be trying to incorporate as many of their concerns and try to accentuate any of the possibilities that they were saying."
The North Caroline High location puts the new site directly to the west of the high school. The potential middle school would sit on a 23-acre parcel.
On that parcel, there is a solar field area that architects would have to contend with. There is also a pasture connected to the Career Center that could impact school placement and design.
Community members brought forward suggestions for what the county could do with the Lockerman location if it moved next to North Caroline High. They recommended students could share bus routes with high schoolers and made safety suggestions for both schools.
The Double Hills road site is located near the Caroline County Sheriffs Office and Caroline County Emergency Services buildings on 76 acres. The county owns the land, and the Lockerman Committee is looking for a 21-acre portion.
Kevin Shearon, engineer for the Lockerman project, brought attention to the size and distance of the road and made considerations for what they would do to the road to make it accessible for the school.
"Double Hills is a 20-21 foot road with no shoulders on either side," Shearon said. "So, we would consider adding shoulders, at least on the school side or the site side for ACLD cell and just a wider feel for the right."
According to Lockerman Committee members, the public water and sewer could be extended from the Denton's systems for the potential school.
After explaining both new locations, Lockerman Committee members and Superintendent Derek Simmons answered questions from residents and heard their concerns and suggestions.
"It was great to see the turnout," Simmons said. "It was great to see the engagement, folks are really passionate about their faults, which is great. Our architects and our consultants need that information now as we're working in the very early stages of design. I'm glad they came out.
"There will be another opportunity on June 2, and I hope the turnout is equally as good as not better. Because the board's got a big decision to make in July, and we want to provide them with the best information we can on the sites that we're considering."
The next public meeting on potential school locations will be held on June 2 at Lockerman Middle School at 6 p.m. Following that, the committee will have a presentation to the Board of Education on July 1 about their decision.

title: Tilghman Island Celebrates Opening of Judy Center
author: Konner Metz
content:
Tilghman Island celebrates opening of Judy Center

 April 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 389
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TILGHMAN ISLAND — The Tilghman Elementary School Judy Center, which opened in January, is already serving 40 families.Lori Julian, the center's coordinator, says the early learning hub is important to ensure young children and families become comfortable in a school environment.
"It's really a great transition tool to get children ready and families ready for school," Julian said.
Julian joined community members, school and center staff and state partners Wednesday to cut the ribbon on the Tilghman Island Judy Center. It's Talbot County's third center, following locations in Easton and St. Michaels.
Judy Centers are funded by the state and are a focus of The Blueprint, Maryland's expansive initiative to fund education. Last October, the state awarded a grant to Tilghman Elementary School to create one.
The centers provide workshops, family support services, enrichment and learning activities, and more for children up to five years old, according to the Maryland Department of Education. They provide most services for free for families in the school district where a center is located.
"Learning begins long before a child enters the classroom," Talbot County Public Schools Judy Center Supervisor Amy Walstrum said Wednesday. "It starts at birth."
"The earliest years are the most critical years, and the most influential people during those years are the child's first and most important teachers, who are their families," Walstrum added.
Julian has 25 years of experience as a Judy Center coordinator in Maryland, including in Queen Anne's County and recently at the St. Michaels site. The new Tilghman Island Judy Center is paramount to providing local families with resources, Julian said.
"We had (Tilghman Island) families that were coming to our St. Michaels (site), and then due to funding, we had to tell them they couldn't come anymore," Julian said. "So we lost half our families. So when we put in for this grant, we were blessed to get it here."
Julian says in a way, the Tilghman Island community has been left behind and put at a disadvantage. The elementary school only has about 100 students, community resources are limited and families have to make 20-minute drives to get to a grocery store, she said.
But the Judy Center is a significant step toward closing that gap for local families.
"Because we're such a small school, we really were surprised when we did get the grant," Julian said. "And the families were just thrilled."

title: Dorchester County Makes Its Way Through Grueling Budget Process
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Dorchester County makes its way through grueling budget process

 April 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 694
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Over the past four months, an atmosphere of concern, frustration and, at times, despair has colored budget meetings in Dorchester County.In mid-April, the Dorchester County Council introduced a $91.96 million proposed operating budget for fiscal year 2026 with proposals to increase taxes. The introduction came after months of work by county staff to eliminate an estimated $6.2 million deficit.
At the same time, Dorchester County Public Schools has been working to eliminate a multi-million dollar deficit of its own. At an April budget work session, DCPS Superintendent Jymil Thompson said the district is still $5.59 million in the hole. The district hopes to eliminate the deficit by the Board of Education's May meeting.
To balance and pass these budgets, difficult decisions — like the school district canceling summer school for 2025 and the county increasing 911 fees from $1.50 to $4.25 — have already been made.
"We hate to have to put any of this on the backs of our citizens, but these are state laws that are being passed down as a bandaid for us to pay," County Council President Lenny Pfeffer said in an interview with The Star Democrat. "And unfortunately we're having to pass it down onto our citizens because we have no other revenue to pay these bills."
WHAT MAKES FY26 DIFFERENT
Dorchester County's proposed operating budget is $10 million more than the fiscal year 2025 budget passed last May. County Manager Jerry Jones said the increases are in part due to new education requirements from the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's education plan.
Jones said another reason the county has had to increase spending include cost shifts from the state to the county for things like teacher pensions.
In an effort to lessen budget costs, the county sought a waiver for the maintenance of effort for education, which is a law that requires counties to provide as much funding per pupil as was provided in the previous fiscal year. But with a narrow window between the state passing a budget and the waiver's due date, the county had to ask for an extension, which was denied.
"It's disappointing," Jones said. "But at the end of the day, we've got to keep moving forward."
Thompson said Blueprint requirements, like increasing teacher starting salaries, are part of the reason why the school district's budget — which is separate from the county's — has been difficult to balance this year. He said inflation and recurring program costs have also hindered the process.
"No decision is easy," he said. "But I think we're all trying to make the best decision for our students."
Both Jones and Thompson said they don't see the annual budget process getting easier any time soon. Jones said he doesn't see things getting easier unless change is made at the state level.
"I don't see (the budget) easing up in years to come unless some big changes are considered at the general assembly and future sessions," he said. "We'll see how it plays out."
TAX DIFFERENTIALS
One of the proposed changes to balance the county's budget is to remove the tax differential, or lower property tax rate, for Cambridge and Hurlock. This would mean Cambridge and Hurlock residents would have to pay the full property tax rate.
Cambridge Mayor Lajan Cephas said although the county is trying its best to balance the budget, she believes this measure is unfair to Cambridge residents. She said the tax differential essentially returns money to tax payers for "duplicated" services.
Cephas also said Cambridge is growing, which will increase the tax base and bring in more revenue for the county. She said the county should instead look into raising taxes in unincorporated areas that are "a little bit better off."
Jones said he doesn't know what the final budget will look like, but said the council welcomes input.
"We want people to come forward and contribute to this conversation," he said.
Adoption of Dorchester County's budget is slated for May 20. The county's first public budget hearing will be held May 6.
Thompson said the Dorchester County Board of Education has to pass the budget by the end of June, but he hopes the board will pass the budget in May to give staff time to make necessary preparations.

title: Counties Approve Chesapeake College Budget Request, Shift Cost of Tech Center
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Counties approve Chesapeake College budget request, shift cost of tech center

 April 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 526
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — In a joint meeting Thursday, officials across Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties approved a shift in county cost shares for Chesapeake College's new technical building.During the meeting, which was held at the college's main campus in Queen Anne's County, the five counties approved a total $9.02 million budget request made by the college for fiscal year 2026. The school's budget is $1.31 million higher than its fiscal year 2025 budget.
Part of the $9.02 million budget request included a $952,560 request for the design of a new technical building. Chesapeake College Vice President for Administrative Services Karen Smith said the new building will have areas for a variety of programs, including agriculture, electrical, welding and fabrication, construction trades and advanced manufacturing. She said the cost for the design phase could be lower depending on state approval.
Although the five counties approved the request for funding for the design, the decision came with a shift in contributions toward the project.
Dorchester County's share of costs for the design phase will be taken on by Queen Anne's County. This means Queen Anne's County's responsibility for the project will jump from 28.9%, or an estimated $275,290, to 47.8%, or an estimated $455,324.
During the meeting, Dorchester County Council President Lenny Pfeffer and Vice President Mike Detmer outlined their council's concerns regarding paying for the project.
Although other counties hope to use the new technical building for career and technical education at the high school level, Dorchester County has a career and technology center it is still paying off, they said.
Through its budget process, Dorchester County has struggled to eliminate an estimated $6.2 million deficit.
Pfeffer said Dorchester County takes in about $45 million in property and income taxes and will have to give Dorchester County Public Schools $26.6 million for fiscal year 2026.
"So we're trying to run the rest of the county on half of that," he said. "So while in conceptual context, we believe in the project, fiscally our citizens and our staff are saying we don't know how we're going to be able to participate."
At the Chesapeake College meeting, Queen Anne's County Commissioner Jack Wilson Jr. shared his county's decision to cover Dorchester County for the project design costs.
"We all know what happens if we let this money go back to the state," Wilson said. "It's going to go somewhere else in this state, and it's not going to be here. We got this far. And Lenny, listen, I feel for you guys. I know what you're going through. But I think we just need to keep it on the rails at least through the design phase and see what the state's going to help with."
According to documents from the meeting, the state will support 75% of project costs, and the counties will support the remaining 25%.
After the counties voted to approve the amended capital budget, Kent County Commission President Ron Fithian said he understands the position Dorchester County is in, mentioning the Blueprint for Maryland's Future and "unfunded mandates" by the state.
"I think we all understand any one of us could be in your same position very easily," Fithian told the Dorchester County Council members.

title: High School Graduation Rate Reaches Seven-Year High
author: Erin Sjostedt Capital News Service
content:
High school graduation rate reaches seven-year high

 April 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Erin Sjostedt Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 510
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland's high school graduation rate climbed to 88% in 2024, reaching its highest point since 2017, according to the Maryland State Department of Education. The increase of nearly 2 percentage points over the previous year marks a significant recovery following pandemic-era declines.The 2024 data from MSDE shows significant gains among student groups that have historically faced barriers to graduation. Hispanic students saw their graduation rate rise over seven percentage points, while multilingual learners experienced a dramatic increase of over 10%.
"Last year was the largest year-over-year gain of any student group, and I think that's a testimony to targeted, sustained supports that are making the difference," said Theresa Timmons Parrott, an MSDE official focused on multilingual education. "It's a step in the right direction, but it's not the finish line."
Talbot County boasted a graduation rate of 95%, seven points above the state average.
Caroline and Dorchester counties both fell below the state average with rates of 87.5 and 84.4, respectively.
Statewide, female students continued to graduate at higher rates than male students, and white and Asian students graduated at higher rates than their Black and Hispanic peers. Students with disabilities graduated at a rate of 69%, still well below the statewide average. Economically disadvantaged students' graduation rate increased slightly from 2023, graduating at a rate of 82%.
The graduation rate report comes as Maryland begins to implement the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, a landmark education reform law that aims to expand early childhood education, increase college and career readiness and close equity gaps.
Several of the strategies outlined in the Blueprint — including community school models and increased funding for English language learners — align with areas of progress highlighted in the 2024 data.
"If you dig down into the Blueprint, it really lays the foundation for the strategies we're seeing pay off," Parrott said. She attributes a large portion of the progress made to broaden access to early childhood education, target funding for multilingual learners, and mandate college and career readiness pathways by tenth grade.
While the Blueprint for Maryland's Future has driven recent graduation gains, lawmakers enacted adjustments this year due to a projected $3 billion budget shortfall. The Excellence in Maryland Public Schools Act, passed in April 2025, includes a three-year delay in implementing teacher collaborative time and provisions to freeze increases in funding if state revenues significantly decline.
Still, regional disparities persist. While some districts reported graduation rates above 90%, others, particularly in rural counties on the Eastern Shore and in Western Maryland, sit at 80% and below. Education advocates say these gaps underscore the need for continued investment and monitoring.
"This is great news for Maryland," State Superintendent of Schools Carey Wright said in a press release from MSDE. "When we set high standards, deliver strong instruction, and invest in proven supports, our students show that they will exceed expectations."
As the 2025 graduating class enters its final year, educators and policymakers are cautiously optimistic. The latest data suggests that Maryland's post-pandemic recovery is underway, however state education officials say it will require long-term commitment to equity, funding and student support services to maintain.

title: Maryland State of Reading Report: 'time for a comeback after a decade of decline'
author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Maryland State of Reading Report: 'time for a comeback after a decade of decline'

 April 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 469
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BALTIMORE — Maryland's schools are showing signs of progress in reading achievement, but a new report underscores that a deep and lasting crisis remains.The Maryland READS "State of Reading in Maryland 2025: It's Time for a Comeback After a Decade of Decline" report reveals that although incremental gains have been made among fourth-grade students, 67% still cannot read at a proficient level — a figure that mirrors the stagnation seen in eighth grade.
"We are still facing a reading crisis," said Trish Brennan-Gac, executive director of Maryland READS. "Our state is dealing with a budget crisis, including unexpected federal education cuts. Equally concerning, our report shows far too many students are not able to read proficiently."
Brennan-Gac's remarks come as state and local leaders attempt to reverse a long-term decline in literacy.
Maryland READS is a nonprofit working to improve reading instruction in the state. The organization partners with government officials and community leaders to create better policies based on research it conducts.
The report, released amid a backdrop of rising education spending — up 37% to nearly $18,900 per pupil since 2013 — provides a snapshot of Maryland's progress compared with national trends. While the state has nudged ahead of some peers in its national ranking for fourth grade reading scores, nearly two thirds of children continue to struggle.
"Reading is an investment," Brennan-Gac said. "Results will not come to fruition unless everyone works together."
The executive director stressed strong reading skills are critical not only for academic success, but for long-term outcomes like career readiness and reducing chronic absenteeism. "If a child can't read, they feel stupid and don't want to come to school," Brennan-Gac said.
Based on data provided by Maryland READS using the Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program reading scores to assess the health of reading instruction in individual districts, Mid-Shore learners fall below 50% proficiency in English Language Arts with the exception of students in Queen Anne's County.
The 2024 ELA Proficiency rates are:
Caroline: 45.5%.
Dorchester: 33.7%.
Kent: 41.2%.
Queen Anne's: 58.5%
Talbot: 47.3%.
State leaders have taken steps toward a solution by prioritizing teacher training and the development of literacy coaching programs. However, Brennan-Gac criticized recent legislation for "missing the mark" by not providing adequate funding for literacy coaches — a move she argues is essential for "translating research-based practices into everyday classroom instruction."
In addition to bolstering teacher support, the report calls for a comprehensive, community-driven approach to literacy. It highlights a need for creating reading ecosystems that extend beyond the classroom and address factors such as excessive screen time — a growing barrier to the "deep reading" it says underpins comprehension and critical thinking.
"Over the last year, state leaders have led by taking action, but we need a comprehensive, community-driven effort," Brennan-Gac said. "My hope is the legislator will look at his data and start to ask why and, next year, have a different mindset."

title: Shore Legislators Worry About Tax Hikes, Energy, Education in the Wake of General Assembly
author: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Shore legislators worry about tax hikes, energy, education in the wake of General Assembly

 April 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 802
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Maryland General Assembly session officially ended Monday night. Lawmakers fought through a very tough fiscal year budget, which had some significant impacts for Eastern Shore communities, legislators said.Members of the Eastern Shore delegation stressed budget difficulties loom over state lawmakers, who spent much of this year's session tackling an over $3 billion deficit.
"I think the session was not a good session," Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said. "We've just made Maryland a very expensive, more expensive than it was, and it's going to make us less competitive in the region.
"If you believe that economic competitiveness is in fact a priority, I think that it is, and I think that by raising taxes and fees, both at the state level and then forcing the locals to also increase their fees and taxes is a double whammy."
Maryland lawmakers passed a balanced budget Monday, concluding their spring session after months of grappling with the deficit. The final budget included about $2 billion in cuts and about $1.6 billion in tax hikes.
"I think we left frustrated that we had to raise taxes $1.66 billion and there was no regard to wanting to really seriously cut expenses from the state budget," said Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico).
Eastern Shore Delegation members believe after this year's session, the Shore will see lasting effects both fiscally and in several key industries.
Solar
One of the biggest concerns for the Mid-Shore this budget session has been solar energy.
A renewable energy bill aimed at increasing generation of energy within the state by promoting solar energy production was passed by both chambers of the state legislature.
Some Eastern Shore Delegation members feel provisions added to these bills during legislators' deliberations supersede counties' authority regarding solar permitting and regulation.
"It undermines all the work that the counties have already done to try to facilitate where and how to put solar," Mautz said. "It includes a new assessment for planting solar, which is going to raise energy costs."
Hutchinson echoed this sentiment, saying, "It falls on deaf ears that the Democrats from Montgomery and Prince George's county all think that they know how the quality of life is here on the Eastern Shore."
Utility bills
House Bill 1035 and Senate Bill 937, known collectively as the "Next Generation Energy Act," include plans to reduce energy bills and address shortfalls by modernizing the state's energy infrastructure and incentivizing in-state energy production.
Eastern Shore Delegation members believe this effort to get the cost down lacked the immediacy rate payers need to address bill hikes.
"We have not addressed the number one complaint I received when I arrived in January," Hutchinson said, "rate payers calling to say that their electric bills are astronomical. We put legislation forward to try to lower utility bills, and again, it falls on deaf ears."
Education funding
The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's education improvement and funding initiative through 2032, originally outlined an increase in teacher collaborative time, during which teachers are not in classes and can plan, grade or meet with students individually. But with adjustments made in the state's budget to combat the deficit, funding to implement the change has been postponed.
The Blueprint also sustained several other cuts and freezes that impact county finances. Multiple Mid-Shore county school boards have had to make budget cut decisions and potential layoffs in response.
"So let me take Dorchester County, for example," Hutchinson said. "They pushed down the teachers' pensions. They pushed down the Blueprint. They pushed down other mandates that the state usually paid for, but now it's all the county, they have to pay for (it)."
"The school board is short about $5 million. They just eliminated summer school," he said. "They're looking at having to lay off student support personnel. They say we want to create a world-class education. Yet you look at the results of what's happening in Maryland and say that doesn't make sense."
Potential special sessions
While the 2025 session has ended, Mautz doesn't believe discussion is officially over.
As the federal government continues to shift funding priorities, state legislators may need to reconvene to address any impacts this has on the balanced budget, he said.
"Counties are probably going to have to raise revenue through taxes and different things," Mautz said. "The federal government is probably going to continue to reduce spending. Then there's a high likelihood that we're going to have a special session."
"So we would have to go back to Annapolis again to address any changes that that come from federal spending reductions. Just as the federal government is reducing its spending, the state is doing the same thing to the counties, and so where all this ends, it seems to be, taxpayer, taxpayer, taxpayer.
"Everybody should know it's very hard to predict how this is all going to play out, but I don't think the discussion about the budget is is officially over."

title: Rescinded Federal Reimbursements Cause $1.4 Million Impact on TCPS Health Center
author: Konner Metz
content:
Rescinded federal reimbursements cause $1.4 million impact on TCPS health center

 April 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 525
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Construction work on a health center for Talbot County Public Schools staff members has been delayed due to rescinded reimbursements from the U.S. Department of Education.School board and district leaders have touted the Marathon Health center — located on Idlewild Avenue and expected to open later this year — as a significant benefit for staff and their families. But now the project is facing an uncertain future following a notice from the U.S. Department of Education.
In a March 28 letter, Secretary of Education Linda McMahon announced effective the same day that the department would not be honoring extension requests for projects that were granted pandemic-era funds, such as the American Rescue Plan's Elementary and Secondary School Emergency Relief, or ESSER, program.
The move left the state with millions of dollars in funding at risk after it was previously granted an extension by the Biden administration.
State Superintendent Carey Wright said in a press release that the rescinded reimbursements would put more than $400 million of Maryland schools' pandemic-era funding in jeopardy.
About $305 million had already been spent and was awaiting reimbursement from the federal government, state officials said in March. About $112 million had not yet been paid out by the state, requiring school districts to halt ongoing work.
At a Board of Education meeting Wednesday, TCPS Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones said the district isn't finding itself in a huge hole with regards to the reimbursement window unexpectedly closing.
But as far as the staff health center goes, the district is "sort of dead in the water," she said.
TCPS has paid $127,000 to Marathon for its work to date, Jones said. Remaining costs total to around $1.4 million.
"Those are costs that have not yet been spent, but we don't have authority to spend them," Jones said.
Jones told board members the district contacted Marathon, and the company quit work on the project.
The board agreed to revisit the question of funding the health center at a future meeting. Jones said there are multiple funding options at the district's disposal, including tapping into fund balance.
"We should really figure out how to make this work, and we should fund this," Board President Emily Jackson said.
Both Caroline County Public Schools and Dorchester County Public Schools have been fully reimbursed for all of their ESSER-related spending, according to school officials.
"We expended our funding within the timeline that was originally stated," CCPS Superintendent Derek Simmons said. "We considered (extending), but we did not end up needing it."
Simmons and Dorchester County assistant superintendent Jodi Colman each said the March 28 letter did raise concerns for the status of federal funding in general.
In the letter, McMahon wrote the department "will consider an extension to your liquidation period on an individual project-specific basis."
Wednesday, TCPS Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi noted the state has submitted an extension request to the U.S. Department of Education.
Jones said she imagines there will have to be "some allowances for costs that have actually been incurred" made by the federal government.
"There are literally schools that are in the middle of some sort of construction, capital improvement, and you can't leave a gym half built," Jones said. "You can't leave an HVAC system half-installed."

title: Chapel District Elementary Renovations Nearing 30% Completion Mark
author: Konner Metz
content:
Chapel District Elementary renovations nearing 30% completion mark

 April 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 366
 Words

 CORDOVA — As students approach spring break and the final stretch of the school year, construction teams at Chapel District Elementary School are making progress.Kevin Shafer, director of operations for Talbot County Public Schools, told district and county officials this week that the first phase of work should be complete at the Cordova school this June.
About $11.28 million, or around 30% of the total cost, has been spent to date, Shafer said. Construction progress isn't quite at that mark, however.
"We'll be about 30% done at the end of the first phase in June," Shafer said during a meeting Monday. "And the reason for that is a lot of front loading."
The renovation is a multimillion-dollar effort that includes around $27 million in county funding as well as state funds from Maryland's Interagency Commission on School Construction. Construction is being led by the Whiting-Turner Contracting Company.
The project is set to fully renovate the existing building and add around 16,000 square feet. There will be additional learning space for the school, as well as a Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers site located in the building.
The school's media center is moving to the center of the building, and the playground is also under renovation.
Construction, which began in summer 2024, is expected to take a couple years. The school was built in 1952 and last renovated in 1994.
Shafer noted the construction project started about 34 days late due to unforeseen septic system issues and permitting delays.
He credited Bill Stagg, the project manager appointed by the Talbot County Council, for preventing what could've been a significant delay.
"He was instrumental in making sure that this project even got started on time," Shafer said. "If that would've hit about 40 days, it would've been pushed back a year."
School operations have continued in the existing building this year during the first phase of work. Phase two of renovations will begin this summer once school ends, Shafer said.
"That is why you will see a front loading of expenses, making sure the supplies and equipment are here in place ready to hit the ground running," he said.
"That is a make-or-break time for this project. We have to be ready by the time kids come back in August."

title: Maryland Wrestles With Blow to the State Schools Budget
author: Sasha Allen Capital News Service
content:
Maryland wrestles with blow to the state schools budget

 April 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service | Section: Local News 
 
 733
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Maryland lawmakers are scrambling to figure out their education budget this spring after learning that $418 million they'd been expecting for public schools from the federal government may not come through.Senate President Bill Ferguson says the state had already spent approximately $300 million of the money and allocated the rest to school districts around the state when they learned that President Donald Trump's education department may not reimburse them as previously planned. The money was supposed to come from a special pandemic-era fund.
The funds are being spent by school districts to cover reading materials, after-school programming, and repairs for heating and air conditioning units, among other things.
Mid-Shore school districts were still unsure of the exact impacts to their budgets when asked for comment Thursday.
"At this time, we are waiting for details from MSDE (Maryland State Department of Education) regarding the final calculations and impact on funding for all Maryland school districts," Talbot County Public Schools said in a statement to the press. District officials said they expected to have more information by Monday, the final day of this year's state legislative session.
Senate Democrats had already proposed cuts to the state's education plan, known as the Blueprint for Maryland's Future. Now Republicans say it's even more important to make significant trims.
"We don't have an extra $300 million to spare, and it is foolish to double down on Blueprint spending when there are obvious accountability issues coupled with the concerns of our local school districts who are struggling to meet both the financial and the policy mandates," said Sen. Mary Beth Carozza (R-Somerset, Wicomico, Worcester).
Word of the $418 million gap came late last week in a letter from U.S. Secretary of Education Linda McMahon, informing states that the fund's liquidation period would be coming to an end that day. Extensions of the pandemic-era fund, she said in the letter, were "well past the period of performance" and were "not justified."
The letter specified that there may be exceptions on an individual basis, and Office of the Attorney General Spokesperson Jennifer Donelan said in a statement they are "reviewing the matter and weighing our options."
"Protecting the state's schools and Maryland students is a top priority," read the statement.
But on Monday, Carozza introduced an amendment to the Excellence in Maryland Public Schools Act, a bill aiming to reduce Blueprint funding, to pause implementation of the plan for the next two years.
"It's never been more clear that we need a pause in the Blueprint when it comes to affordability and implementation," Carozza said.
To balance the state's budget and bridge the structural deficit, the Excellence in Maryland Public Schools Act would make numerous cuts to the state's plan for hiking the investment in public education. While many Democrats still believe the Blueprint is necessary for the future of Maryland public schools, Republicans like Carozza are pushing for further cuts.
"There's no question that we've increased spending dramatically in education for the last 25 years, and our SAT scores are worse, our reading scores are worse, math is worse," said Sen. Justin Ready (R- Carroll, Frederick) on the Senate floor Tuesday. "While we're not suggesting you want to cut education from where you are now, we are saying we should slow down how fast we're going and not raise taxes on working Marylanders for a little while longer."
Ready and numerous other Senate Republicans fought against tax increases in the budget bill, and many advocated instead to cut education even more.
But cuts have already been proposed. Senate amendments to the Excellence in Maryland Public Schools Act include pausing for four years the requirement for "collaborative time," or the allocated period each day when teachers get for planning. The act would also maintain some reduction in funding for the Consortium on Coordinated Community Supports, a program providing mental health support in schools under the Blueprint.
Some Senate Democrats, however, are in staunch disagreement with Republicans regarding the bill. Sen. Jim Rosapepe (D-Prince George's, Anne Arundel) was the first to speak about the budget on the Senate floor Tuesday morning.
"We're not rolling over for the attacks on Maryland," Rosapepe said. "We're protecting health care, we're protecting education, we're protecting public safety, we're protecting transportation … We're making the tax system more fair."
Like Rosapepe, many senators mentioned the necessity of education funding. State Democrats pushed to protect funding for low-income students and English Language learners.
The Star Democrat Reporter Konner Metz contributed to this article.
