title: Talbot County Wrestles with Schools Funding Request, Long-Term Blueprint Concerns
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County wrestles with schools funding request, long-term Blueprint concerns

 April 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 660
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council opted Tuesday not to include an additional $5.7 million in funding for Talbot County Public Schools in the county's draft fiscal year 2026 budget.TCPS requested the additional funds last month to help with teacher salary mandates from the state, new positions and health insurance hikes, among other factors.
The county's budget will already include around $55 million in required education funding as mandated by The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's overarching education improvement framework.
Council member Keasha Haythe argued Tuesday to keep the $5.7 million out of the budget for the time being. Any additional funding for education included would potentially lead to a property tax increase for residents by way of an education supplement.
"Putting an additional property tax supplement on them this year specifically is a challenge," Haythe said. " ... I just believe we have to be very conservative and think about the vulnerable population."
Vice President Pete Lesher was the council's lone member in favor of including additional educational funding in the county's initial budget proposal. Lesher said it's "not prudent" to push off the education funding to next year.
"It would make next year a lot more painful," Lesher said. " … I'd rather do steady, incremental increases than take a year off and be hit with a much larger percentage increase a year down the road."
Lesher warned that holding off on fulfilling some of the district's requests could endanger recent county investments for new positions such as math coaches and social workers, since the district is under state pressure to meet $60,000 teacher salary minimums.
TCPS Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said Tuesday the district won't be able to continue funding all its priorities if the county only provides the minimum required funding.
"We will have to prioritize and we will have to make some tough decisions," Pepukayi said.
Council members and county officials said Tuesday the option to fulfill some or all of the $5.7 million ask remains available in the coming weeks as the budget is amended. A budget proposal will officially be introduced April 15.
LONG-TERM UNCERTAINTY
While the county held off on promising additional education funding Tuesday, council members and school leaders found common ground during a joint meeting Monday, fielding concerns over the long-term sustainability of the state's Blueprint initiative.
Talbot County Public Schools Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones touched on projections from the Department of Legislative Services released in February, which forecast significant increases for how much money counties are expected to provide school districts.
The report shows Talbot County is expected to contribute $90 million to schools in fiscal year 2034, up $35 million from what the council is planning to obligate for FY2026.
"That's a really sobering increase, but it's baked into the law," Jones said. "I don't know what the council's view is on how you're going to be able to meet this contribution."
Jones said the DLS calculations, in part, are derived from The Blueprint's goals to improve teacher compensation and provide needed student support.
Haythe said it's going to take time for the county to assess whether meeting those requirements is possible.
"We would have to come together as a council and really think through, get the details, work with (Finance Director Martha Sparks) to determine how we can get there, and if we can get there," she said.
Board President Emily Jackson said the state doesn't always offer financial solutions when it asks counties to fork over funding for The Blueprint. She said the state advising districts to ask counties to fill funding gaps isn't effective.
"That's not good government, that's not good planning, that's not good oversight," Jackson said. "But I think that the people in this room can do all those things, good planning, good government, good foresight, good working together."
As for the looming $90 million mark, officials agreed it's going to take joint strategic planning and a lot of time to flesh out the path forward.
"'Can we get there?' is important to determine first before we figure out how," Jackson said.

title: Committee Made for Potential New Lockerman Middle School
author: Ahmad Garnett
content:
Committee made for potential new Lockerman Middle School

 April 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 513

 EASTON — A committee called the Education Specifications Committee has come together to begin the discussion of renovating or replacing Lockerman Middle School."So this is the first step of the project process we go through for renovation," Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons said. "This committee... is an opportunity for our community, this group of stakeholders and working with our outside consultant to talk about what they may feel is needed in a modern 2025, 2026 middle school."
In the summer of 2024, the Caroline County Board of Education approved Lockerman Middle School as the next large construction project for the county. Consultant David Lever with Educational Facilities Planning LLC was contracted with to begin the process.
According to Simmons, the committee will help give the consultant a picture of what a middle school facility should look like to educate kids in the modern era and moving forward.
The architect will use the Education Specification Committee's documents to help design the school, whether renovating the current structure or building a new school altogether.
County Administrator and Committee Member Katheleen Freeman says the committee will go through multiple different scenarios and specifications to make sure the middle school is correctly designed.
"We're going to look at the square footage that's needed for the facilities that would be needed in the school," Freeman said. "Also the traffic flow. Can can students walk to the school? If they have to drive, what's the traffic impact going to be? Is it going to be easy for parents to drop off and pick up, and the buses and all of that kind of thing?"
The committee consists of multiple school officials from schools in Caroline County and officials from the state, as well as community members.
"We have teachers from Lockerman, we have members of the Lockerman Association," Simmons said. "We have central office folks who are involved with curriculum as well as building and facilities. We have parents at our elementary schools, as well as administration from Lockerman. We have some state representation that's been invited because the state will be a major funder."
At the Nov. 26, 2024, Caroline County Commissioners meeting, Bill Mengel, director of operations at Caroline County Public Schools, said the state is projected to be receive $76 million in requested funding from the state.
Mengel said the $76 million is around 89% of the total $86 million estimated for years one and two of the project. The county would be responsible for the remaining 11% of the funding.
Simmons said the forming of the committee is a first step in what will be a long process to bring the middle school together.
"It is a marathon in terms of pulling this together," Simmons said. "As we work through the process, we want to really keep an eye on respecting the past and preparing for the future for the needs for Lockerman.
"We want to make sure that it's done right, something the community can be proud of. It is also a responsible use of the funding that will be used to build it. We are really looking forward to the process."

title: Amid Budget Woes, Dorchester Cancels Summer School, Appeals to Students to 'Get the Work Done'
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Amid budget woes, Dorchester cancels summer school, appeals to students to 'get the work done'

 March 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 534
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County Public Schools will not offer summer school this year, citing budget restraints. But county education officials say there is still time to improve grades for students who are at risk of having to repeat a grade."There is still time to pull it out," Dorchester County Board of Education President Sheri Hubbard said during a board meeting March 27. "... Buckle down and work as hard as you can to get the grades to where they need to be so that you don't have to worry about there not being summer school."
On March 20, the district announced it would not be able to offer elementary and middle school summer sessions nor the high school credit recovery summer program in 2025 due to the district's need to adjust its programming.
The move does not affect the Extended School Year program for students receiving special education services nor the Summer Career Enrichment Program being offered in Talbot County.
"As we work to balance our budget for the upcoming fiscal year, we are having to realign our resources and adjust various programs," the announcement addressed to families said.
Currently, the district is facing a multi-million dollar deficit for fiscal year 2026.
Since January, the district has reduced this deficit from $10.19 million to $5.59 million. During a Board of Education budget work session March 20, Superintendent Jymil Thompson said the district would next be looking into reducing its staff by 12 to 24 positions to save money. According the district, it currently has 859 total positions.
WHAT THIS MEANS FOR STUDENTSThe lack of summer school will mean if a student fails a course this school year, that student will not be able to make up the course this summer. The district wants parents to plan accordingly.
"If your student is failing a course, please reach out to the school to determine what can be done to help your child pass the course prior to the end of the school year so he/she does not risk being retained in the same grade level next year," the announcement said.
During the Board of Education meeting March 27, Thompson said his suggestion to students is to take advantage of the time remaining in the school year "to get the work done."
Hubbard said the board wishes the district could offer summer school this year.
"Of course we like to be able to offer summer school," she said. "But in today's budget climate, it is not something that is foreseeable at this moment, so I do apologize."
Hubbard, who used to be a teacher, said teachers are generally willing to work with students who ask them if there is something they can do to bring up their grade.
"Whenever there was a student who came to me with sincerity and said, 'Is there something I can do? Can I please make up some work?' or whatever, we always came to some sort of way that that student was able to bring up their grades if they really wanted to," she said. "It is possible."
Hubbard said the district doesn't want to have to hold students back.
"And we certainly don't want to keep anybody from graduating," she said. "So just please, all of you work together and get it done."

title: Plan to Require School Uniforms Doesn't Gain Traction with Talbot Board of Ed
author: Konner Metz
content:
Plan to require school uniforms doesn't gain traction with Talbot Board of Ed

 March 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 453
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A proposal to institute school uniforms in Talbot County failed to advance at last week's Board of Education meeting.Board member Ann O'Connor, who first raised the uniform topic at a meeting last month, made a motion to institute school uniforms. However, that motion did not carry, as none of the other six board members seconded.
Before the failed motion, Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi shared results of a community survey with the board. Nearly 1,900 responses were recorded — 74% of those coming from parents, 15% from staff and 8% from students.
Overall, around 49% opposed school uniforms, with 45% in favor and the remaining voting no opinion. Responses varied based on the grade level:
Elementary school: 49% in favor, 41% opposed.Middle school: 49% in favor, 42% opposed.High school: 44% in favor, 48% opposed.
O'Connor said after one year of implementation, there could be a school shop with "hand-me-down" uniforms. She said purchasing uniforms wouldn't be "an exorbitant expense."
Vice President Amy Dodson disagreed.
"If you have a family that is only making minimum wage, it's a significant expense," Dodson said. "And you have a significant portion of our student population that is on free and reduced meals."
Board member Dyshekia Strawberry said she doesn't see the need to introduce uniforms since the survey didn't show "an overwhelming response either way." President Emily Jackson concurred.
"I don't see an overwhelming need to make a major change in policy and procedure," Jackson said. "Combined with the fact that, again, we are in a challenging budget year, and this would be an expensive undertaking should we go forward with it.
"Those two factors combined leave me not compelled to do anything in this regard."
O'Connor said she was surprised by the high response rate. She told The Star Democrat she'd like the district to gather information on the impacts of uniforms at other schools and potentially revisit the topic next school year.
In an interview Friday, Pepukayi said she was surprised by both the high survey response rate and "the closeness of the percentages that came out with elementary and middle" school questions.
The superintendent said her team discussed the cost factors around having parents pay for uniforms, though they did not get into what specifics costs may be if the district assumed uniform payments.
Pepukayi said potentially helping families pay for school uniforms would bring up questions of which families the district helps and how that's determined.
"That's another discussion because then where do you draw the line?" she said.
Pepukayi said she doesn't expect the topic of uniforms to come up again anytime soon.
"It didn't get the second (to) the motion, so it kind of died right there on the spot. But that's not to say it couldn't come up again," she said.

title: DCPS Looks to Staff Reductions to Balance Budget
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
DCPS looks to staff reductions to balance budget

 March 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 365
 Words

 CAMBRIDGE — Facing a $5.59 million deficit for fiscal year 2026, Dorchester County Public Schools is considering staff reductions."We're not just making decisions based on how we feel," DCPS Superintendent Jymil Thompson said during a Dorchester County Board of Education budget work session Thursday. "We're looking at every ounce of data. We're having budget meetings on a weekly basis. We're talking to our team consistently with the board. We're trying to make the best decision possible for Dorchester County Public Schools, and it's not easy."
While giving a budget update at the meeting, Thompson said the district will be looking into reducing its staff by 12 to 24 positions. He said those layoffs could save the district between $900,000 and $1.8 million.
"There are no definitive positions that we have identified as of yet," he said. "But we will be moving forward to doing that at our next meeting."
Thompson said the district has been in conversation with district principals, Dorchester Educators, Dorchester Educators Education Support Professionals and the Dorchester Administrators and Supervisors Association to discuss where those staff reductions could be made.
Thompson said the district wants to retain as many staff as possible and minimize the impact on teaching and learning.
"If we want to get from 23 to 15, we can't afford to lose teachers," he said about the district's state rating. "We have to make sure that we keep our class sizes small and keep teachers at all costs. And we're trying to do what's best for everyone."
Thompson said the district is reviewing attrition rate trends. He said he believes the number of teachers who leave the district for retirement and other reasons at the end of the school year will help.
"And we may not have to reduce as many staff," he said. "But we will have to reduce some staff."
Along with looking into staff reductions, Thompson said the district will be opening up negotiations with its staff representatives, which include Dorchester Educators, Dorchester Educators Education Support Professionals and the Dorchester Administrators and Supervisors Association.
"And the reason is because we cannot currently honor the step increases and the (cost of living adjustment)," he said.
Thompson said the district could potentially save $3.5 million through these negotiations.

title: Schools Struggle to Bridge Learning Gaps, Adapt to a New Normal
author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Schools struggle to bridge learning gaps, adapt to a new normal

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 726
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Five years after COVID-19 upended classrooms, Mid-Shore school districts are still working to close learning gaps, combat chronic absenteeism and adapt to lasting changes in education. While academic performance is improving across Maryland, with more schools earning top ratings, districts continue to wrestle with pandemic-era challenges — particularly in student engagement, virtual learning access and social-emotional development."We continue to see some gaps in students' learning," said Queen Anne's County Public Schools Superintendent Patricia Saelens, emphasizing the district's focus on tutoring, academic intervention and social-emotional strategies. Yet chronic absenteeism remains high, with some counties reporting rates above 25%, and virtual learning remains a logistical hurdle due to disparities in technology access.
Despite the challenges, local educators say students have proven resilient, with many now excelling in academics and careers. The post-pandemic education system may look different, but its impact on today's students will be felt for years to come.
LEARNING GAPSMaryland's most recent education report indicated steady improvements in school performance, with 91 schools achieving five-star ratings in the 2023-24 school year, up from 85 the previous year. About 41% of schools statewide received a four- or five-star rating, marking a gradual increase. However, despite these gains, schools statewide still fell short of meeting annual targets in every category.
To address learning gaps, Queen Anne's County Public Schools have expanded tutoring services where funding is available. Additional intervention programs in reading and math aim to support struggling students. Saelens stressed the need for continued focus on social-emotional learning, ensuring that students feel connected and ready to learn.
CHRONIC ABSENTEEISMOne of the most persistent challenges post-COVID is chronic absenteeism, according to state Department of Education data. While attendance rates have improved since the height of the pandemic, absenteeism remains above 25% across the Mid-Shore:
Queen Anne's County: 22.9%Kent County: 26%Caroline County: 28%Talbot County: 28.5%Dorchester County: 38.3%
Matt Evans, supervisor of Student Services in Queen Anne's County said their district was already experiencing a slight increase in chronic absenteeism prior to the pandemic; however, that rate significantly increased during COVID-19 school closures and peaked during the 2021-2022 school year. Since then, the chronic absenteeism rate is on a steady decline but not back to the pre-pandemic rates, Evans said.
Home instruction numbers also were increasing prior to the pandemic, with the sharpest increase and peak during the 2020-2021 school year. After 2020-2021, the home instruction numbers significantly decreased and ultimately plateaued, although they are not back to the pre-pandemic numbers, he noted.
Statewide, officials are working to reengage students but lingering effects of pandemic-related disruptions continue to impact attendance.
VIRTUAL LEARNINGVirtual learning, once an emergency measure, remains a complex issue. While some districts have successfully integrated online instruction for inclement weather closures, Queen Anne's County faces challenges in fully adopting virtual learning due to technology and connectivity limitations.
"In the state of Maryland, virtual learning days must adhere to all the guidelines of MSDE," Saelens said. "Not all QACPS students have a one-to-one device, and unfortunately, we still have pockets throughout the district where internet connectivity is challenging."
Additionally, some teachers struggle with reliable internet access, making a full-scale virtual learning model unfeasible.
ADOPTION AND INNOVATIONDespite the setbacks, educators see lasting benefits from the changes forced by the pandemic. Kent County Public Schools Superintendent Mary Boswell-McComas noted that five years is a significant portion of a student's educational journey.
"A fifth grader in 2020 is now well into their high school years. Elementary school students today don't remember the pandemic and wearing masks," she said.
While routines have returned to pre-COVID norms, teachers and students have become more proficient with technology. Virtual instruction, once foreign, is now a tool used strategically during weather-related closures.
Federal funding post-pandemic helped schools innovate, including the implementation of student support coaches in Kent County classrooms. These coaches allow teachers to work with students in smaller groups, providing targeted academic support and aiding in social-emotional development.
A NEW CHAPTERAs districts continue to navigate post-COVID realities, educators emphasize resilience and adaptation. Students who graduated during the pandemic are now succeeding at competitive universities and in the workforce, proving that the disruptions, while significant, did not define their futures.
"The pandemic was a challenging and troubling time for all of us: in schools, in our communities and around the world," Kent County's Boswell-McComas said. "As with so many challenges, we have come out of it stronger. We learned more about ourselves and have incorporated innovative techniques that are still in use today."

title: From Crisis to Change: COVID-19’s Enduring Mark on the Eastern Shore
author: Staff Report
content:
From crisis to change: COVID-19’s enduring mark on the Eastern Shore

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 642
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Five years after the COVID-19 pandemic reached the Eastern Shore, its impact lingers in ways both visible and unseen. The empty streets, masked faces, and social distancing markers have faded, but the profound shifts in health care, worship, business and daily life remain.Emma Zonetti never expected the pandemic to reach her tight-knit community.
"I remember being in church, actually. My husband's mom told me that this was happening," said Zonetti, now a senior clinical nurse with University of Maryland Shore Regional Health. "And I went, 'Oh, it's nothing to worry about. It's just another virus.' And then quickly did we learn that it was way more than that."
Zonetti, who was a clinical coordinator in the telemetry unit at the Shore Medical Center at Easton during the height of the crisis, recalled the stark reality that unfolded as cases surged.
"It certainly impacted us far larger than I could ever anticipate," she said.
Late in January 2020, hospitals began screening for the virus as patients arrived in emergency rooms.
By March, State Superintendent of Schools Dr. Karen Salmon ordered a closure of schools — a temporary order that extended well into 2021, much longer than anyone anticipated.
Beaches and boardwalks closed. And by April, the number of positive cases surged and mask orders ensued.
COMMUNITY BLINDSIDEDThe first confirmed case of COVID-19 on the Eastern Shore was reported in Talbot County on March 16, 2020. Since then, there have been 8,056 confirmed cases in the county and more than 40,000 across the Mid-Shore. The virus claimed the lives of 592 Mid-Shore residents.
For religious communities, the impact was swift and disruptive. Pastor Doug Morley of Greater Impact Church in Greensboro said the closure of worship spaces came at a critical time for his newly merged congregation.
"Building on the momentum of coming together for greater Kingdom impact in 2019 and gearing up for what would potentially be one of our highest attended worship experiences on Easter Sunday (April 12, 2020), we were definitely blindsided by the mandated closure of all religious gatherings," Morley said.
Church leaders scrambled to adapt, turning to Facebook Live for virtual worship and launching a "drive-in" service using a tractor-trailer bed as a stage and an FM transmitter to broadcast services to parked cars.
"It forced us to think outside the four walls of the church," Morley said. "That shift in approach has remained with us."
Even after indoor services resumed, Morley noted, worship attendance has not yet returned to pre-pandemic levels. While some members embraced online services, others simply fell out of the habit.
LASTING LEGACYWhen Maryland lifted its COVID-19 state of emergency on July 1, 2021, many expected a swift return to normalcy. In some ways, that happened — travel resumed, restaurants filled and hugs replaced distanced greetings. But the pandemic left lasting imprints on the Eastern Shore.
Telehealth became commonplace. Remote work grew. Businesses closed, moved or downsized. Schools and universities permanently integrated virtual options. Many delayed retirement. Awareness of mental health surged as loneliness and isolation persisted.
The pandemic reshaped our priorities, forcing people to rethink work, education and social connection. Some changes were temporary, but others — like digital access and hybrid work models — are likely here to stay.
While it has taken a few years to get back to some semblance of normalcy, the impact of COVID-19 upon regular worship attendance is still evident.
"We have not returned to pre-pandemic numbers, and we still have individuals and families who choose to worship online rather than in-person," Morely said. "A few who once attended regularly have gotten out of the habit and find it difficult to return on a consistent basis."
As the Eastern Shore reflects on the past five years, the region has found resilience in adversity. Communities innovated, businesses adapted and individuals discovered new ways to connect. The pandemic may have left its mark, but so, too, did the spirit of perseverance that defines the Shore.

title: Dorchester County Blueprint Costs Higher Than 2022 Projections
author: Maggie Trovato

Dorchester County Blueprint costs higher than 2022 projections

 March 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County's projected education expenses are higher than the county expected three years ago.During a Dorchester County Council meeting March 18, Council President Lenny Pfeffer said its projected education expenses have increased since the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, which is the state's education plan, was adopted by the Blueprint's Accountability and Implementation Board in 2022.
Although Dorchester County Public Schools has its own budget, the county is responsible for giving a portion of its revenues to the district every year based on a calculation determined by the state.
At the meeting, Pfeffer said the county expects it will owe the district $26.3 million for education expenses in fiscal year 2026. Projections from 2022 estimated the county would owe $23.9 million for fiscal year 2026 education expenses, according to projections from the Maryland Department of Legislative Services.
That is $2.4 million less than what is currently projected.
Pfeffer said that in 2022, the county expected to owe the district $26.8 million in fiscal year 2030.
"So we're almost at fiscal year '30," he said about how much the county is paying for education with the Blueprint in place.
Pfeffer said that in fiscal year 2034, the county expects it will have to spend $36.3 million on education. He said that in 2022, the county expected it would be paying $29.4 million in fiscal year 2034.
"They need more money than we can give them," Pfeffer said about the school district, adding that the county's issue is not with the district, but with the state's plan. "We just cannot pay our bills that are unfundedly mandated on this county."

title: Caroline County Discuss Chesapeake College at First FY26 Budget Workshop
author: Ahmad Garnett
content:
Caroline County discuss Chesapeake College at first FY26 budget workshop

 March 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 402
 Words 

 Read News Document

 At Tuesday's Caroline County Commissioners meeting, the commissioners and county officials tackled a big ticket item in its first budget workshop.The capital budget contains a request for funds for Chesapeake College.
Chesapeake College plans to rebuild Queen Anne's Tech building in the future and needs funding from all five counties on the Mid-Shore. While this is a state- funded project the counties in the community college district are expected to contribute as well.
Contacted after the meeting, Chesapeake College President Clifford Coppersmith offered some information about the proposed building.
"The building project we have proposed is to replace an existing facility that is very dated," Coppersmith said. "The existing Queen Anne's Tech Building was built in 1976 and is the last building on campus that has not been renovated."
Three of the five counties must be on board to approve this new proposed building.
The proposed new building will take three years to build. If funded by the state, Caroline County's total share adds up to $2.7 million over three years in the capital funding budget.
Coppersmith believes that the state will leave the funding for the replacement and renovations college in the state budget.
"It's huge," Coppersmith said about the state potential funding for the proposed building. "The state ultimately bears 75% of the cost of the construction with our local counties sharing the 25% share."
For Caroline County, the share for the first year will be $180,000, but in fiscal year 2027-28, the larger chunk of the $2.7 million will be in the capital budget. The county is worried about the capital funds for the next two years.
"I'm just concerned we may not have any money for capital next year," County Commission President Travis Breeding said. "I personally think it's a good conservative play to build it into this year's budget, fund it, if we are going to be on the hook for it let's fund it so we don't have to worry about funding any of it next year. Either we deal with it now, or we worry about it next year."
The commissioners decided to table the discussion until the end of the budget workshop to make a final decision on how the capital funds for Chesapeake College will be allocated.
"I would say yes we leave it here and when we get to the final process on this years budget we go back and take a look at it," County Commission Vice President Larry Porter said.

title: Community School Leaders in Talbot County Aim to Make a Difference
author: Konner Metz
content:
Community school leaders in Talbot County aim to make a difference

 March 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 794
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In her third year as community school manager at Easton Elementary, Katie Fox's job is all about removing barriers for students in need and becoming a community resource."The premise of a community school is for you to be the community hub," Fox said of her role. "So you serve as a resource for everyone."
It's a relatively new position in Talbot County Public Schools and across the state. In 2019, community schools were introduced as part of The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's initiative to fund and improve education.
More than 600 Maryland schools are community schools. Two are in Talbot County: Easton Elementary and Easton Middle. Those schools receive extra funds to create services for students and families in poverty.
As future funding remains up in the air this legislative session, Talbot County's two community schools are moving forward at two different stages of the process.
Last school year, Easton Elementary came up with an implementation plan and goals. Those goals are to increase availability of healthy foods, provide mental health resources, raise enrichment by 15%, and add 100 students to the school's Choptank Community Health partnership, Fox said.
Fox, a longtime teacher before taking on her current role, said those needs become apparent.
"You could probably spot test any single classroom teacher. All of those things spike up," Fox said. "Food insecurity, needing materials, clothing. All of that is prevalent in all of the spaces, especially post-pandemic."
Easton Elementary is in its third year as a community school. Starting off, the school received state funding to hire Fox's position and a health care practitioner. In Year 3, it received "per-pupil" funding to begin providing specific services and resources.
Fox said the per-pupil funding has supported before- and after-school programs and Teddy Bear Fresh Produce boxes for family events, among other programs.
Easton Middle, meanwhile, is in its first year. Community school facilitator Shelby Parks is spearheading a needs assessment that includes staff, family, student and community surveys.
At the middle school, Parks says mental health, food insecurity and transportation are focus areas.
"We can't offer too many after-school programs because we just don't have the transportation, and students are struggling," Parks said.
Fox noted that transportation to grocery stores for neighborhoods around Easton Elementary and Easton Middle is a challenge.
"We don't have a current grocery store that's within walking distance, so that's just something to consider," Fox said. "If the family doesn't have their own personal transportation, it makes it more difficult to access any kind of healthy food outside of a few restaurants that are there."
FUNDING UNCERTAINTY
Attempting to close a nearly $3 billion state deficit, Gov. Wes Moore proposed a budget in January with significant cuts and freezes to education funding, including for community schools. Many education advocates pushed back.
His budget proposed freezing community school funding at next year's levels, potentially impacting the money provided to schools such as Easton Elementary in future years.
But last week, the House of Delegates amended some of Moore's education cuts by passing a refined Blueprint education bill. The House struck through his proposed pause to community school funding and sent the bill to the Senate chamber.
Kristen Tilghman, Blueprint implementation coordinator for Talbot County Public Schools, said the district is watching closely to see if community school funding is paused or affected in any way.
The district is "going to move forward because our community clearly has a need," Tilghman added. Easton High, White Marsh Elementary and Tilghman Elementary are the district's schools next in line to become community schools. Job postings for community school program leaders are active for those three schools.
Tilghman said the state funding "sets the stage" for schools to create partnerships and assist families all over Talbot County.
"(It's) vital to the whole community, not just that particular school's community," she said.
'HELPING ALL'
Talbot school leaders emphasized that theme of not just helping the designated community schools but bettering the entire district.
For instance, Fox is involved in monthly food distributions for families across the district, not just Easton Elementary.
"Because we're a small county, I can do this heavy lift at Easton Elementary, but Easton Middle and High and Chapel (District Elementary) and Tilghman (Elementary) can benefit from some of the things that are happening," she said.
As Parks prepares to move EMS into the implementation phase next year, she's watching how Fox makes an impact at the elementary school.
"I'm excited that if Easton High comes on board, we can see trends between Easton Elementary, Easton Middle and Easton High, how it all flows, how we all work together," Parks said.
The concept of working together applies not just for every school in Talbot County, but for every student in each school. Fox said all students benefit from the community school resources and programs.
"You create something for one, it always ends up helping all," Fox said.

title: Dorchester County Council, Board of Education Discuss Budget Concerns
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Dorchester County Council, Board of Education discuss budget concerns

 March 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 566
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Members of the Dorchester County Council and Dorchester County Board of Education highlighted the dangers of making sweeping cuts to education expenses during a County Council meeting March 18."You can't do big sweeping things that a business would do," County Council Vice President Mike Detmer said about education during the meeting.
Both the county and Dorchester County Public Schools face budget deficits for fiscal year 2026. Since January, the school district has reduced its estimated budget deficit, which is separate from the county's budget, from $10.19 million to $5.59 million. It is still looking for ways to further reduce the deficit.
Both the district and county — which gives a portion of its revenues to the district every year — have said state mandates regarding the Blueprint for Maryland's Future are affecting their budgets.
During the council meeting, DCPS Superintendent Jymil Thompson and Board of Education member and Finance Chair Chris Wheedleton presented on the district's draft budget for fiscal year 2026, reiterating what was shared during a Board of Education budget work session in late February. Thompson said the district will be presenting more changes to the budget at another Board of Education budget work session on March 20.
After the presentation, Detmer said $5 million of the district's deficit equates to a 15% increase in property tax rates.
"My question is how much do athletic programs cost?" he asked. "How much do school plays cost? How much does operating two high schools instead of one high school in the county, how much does that cost?"
Board of Education Vice President Talibah Chikwendu, who was sitting in the audience at the meeting, stood up to answer Detmer's question. She said sending all the county's high schoolers to one high school would increase transportation costs, increase class sizes and hurt student achievement.
Chikwendu said the Blueprint, which is a state plan that aims to improve student outcomes and the quality of education, does not just increase starting teacher salaries, but it changes what makes a student eligible to graduate.
She said getting rid of extracurriculars like athletics, which are outlets for students, will increase the district's dropout rate.
"If we do not have graduates, we do not have good employees, we do not have homeowners, we do not have property taxes to spend," she said. "Everything is connected largely to how well we educate our students."
Chikwendu said removing extracurriculars would affect school culture and climate.
"That's also part of what the state evaluates," she said. "And if those things slide, so do then our ratings and so do then what the state provides to us."
Detmer said he resents having to ask those questions.
"I resent the fact that a one-size-fits-not-us solution has been passed down," he said about the Blueprint. "I would much rather be waiting for recommendations developed here for how to best serve our students."
Detmer said he would like to have the county look into asking for a special dispensation so the district can follow a plan that is tailored to it.
"We've just heard that the big, nuclear solutions, for many reasons, aren't tenable," he said. "We can't just close multiple schools."
Detmer said the county needs to follow a plan for education improvement that is slower and more purposeful.
"We don't have the property tax base," he said.
Council President Lenny Pfeffer said the council will be directing county staff to look at options to solve the deficit, including looking into getting a dispensation.

title: Talbot County Provides First Look at Draft Budget for FY26
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County provides first look at draft budget for FY26

 March 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 474
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County Manager Clay Stamp said one aspect was clear when drafting the county's fiscal year 2026 budget: it needed to remain flat.Speaking with the Talbot County Council at a workshop Tuesday, county employees presented a balanced draft budget coming in at $163.3 million. It comes in slightly below last year's budget of $163.8 million.
The county's total budget has ballooned in recent years. In fiscal year 2023, it was $112 million, and one year later, it rose to $128 million. It took a sharper jump to the $163 million mark last year.
Stamp said the increases were for good cause. "You've made incredible and important investments in public safety and education," he told council members.
But Stamp emphasized that given federal uncertainties, state cost shifts and recurring county costs, it is important to curb that recent upward trend.
"That was a mandate as we put this budget together," Stamp said of the belt-tightening.
Stamp said the draft fiscal year 2026 budget currently proposes no additional job positions. The county's capital improvement plan is also trimmed back, he said. He hopes the county can focus on finishing projects already underway, such as Chapel District Elementary School renovations and a new EMS station in Cordova.
When drafting the budget, Stamp and Finance Director Martha Sparks said they initially came in $6 million over their target. To remedy that, they're proposing delayed payments for postemployment benefits and correctional officers' retirements, respectively — the latter of which is to be expected to be included in fiscal year 2027.
Sparks mentioned that tax hikes proposed at the state level for wealthy individuals may have an impact on Talbot County revenues. Sparks said last time a similar tax increase was levied in 2009, it made a significant dent, partly due to the recession.
"We had an exodus of the wealthy in our county as a result of that," Sparks said. "And it took us approximately 10 years to recover."
Sparks added, however, that the county looks OK for fiscal year 2026 in terms of those tax proposals. She said she's "not sure what that will look like for us moving forward."
As for policy and funding shifts at the federal level, Stamp said "it's reasonable" to expect impacts will trickle down to Talbot County.
"We are cognizant of that," Stamp said. "Radars are up, antennas are up. We're watching closely."
The draft budget shows $55 million in funding for the Talbot Board of Education. Stamp said the county must contribute that mark since it's required by state funding formulas. Any additional education funding is left for the County Council to consider in the coming weeks.
Council members and staff will hold a number of workshops this month and in April before a budget proposal is officially introduced April 15.
Public budget hearings are scheduled for May 6, and the County Council is expected to enact a budget ordinance May 27.

title: Dorchester County and DCPS Working to Reduce FY26 Budget Deficits
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Dorchester County and DCPS working to reduce FY26 budget deficits

 March 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 573

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County Manager Jerry Jones considers the fiscal year 2026 budget a moving target."There are a lot of things that are changing," he said about predicted state funding during a Dorchester County Council budget work session Thursday. "This is not a weekly thing, but almost a daily thing. ... We just don't know how this is going to unfold."
County staff has been going through the operating and capital budgets line by line to find efficiencies, Jones said.
"We are constantly working on solutions," he said. "We're finding those efficiencies. We have made substantial changes already."
During the work session, Jones detailed estimated revenue and expenditures for fiscal year 2026. According to Jones' presentation, preliminary projections for the budget show a deficit of $6.2 million, with $87.7 million in estimated revenue and $93.9 million in estimated expenditures.
Jones outlined a list of mandates from the state that contribute to the county's deficit. These include reductions in grant funding, losses from proposed property tax deductions, an increase in state education maintenance of effort costs and increased financial responsibilities for things like teacher retirement.
Both Jones and County Council members said the budget would look a lot different without these mandates. Jones said that without the mandates, the county would not be facing a deficit. He said the county would instead have had $200,812 more in revenue than expenditures.
The council and county manager also talked about significant budget cuts made two years ago. Council Vice President Mike Detmer said the fat had already been trimmed from the budget at that time.
"At this point, we're trying to keep the ship from sinking," he said.
Council President Lenny Pfeffer said he and Detmer have plans to go to Annapolis to testify in front of the Maryland General Assembly on legislation that would negatively affect the county's budget.
EDUCATION FUNDING
Detmer said the decrease in state funding and increase in the county's fiscal responsibility is largely driven by the state's goal to meet its financial obligation to the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, a state plan that aims to improve student outcomes and the quality of education.
Dorchester County Public Schools, which has its own budget separate from the county, also is facing a deficit. The deficit, which was estimated to be $10.19 million in January, is now estimated to be $5.59 million.
During a Dorchester County Board of Education budget work session also held Thursday, Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson shared refinements the district has made to the budget since the board's work session in January.
He said the $4.6 million in additional cuts to reduce the deficit were made through reductions to alternative education programming, supplies costs, travel costs, contracted services and fixed charges as well as expanding the district's understanding of Blueprint guidance to better match funding with expenses.
"We are taking it serious, and we are trying to make the changes we can to reduce our budget in a smart way," Thompson said.
At the County Council work session, council member Ricky Travers said other counties are having the same budget problems.
"Rural Maryland is the worst right now because the bigger counties, you just add another zero to it, but they've got a little bit more ability to garnish more money per penny (on taxes)," he said. "But this big number is astronomical."
Jones said the county will play it by ear on when it holds its next budget work session. He said when it is held will be announced to the public.

title: Maryland spent big on youth mental health — but then the budget crisis hit
author: Sasha Allen Capital News Service
content:
Maryland spent big on youth mental health — but then the budget crisis hit

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Sasha Allen Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 1370
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The new statewide youth mental health program supported behavioral health services for more than 58,000 students in its first eight months of operations from March through October 2024. Four out of every five of Maryland public schools received aid for mental health services under the state's effort.But as the General Assembly moved to balance Maryland's fiscal 2025 budget last spring, lawmakers cut funding for the state's fledgling youth mental health program from Gov. Wes Moore's recommended $110 million to $40 million.
With the state's fiscal problems deepening, Moore is recommending the state allocate $40 million annually through 2030 to a program he once suggested should get $130 million a year starting in fiscal 2026.
Meagan Pantelis, a clinical social worker at Thrive Behavioral Health, said the proposed cuts would decimate services for students that, in many cases, are just getting off the ground.
"Whenever I found out about that proposed cut, the very first thing that came to mind is that Gov. Moore is wanting to balance a budget on the backs of our children," Pantelis said. "I just find that to be just egregious. I mean, why are our children the population that we are targeting? Why are they not the population that we want to build up and support?"
Moore, however, has stressed the state must act to close a structural $3 billion budget gap driven in part by the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the 10-year, multibillion-dollar education reform plan that created the youth mental health program.
"We only have difficult decisions ahead," Moore said in his State of the State address in early February. "We must close this $3 billion budget gap."
The mental health crisisDuring the 2022-23 school year, over a quarter of Maryland high school students reported their mental health was not good at most or all times, according to a Maryland Department of Health survey.
The percentage was only slightly lower for middle school students, with 22% reporting their mental health was not good at most or all times.
"We all know generally that there's a mental health crisis," said Lorianne Moss, the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission program manager. "So as sort of the preamble to our first call for proposals, we laid out some data."
That data, from the Centers for Disease Control, showed 40% of high school students experience persistent feelings of sadness or hopelessness. Citing such statistics, the consortium urged mental health programs and nonprofits across the state to apply for funds.
Applicants requested a total of $380 million in grants, said Mark Luckner, executive director of the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission, which oversees the consortium. That's more than three times what the consortium had to allocate.
Nevertheless, the state funded mental health service providers in every county.
Preventing youth suicide is one of the consortium's key goals, said Dr. John Campo, director of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine. Sixteen of the consortium's 129 grants so far focus on suicide prevention.
Suicide is the second-leading cause of death for people ages 10-14 and third for people ages 15-24, according to the most recent CDC data.
"Suicide kills more young people in that age group than cancer, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, respiratory illnesses, infections of all kinds, meningitis, pneumonia, HIV, COVID — the whole nine yards," Campo said. "Add them all together, suicide kills more people than all those things combined."
In Maryland, the teen suicide rate increased by more than a third from 2014 to 2022. Campo said the state's health care system has been ill-equipped to deal with that increase.
"Mental health crisis isn't a priority in most emergency departments," Campo said.
Campo is one of the co-chairs of the consortium's best practices subcommittee, a group that developed a list of evidence-based mental health practices for grantees to implement.
Each program targets a different facet of the mental health crisis. The responses are also tailored to the varying levels of severity of the mental health conditions different age groups experience.
The consortium found through surveys targeted at both students and parents that 90% of students and families were satisfied with the services.
"A lot of these practices have been tested," Campo said. "If regional organizations adopt them and implement them with fidelity, we really do want to believe that there will be positive outcomes associated with it."
From the city to the ShoreThe youth mental health crisis touches all of Maryland, and so does the state's response — but grants are tailored to the vast differences among Maryland's urban, suburban and rural communities.
In Baltimore City, the 11 grants the consortium issued take into account a stigma surrounding mental health services, said Jennifer Cox, director of the University of Maryland School Mental Health Program, which received a $970,000 grant to run a number of programs.
"We think in Baltimore City, we have to be a little bit more creative than just saying, 'Come get help,' " Cox said. "We know we have good things to offer, we just need to find a good way to offer it."
Working with trusted community organizations such as churches and youth centers, the program has been able to reach people who would otherwise not seek out mental health treatment, Cox said.
Services range from in-school counseling from certified clinicians to parent and caregiver education programs.
Meanwhile, the state's efforts on the largely rural Eastern Shore stress increasing access to treatment in a region that's short of professionals to respond to the youth mental health crisis.
According to the October 2024 report, "Investing in Maryland's Behavioral Health Talent," Maryland is nearly 50% short of the mental health workers it needs.
"There's a resounding message of 'we just need more,'" said Beth Anne Dorman, CEO of For All Seasons, a behavioral health and rape crisis center that received a grant to expand its services in Kent County. "We need more."
Caroline County, where two organizations won grants to expand their mental health services, faces the same situation, said Derek Simmons, the county's superintendent of schools.
"We are a rural county that is less wealthy than a lot of parts of the state," said Simmons, co-chair of the consortium's best practices committee. "So access to behavioral health is near and dear, and a real challenge where I'm at."
An uncertain future
If the General Assembly agrees with the funding levels suggested in the governor's budget, programs that just started last year may have to be eliminated, said Del. Eric Ebersole (D-Baltimore County, Howard).
"That group worked in good faith to bring providers online," said Ebersole, a consortium member. "If the government loses them, can you get them back?"
Dan Martin, senior director of public policy at the Mental Health Association of Maryland, said the proposed cut in planned funding comes at a time when youth mental health care is more important than ever.
"At a time when 18% of high school students and 24% of middle school students have seriously considered suicide in the past year, a reduction of this size in school mental health funding could prove disastrous," Martin said.
If the General Assembly approves Moore's budget proposal, the grants distributed by the program in fiscal years 2025 and 2026 combined will be cut 28% from the total amount distributed the prior two years.
Asked for comment, Moore's office stressed the governor's proposed allocation for fiscal year 2026 and beyond is exactly what the General Assembly approved for 2025.
"Gov. Moore is maintaining the current level of funding for the Maryland Consortium on Coordinated Community Supports," wrote a spokesperson from the governor's office. "The Governor strongly supports behavioral health treatment for Maryland's children, and maintaining current levels of funding during the state's budget crisis reflects that commitment."
The Mental Health Association of Maryland is urging action to try to persuade the General Assembly to restore funding to a higher level. The organization is circulating a fact sheet with information on the consortium, the work it's done and what a permanent cut in funding would do to students and schools.
"Use the above information and write an email to your legislators asking them to restore funding to the Community Supports Partnership Fund," the fact sheet said. "Provide testimony (either written or oral or both) opposing the cut" at General Assembly hearings.
And under the "why is funding needed" section, the Mental Health Association fact sheet reads: "Dramatic worsening of the behavioral health of children and youth over the last decade."

title: Dorchester County Public Schools Credits Test Improvement to Student Accountability
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Dorchester County Public Schools credits test improvement to student accountability

 February 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 461
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County Public Schools reading and language arts supervisor believes the more than 20% jump in reading proficiency for Mace's Lane Middle School eighth graders has to do with students taking a reading diagnostic seriously."And that's where I struggle the most is trying to really get across how important it is for us to truly know what students can do," Reading and Language Arts Supervisor Laura Aberg said at a Dorchester County Board of Education meeting Thursday. "And if they don't chose to show us that on the assessments, it's really hard for us to support them the best way possible."
Aberg said that before students took the middle of the year NWEA MAP Growth Assessment, she went to each eighth grade class at Mace's Lane and North Dorchester Middle schools to "impress upon them the importance of this assessment and college and career readiness."
"And I feel like it made a positive impact," she said. "The teachers at Maces Lane said that the kids really took their assessment much more seriously this go-around."
The proof is in the pudding. At Mace's Lane, eighth grade reading proficiency increased 20.8% from the beginning of year assessment. It increased from 35.2% to 56%.
At North Dorchester Middle, eighth grade reading proficiency increased 1.1%, from 51.9% to 53%. At South Dorchester School, eighth grade reading proficiency increased 4%, from 64% to 68%.
Aberg said the test's national vendor reached out about Mace's Lane Middle's eighth grade scores because they were confused about the major increase.
"Students are only meant to grow at the eighth grade level by 4.5 percentage points," she said. "We had students growing by crazy amounts."
Aberg said she thinks students didn't show "what they're actually made of" on the beginning of the year assessment.
"And I believe that is a much more accurate picture of our students," she said about the middle of the year scores.
At the end of the presentation, Board of Education Member Christine LaMonica said this generation of children is inquisitive. "And they want to know the 'why,'" she said. "And if you can grasp them in on the 'why,' then they show you what they got."
Mentioning her own experience as a teacher, Board President Sheri Hubbard said the bottom line is kids have to feel it's important to show what they know.
"And no matter how hard teachers try, it's just hard," she said. "And so we need everybody working together to impress upon the kids how important it is for them to show what they know."
Hubbard said it's about more than a test.
"Not just for the school system," she said. "Who cares what we get on a test? But we have to give them the intrinsic gratification, help build that in kids so that they will want to do it."

title: Talbot Board of Education Approves FY2026 Budget
author: Konner Metz

Talbot Board of Education approves FY2026 budget

 February 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News

 EASTON — The Talbot County Board of Education passed the district's fiscal year 2026 unrestricted budget during Wednesday's meeting.It comes in at $86 million, an $8.9 million increase compared to the district's unrestricted budget in fiscal year 2025. Significant increases include salary costs and fixed charges.
Talbot County Public Schools Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones said that $2 million is built out for 33 "highly necessary," additional positions. The budget also accounts for $1.3 million in expected health insurance cost increases due to inflation and the new positions, she said.
Jones noted that while the unrestricted budget is $8.9 million higher than last year, the overall budget of $95.9 million — made up of restricted and unrestricted funds — is only up by $3.6 million. This is mostly due to a year-to-year decrease in federal grant funding.
"So it is not, in total, a significant increase," Jones said. "There has been a significant shift from federal to … local."
Next month, the district will present the budget to the Talbot County Council. The council will hold a public budget hearing in May.
The district will be asking the county for approximately $18.4 million in capital funding — $18.1 million for ongoing renovations at Chapel District Elementary School and $260,000 for new stadium lights at St. Michaels Middle High School.
Wednesday, Board of Education President Emily Jackson complimented Jones for her work during the budget process. She said she's comfortable with the budget while acknowledging that much is unknown in regards to the state's contributions.
"I will vote yes on the budget when it comes to that, because I feel like this is a very sound budget based in fact of what we do know," Jackson said.
Board Member Cynthia Jurrius said she appreciates that the budget aligns with the district's strategic goals.
"We do know we have some potential things down the road that may change the budget as far as what state funding we get (and) what changes may come down the road there," Jurrius said. "But for what we know now, I think this is a good budget and a sound plan."

title: Talbot Board of Ed Discusses Dress Code, School Uniforms
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Ed discusses dress code, school uniforms

 February 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 527
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Board of Education held a discussion during its virtual meeting Wednesday, touching on dress code updates and the possibility of implementing school uniforms.District Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi shared a revision to the district's administrative regulations for dress code. Administrative regulations do not require board approval.
Under the dress code standards, wording that singled out specific clothing items, such as "low rider pants" and "spaghetti straps," was removed. The dress code largely remained unchanged aside from a few strikethroughs.
Board Member Ann O'Connor asked why some of the language was removed. Pepukayi said there were discrepancies of students getting coded, particularly in regards to body shape and size.
"Some of our administrators feel like they spend a lot of their day chasing down specific, indicated things in dress code," Board President Emily Jackson said. "And it becomes a barrier to creating a relationship. And we feel like we are policing tiny little infractions all day long."
The board president later added that when it comes to dress code, she's in favor of standards that promote "the dignity, and value and worth of each student" rather than rules that police "individual items of clothing."
Board Member Deborah Bridges said the revision "guts what we had intended it to be."
O'Connor said while she wasn't on the board for past discussions regarding dress code policy, she doesn't see a need for spaghetti straps to be permitted. She then raised the topic of school uniforms.
"In fact, I know this is probably not the way to bring it up, but I'm in full favor of school uniforms," O'Connor said.
She said uniforms would put everyone "on the same playing field" and "solve all problems." O'Connor asked for it to be put on the table as an option.
Pepukayi said the topic of school uniforms has been discussed since she joined the district in 2022. Rochelle Eisenberg, the board's attorney, said the board does have the power to require school uniforms.
"You can have a policy requiring school uniforms so long as you would be willing to purchase them for children whose families could not afford them," Eisenberg said.
"I'm not opposed to uniforms," Board Vice President Amy Dodson said. "I actually went to a high school that required uniforms, and I personally loved them as a student because I didn't have to think about what I was going to wear."
"I know the kids aren't in favor of this at all, but it would solve many problems," O'Connor said.
Eisenberg suggested no matter how the board proceeds, it should procure sufficient community input.
Jackson, who has been on the board since 2018, said the discussion of school uniforms has come up under past superintendents. She suggested the board look at past data and outcomes.
"I was told that it was once tried and it was not widely adopted, and it was very hard to enforce," Jackson said. "I think that was at one of our elementary schools."
Pepukayi said talking with administrators and advisory committees can be a "starting point."
"I'll talk to team members who've been here to get some historical context," Pepukayi said. " … And then with current groups that we have, we'll formulate some questions and get some information."

title: Talbot School Leaders Discuss Immediate, Long-Term Effects of Blueprint Cuts
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot school leaders discuss immediate, long-term effects of Blueprint cuts

 February 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 494
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Budget cuts in The Blueprint for Maryland's Future could have a potential impact of $1.7 million to Talbot County Public Schools this fiscal year, district officials said Monday.That gap is the amount of additional local funding the district may need if the governor's current budget proposal is passed, Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones said to Board of Education members during Monday's work session.
She added that the impacts may snowball over the next eight years to the tune of more than $30 million in reduced funding from the state.
"These are deep cuts that are being proposed," Jones said.
Gov. Wes Moore filed the Excellence in Maryland Public Schools Act last month, a bill that proposes drastic cuts to education funding amid a nearly $3 billion state budget deficit.
If passed, the most significant cut would be a reduction in the "per-pupil foundation" funding outlined in The Blueprint's original formulas. In fiscal year 2026, it would reduce Talbot County's funding by $685,000, according to district calculations.
That's more than a third of the projected $1.7 million gap created by state cuts this year, which also includes reductions in compensatory education and multilingual learners funding, a decrease in the state's share of nonpublic special education tuition costs, and a hike in how much pension costs districts are required to pick up.
District Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said the cuts to foundation funding per pupil, along with the slashes to compensatory and multilingual education, stand out. Superintendents across the state are continuing to advocate against the proposals, she said.
"While this excellence in education bill overall is saving money, it's still not hitting the foundation," Pepukayi said. "That's the main push in the advocacy."
The superintendent said it's been conveyed that districts are expected to go back to counties "to make up those expenses."
"That's all well and good if you live in Montgomery County or Prince George's County," Board Vice President Amy Dodson said. "That doesn't really help us out here."
During the meeting, Jones provided what the cumulative reductions in funding to Talbot County will be if the Excellence in Maryland Public Schools Act passes as proposed. For fiscal years 2026 through 2033, $20 million would be stripped from what the current Blueprint formulas outline for per-student funding.
Additionally, $9 million in compensatory education aid and $2.9 million in multilingual learner aid could be slashed over the next eight years, she said.
Board President Emily Jackson suggested board members begin their own advocacy amid the looming cuts.
"If we could, as a board, come together and talk about how we could take a stand here, I think that would be good," Jackson said. "I think that would be a good first step in that direction."
Dodson added on, asking if members of the community could speak up, too.
"Do we want to get people in the community to write letters about this at this point? They're chopping our funding majorly," Dodson said. "It seems like people in the community should also speak up, if they're so inclined."

title: Caroline County Public Schools Could Face Major State Budget Cuts
author: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline County Public Schools could face major state budget cuts

 February 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 366
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The proposed Caroline County Public Schools fiscal year 2026 budget shows potential cuts the county could face from the reduction of funding in the proposed state budget.According to the county's 2026 fiscal budget, over eight years, the district could face $41 million in reductions.
"An overall impact on Caroline County Public Schools of a reduction in funding is $41 million over eight years," Caroline County public schools Superintendent Derek Simmons said at the Caroline County board of education meeting.
The education funding cuts laid out in Gov. Wes Moore's proposed state budget for next year come as the state faces a near $3 billion deficit.
With the potential cuts on the horizon, Simmons wants parents and students to know they will be OK in 2026, but in the long term, he said, the cuts will add up.
"I don't want to spread fear and panic for anyone watching at home," Simmons said. "Caroline County Public Schools is going to be OK in FY26. We would be a lot better OK if the promise of Blueprint was there and the reduction wasn't there."
The Blueprint, the state's education improvement and funding initiative through 2032, originally outlined an increase in teacher collaborative time, during which teachers are not in classes and can plan, grade or meet with students individually. But with adjustments made in the state's budget to combat the deficit, collaborative time will take a hit.
Other Blueprint cuts will impact the district in the coming years as well, the superintendent said.
Foundation funding, or the base level per pupil funding from the state, is expected to decrease by $868,273 in 2026, according to Simmons' presentation.
Compensatory education is the fund for students in low-income areas allowing free or reduce lunch for students. In 2026, the proposed funding for compensatory education will decrease by $513,912.
In 2026 the proposed funding for multilingual learners, or students who speak languages other than English, decrease by $91,425.
Although these funding declines are manageable, over time the numbers will grow, causing bigger problems, Simmons said.

Steve Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) has introduced Senate Bill 562, which would designate the original Maryland Orange Crush as the state cocktail. The bill is co-sponsored by Sens. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) and Mary Beth Carozza (R-Somerset, Wicomico, Worcester).
Hershey also sponsored Senate Bill 561, which, along with House Bill 227 sponsored by Del. Chris Adams (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), would allow electric cooperatives to use unclaimed funds only to assist cooperative members or donate to nonprofit organizations, rather than treating them as abandoned property.
Additionally, Hershey introduced Senate Bill 355, seeking to delay the implementation of the Family and Medical Leave Insurance Program by two years.
Energy and Education LegislationDel. Jeff Ghrist (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) is behind two bills on solar energy regulation: House Bill 739 (cross-filed as Senate Bill 478) and House Bill 742. One bill would prohibit the use of eminent domain for solar siting, while the other would return control over solar development to county governments.
Ghrist also introduced House Bill 736, which seeks to remove the mandate requiring local school systems to offer pre-kindergarten for three-year-olds. Another provision in the bill would increase state funding to help Kent County construct a new middle school.
On law enforcement, Ghrist is supporting a bill — potentially House Bill 122 — that would require the removal of unfounded complaints from police personnel files.
Nursing, Historic Preservation, and Cemetery ProtectionsDel. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) has proposed House Bill 602 (cross-filed as Senate Bill 407), directing the State Board of Nursing to negotiate reciprocity agreements with neighboring states for advanced practice nursing licensure. Another measure, House Bill 616 (cross-filed as Senate Bill 421), would extend the statute of limitations for crimes related to cemetery destruction and prohibit damaging cemetery landscaping. The bill is co-sponsored by Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-Dorchester, Wicomico).
Hutchinson is also behind House Bill 760, which would establish a local appeals process for Maryland Historic Trust decisions.
Budget Deficit Shifts to CountiesGov. Wes Moore's proposed budget shifts some of the state's structural deficit onto county governments. Ghrist criticized the move, stating that counties did not contribute to the deficit but are now being forced to compensate for state overspending.
"For my district, $720,000 will be shifted to Caroline County on top of an additional $1.8 million more that the county will have to add to education under Kirwan mandates," Ghrist stated. He cited similar financial burdens for other Eastern Shore counties, including Cecil, Kent, and Queen Anne's.
"This will stifle economic growth because people will be sending more of their hard-earned money to the government rather than spending it in their local economies," Ghrist added.
Law Enforcement and Traffic StopsA controversial proposal, Senate Bill 292, has drawn strong opposition from law enforcement officials, including Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker. The bill would reclassify certain primary traffic offenses as secondary offenses, preventing law enforcement from stopping drivers solely for those violations.
"These minor traffic violations could actually lead to catching suspects that have committed serious felonies, recovering firearms, and stopping drug-related crimes," Baker said. A hearing on the bill is scheduled before the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee.
Other Bills of Local InterestHouse Bill 28, sponsored by Del. Josh Bouchat (R-Carroll, Frederick), proposes a constitutional amendment requiring all Maryland counties to adopt a charter government structure.
House Bill 278, also from Bouchat, would provide an income tax subtraction modification for enhanced agricultural management equipment to support sustainable farming practices.
House Bill 192, introduced by Del. Nino Mangione (R-Baltimore County), aims to curb student cell phone use in schools under the proposed "No Distracted Learning Act."
As these bills move through the legislature, local officials and residents will have the opportunity to voice their support or concerns during committee hearings and public forums.
