title: Caroline Superintendent Projects 'Good Budget Year,' Discusses Blueprint
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Caroline superintendent projects 'good budget year,' discusses Blueprint

 December 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 617
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — At last week's Caroline County Board of Education meeting, Superintendent Derek Simmons provided board members with a preview into the district's fiscal year 2026 outlook as budget season nears.Simmons said he and his team are in the process of developing a draft budget. What happens in this year's state legislative session is expected to impact how the budget looks, the superintendent said.
"We are really contingent upon what happens at the state level for our funding, and we do expect the General Assembly to be very engaged in things that could impact us budget-wise," Simmons said. "So it is 100% likely we will not have a clear picture of our budget, of our revenue numbers until mid-April at best."
At the Dec. 3 meeting, Simmons reviewed the fiscal year 2025 budget, noting that around 60% of unrestricted funds were spent on salaries and wages. Those funds largely come from the state, as the district received around 66% of its FY25 revenue from the state in unrestricted money.
"When we talk about where our expenses come from, it's people," Simmons said. "No surprise as we've said for years, we are a people business. It takes people to educate children. It takes people to make school work."
Contracted services accounted for just under 7% of the unrestricted budget. Board Member Troy Plutschak said he wants the board to find out how much auditing through outside companies costs.
Simmons said the district is often audited, but that moving audits in-house would be difficult and put the district in a "world of hurt." Potentially, one or two finance-related positions would be added, along with adding a stress onto the workload of school principals, Simmons said.
According to the superintendent, he doesn't expect federal money or county allocations to drastically change heading into fiscal year '26. "We knew '25 was the tight year," he said.
Assuming no major changes are made to the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's initiative to increase education funding, Simmons has an optimistic outlook. That's partly due to increased multilingual learner, special education and overall enrollment in the county.
"We are anticipating what should be a good budget year for Caroline County Public Schools," Simmons told the board.
BLUEPRINTWhile there was positivity in the fiscal year 26 forecast, Simmons made clear to board members that the outlook could drastically change if state legislators enact major adjustments to funding in Blueprint.
Changes to fiscal 26 funding "can have absolute detrimental impacts to Caroline County Public Schools," he said, since Caroline County Public Schools is "not a district that has extra wealth to go to to fill gaps."
"Not trying to paint a dire picture, but I don't want to paint roses where they may not exist," he said. "They should. But I want to make sure that everybody in the public is very clear as well. It should be, but if they go changing things in the FY 26 formula, it will hurt in this county more so than others probably."
State legislators may be tasked with discussions about Blueprint funding this winter, as the state faces a predicted budget deficit of $2.7 million for fiscal year 2026.
Blueprint will require all schools to meet a minimum teacher salary of $26,000 by July 2026. Caroline County Public Schools has not met that mark yet, but Simmons said the district is making progress.
"We are still working to get our starting teacher salary up to the mandated $60,000 by FY27," Simmons said. "We have done a great job through negotiations. We're roughly $5,000 away."
Looking to the next budget cycle, salaries and maintaining adequate staffing levels are at the top of mind for the superintendent and his team.
"We need to stay competitive with salaries and benefits for all employees," Simmons said.

 DENTON — Chrissy Bartz and Stefanie Johnson were sworn in Tuesday as the newest members of the Caroline County Board of Education, while Michele Wayman was unanimously selected as the board's new president.Wayman, who has served on the board since 2021, was nominated for president by Board Member Troy Plutschak and confirmed in a 5-0 vote. She previously worked at Caroline County Public Schools in various teacher and administrative roles for a combined 36 years, retiring in 2009.
"I can promise you as president of your board, I will do the very best that I can do," Wayman said during Tuesday evening's meeting.
Bartz nominated Mark Jones to once again serve as vice president of the board alongside Weaver. All five members voted in favor.
Bartz, who was appointed in June to the Board of Education, ran unopposed in District 1. She is the director of community based programs at Choptank Community Health, overseeing the school-based health centers and serving as a provider at Greensboro Elementary.
In an interview, she said she's "excited" about the district's direction, particularly the fact that eight of nine schools are designated community schools by the state's education initiative, Blueprint for Maryland's Future.
"In a county that's rural, it is really important that we recognize that our schools really are hubs in our community and that we can bring a lot of resources to families and kids alongside of the education that they receive in those buildings," Bartz said. "It's a safe place for families."
Assuming outgoing President Richard Barton's District 2 seat is Johnson, who also ran unopposed. In an interview with the Star Democrat, Johnson said she's looking forward to the new role.
At first, she was hesitant about running, but the idea grew over time as she thought about her 11- and 14-year-old daughters, who both attend Caroline County schools. She said it's a great way to be a part of "conversations that can make change."
"When you're a parent sitting on the 'outside, you hear all of these things, and they may not necessarily make sense to you as a parent," Johnson said. "People get in their emotions and they run with that. But I'm that type of person that I want to know why, and I'm going to go straight to the source to figure that answer out."
Johnson is the executive director of the His Hope Ministries shelter in Denton and a board member for the Caroline County Chamber of Commerce.
"There's still parts of Caroline County that I haven't gotten to see or be connected with," Johnson said, "so I'm really excited to be able to go to different parts of the county and just see what's happening, see what schools are doing."

title: Legislators Talk State Budget Before Heading Back to Annapolis in January
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Legislators talk state budget before heading back to Annapolis in January

 December 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 557
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The state of the state's budget took up a large part of the conversation at a Dorchester Chamber of Commerce luncheon with state legislators on Dec. 4.The Lower Shore delegation answered questions from chamber members regarding concerns about Maryland's fiscal health, with a looming $2.7 billion state budget deficit predicted in fiscal year 2026.
"The reality is that if you continue to do the things that have gotten us into this deficit, it's only going to take us back there again," Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said. "There needs to be a structural, fundamental change."
Mautz and Dels. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-Dorchester, Wicomico), Chris Adams (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) and Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) all spoke at the chamber lunch. They, along with the rest of the state's legislators, will head back to Annapolis in January for the 447th session of the Maryland General Assembly.
In talking about the state's budget, Mautz also said there should be incentives in place to try to drive state agencies to save money.
Sample-Hughes said the state should do its fiscal homework and find out what it "really (has) to work with."
"But I do believe that we can still address and attack some of these goals that we have, whether it's education, whether it's climate, whether it's criminal justice," she said. "We can do it in a pragmatic way."
Adams said to solve the budget problem, the state has to leverage and grow its private sector.
"You do not do what we've done for the past two years," he said. He said the state and its leadership need to stop spending so much, own up to the problem and stop blaming it on COVID-19.
Hutchinson expressed his concerns with the transportation budget and the lack of funding for many infrastructure projects across the state.
"We've got to pay attention to our transportation budget," he said.
BLUEPRINTThe legislators also talked about the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, a plan passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021 that aims to improve student outcomes and the quality of education across the state through increasing education funding by $3.8 billion over a 10-year period.
Sample-Hughes said although Blueprint's goals are important, the General Assembly's decision to pass the plan has contributed to the state's budget deficit. She later advocated for giving more resources to the nonprofits that already serve 3 and 4 year olds, rather than putting money toward expanding early childhood education in the state's public school systems.
Mautz said he thinks the project needs to be paused so that the plan's strengths and weaknesses can be better evaluated.
JUVENILE CRIMEThe legislators also talked about the state of juvenile crime in Maryland, with Sample-Hughes calling for the removal of Department of Juvenile Services Secretary Vincent Schiraldi.
Hutchinson said that with recent juvenile justice reforms going into effect Nov. 1, he doesn't think a lot of legislators are going to want to discuss juvenile crime this upcoming session.
"Because they'll say, 'We just put that in place. We haven't even been able to see the results,'" he said.
Adams said law enforcement is needed now more than ever and officers need to be able to do their jobs.
"If you want a society, if you want a City of Cambridge, if you want an Eastern Shore (or) State of Maryland, if you want a United States that is civil, there have to be consequences," he said.

title: More Than Half of Talbot County Students Receive Free and Reduced Lunches
author: Tom McCall
content:
More than half of Talbot County students receive free and reduced lunches

 November 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Life 
 
 944
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — More than half of students in Talbot County Public Schools receive free or reduced cost meals at school every week, according to the Maryland Department of Education.Free and reduced meals allow them to eat well at school.
"It is basically healthy for them. They get a fruit, a vegetable, a protein and they get a milk," said Michelle Garniga, assistant coordinator at the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center for the after school program. She has six children in TCPS.
The number of free and reduced meals in a school is a measure of poverty and food insecurity in a community.
The Maryland Department of Education found 58.41% of the students in Talbot County received free and reduced meals in 2022-2023, just under 13% higher than it was the school year prior.
At some county schools, this rate is even higher.
"What drives up the numbers are Easton Middle School and Easton Elementary School," said Catharine Poe of the Talbot Hunger Coalition, an organization of food banks and resources fighting food insecurity in the county. "Easton Elementary is 76% and the Middle School is 64%."
At other schools, numbers alone may not be enough to gauge the full scope of students' needs. Poe said the Easton High numbers trend lower because the kids do not want the other kids to know they need food.
Debbie Gardner, communications director for Talbot County Public Schools, said "We definitely talk about hunger. We consider feeding children to be one of our responsibilities in addition to educating them. We know the needs are greater than even what we see on paper."
FOOD INSECURITYThe increased rate of students receiving free and reduced meals mirrors a growing amount of food insecurity in Talbot County, where costs of food, housing and other necessities are outpacing salary growth.
"If you make $15 an hour (minimum wage) and work every single day for a 40 hour week, you only make $31,000. So if you have a family, that is not going to go very far. As soon as you have multiple children, it becomes impossible," Poe said. She said you need $38,000 for one person to make it in Talbot County.
Emily Moody, cofounder of CarePacks, said they started the nonprofit because "on weekends some kids were not eating until they got back to school on Monday morning. That is the nature of food insecurity — the uncertainty. Free and reduced meals are a lifeline. No question about it."
"Food insecurity is on the rise everywhere," Moody said. "What we have seen in the school system is an increase in the free and reduced meals program. People are working, but at wages that are not a livable wage and we live in an area where the cost of housing is really exorbitant. The cost for basic necessities like food and gas and utilities have increased. The place where the budget gets squeezed is with food at the grocery budget."
Katie Fox, community school program manager at Easton Elementary School, is the school based coordinator for CarePacks.
"Transportation impacts, if you don't have reliable transportation, which a lot of people in Talbot County don't have. That is a non-negotiable," Fox said.
And if you live in the far corners of Talbot County like Tilghman Island, it is hard to even get to a grocery store."
Moody said, "For people who are working full time to be able to afford housing and afford transportation and insurance and utilities. When those needs are met , then ideally there is room in your budget to be able to feed your family too."
It is not an issue of lazy for the working poor.
"It is not that people are not going to work. It is just that living is really expensive right now," Fox said.
FREE AND REDUCED MEALS HELPFamilies in need benefit from the free and reduced meals at the TCPS, which ensure students receive at least two meals a day for five days a week.
"It is not easy to give $4 every single day to four or five kids. That is like $24 a day. It would be fairer if everyone got free food. Just because you make more money, it is not fair for kids not to get the lunch," Garniga said.
Garniga said without the program she would be in debt and that over $100 a week for food would be a lot.
"It takes a lot of pressure off especially if you have a household with several kids. Being able to rely on the school system to provide breakfast and lunch every day, it is one of the biggest roles that the school plays," Poe said.
"They have figured out that it would save the average family $1,200 a child each year. It would end all this, and everybody who goes to school gets a free meal," Poe said.
Children in Talbot County are not alone in experiencing the benefits of free and reduced lunch programs.
At the state level, Gov. Wes Moore has signed a state Senate bill requiring the Maryland Department of Education to report to the General Assembly how much it will cost to provide free meals to all public school students in Maryland.
SB 579 opens with, "The Maryland General Assembly recognizes the positive impact on student's academic, physical and social and emotional health that results from ensuring students have access to breakfast and lunch programs while at school."
Figuring out how much it costs is the next step in pursuing universal expansion of free school meals, lawmakers argue.
The bill still needs to be funded, and it looks like the state budget is getting tighter. According to the latest briefing in the state's Spending Affordability Committee, there is a projected $2.7 billion budget shortfall that will confront the state legislature in January.

title: Caroline Commissioners Hear Update on Potential for New Middle School
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Caroline Commissioners hear update on potential for new middle school

 November 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 560
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline County Commissioners were given an update Tuesday morning on potential plans for a new middle school in the county.Bill Mengel, director of operations at Caroline County Public Schools, presented a revised fiscal year 2026 capital improvement plan to the commission. That improvement plan includes a priority item of year one and year two funding for a potential new middle school building.
Mengel noted that while the district was in the "talking phase" in August and September, it has "transitioned into the planning phase." This will soon include working with a consultant and eventually procuring a feasibility study, which may be complete in around six to eight months, Mengel said.
"One thing I've learned about building a new school is that it's a very serious endeavor," he said. "It takes a very long time to build one, approximately five years. But things change very, very quickly. That's really what kind of happened here, early October."
Currently, Colonel Richardson Middle School in Federalsburg and Lockerman Middle School in Denton serve as the district's two middle schools. It is unclear if the district will aim to build an entire new school, renovate, or add on. Mengel said those outcomes are largely dependent on the feasibility study's recommendation and the Board of Education's subsequent approval or denial.
The revised capital improvement plan was unanimously approved by the three commissioners Tuesday. Its top priority requests are $500,000 for HVAC work at Denton Elementary School and $5.5 million in early planning and design costs for a new or expanded middle school over the next two fiscal years.
$76 million in requested funding from the state for a new middle school build is listed next on the form. Mengel said that $76 million in requested state funding is around 89% of the total $86 million estimation for years one and two, meaning the county would be responsible for around 11% of the funding.
Maryland's Interagency Commission on School Construction, which the funding form will be submitted to, is looking at an approximate capacity of 126,000 square feet for a potential new build, according to Mengel. Mengel said the district's main point of negotiation is "How do we get more square footage?"
Cost per square foot has risen sharply year to year, the director of operations noted.
"If we get shovels in the ground in FY28 and we're able to move in for FY30 school year, that could be at or north of $490 per square foot," Mengel said. "So that's the driver."
Commission President Travis Breeding asked that the school district keep the county updated on the early planning and feasibility study results.
"Keep us in the loop on the study, because we would like to, if we're on the hook for 11% of this, we'd like to have input into, is it a renovation, addition, new location, all those discussions," Breeding said.
Mengel said he doesn't want work to begin on a large capital project if it's not set to accommodate increases in student population.
"I am aware, and so is the Board of Education, that there are some communities that are planned in and around Denton and points north (in) Caroline County," Mengel said. "We expect that there will be some students moving in impacting our populations. The last thing I want to do a build such as this, and then have it be at 100% occupancy within a couple of years."

 CAMBRIDGE — Since terminating contracts with companies for alternative education programming for students, Dorchester County Public Schools does not plan to move forward with any new companies.At a Dorchester County Board of Education meeting Thursday, the board voted to not pursue contracts with any alternative education companies that reached out through a request for proposal.

"The board is working to encourage and support Dr. Thompson's plans to continuously review and refine the best approaches possible to create the best conditions for each of our students to thrive academically," Wheedleton said in the email.
Four months earlier, the board voted to terminate its more than three-year contract with an alternative education program for high schoolers that would have cost the district over $3.3 million. title: DCPS to Examine Oldest Elementary School Buildings as Teachers Demand Change
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
DCPS to examine oldest elementary school buildings as teachers demand change

 November 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 574
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Cambridge — Sandy Hill Elementary School teachers filled the Dorchester County Board of Education meeting room Thursday to speak about the school's learning environment and the need for change.Karen McGowan, who has been a teacher at Sandy Hill for about 21 years, said their school is losing "excellent and dedicated" teachers. She said families are moving out of the district because they're concerned about sending their kids to Sandy Hill.
"Our school is old and falling apart," she said.
McGowan brought up plumbing issues in bathrooms, issues with the building's room temperatures and the difficulties of having to teach and learn in open concept classrooms. Other teachers brought up mold problems and critters and bugs getting into the building.
"There's organic growth in the building," Sandy Hill teacher Christy Starling said. "Just two years ago, we had to push back our availability to enter the building prior to school starting due to massive mold infestation that had to be treated within a month before school started."
As part of the consent agenda passed during the meeting, the board voted in favor of having architecture firm Hord Coplan Macht do an ed specifications and feasibility study for the district's oldest elementary schools, including Sandy Hill.
The ed specifications and feasibility study is being funded by Maryland's Interagency Commission on School Construction. The IAC is also allocating money for school capital improvement projects in the county once the study has been completed.
During a Board of Education work session in October, board members heard from the IAC on the different programs it operates and its projected budget allocations to Dorchester County.
For fiscal year 2026, the IAC estimates $2.75 million of its Capital Improvement Program will be allocated to Dorchester County, with a state cost share of 98%. The IAC'S Built To Learn Program, a temporary program created to hand out project-specific grants across the state, has $3.9 million budgeted for Dorchester County. Those funds need to be spent by 2031.
At the meeting Thursday, Assistant Superintendent of Administrative Services Michael Collins said it is important that the district moves forward with the ed specifications and feasibility study quickly because the IAC funding for it needs to be encumbered by the end of the year.
"We want to get this phase done so we can make big decisions on our old elementary schools," he said.
Collins said the ed speculations process will take six months. He said a committee will work with the community to get an idea of what the ideal Dorchester County elementary school looks like. The feasibility study, he said, will determine what makes the most sense for each of the schools included.
"The feasibility study basically looks at each school and says, is it feasible to either renovate this school, replace this school or combine this school in order to make it fit with the ed spec?" Collins said.
Once this process is complete, the district will be able to bid out capital improvement projects. Collins estimated it will take about a year to complete the studies.
At the end of the meeting, board member Talibah Chikwendu told the Sandy Hill teachers that she is sorry it will "take so long" to build a school.
"Because even though the things are in place for us to actually get a large amount of that money to get it done, the process takes a very long time," she said. "I am sorry that you will have to continue to work in those conditions while we do so."

title: Caroline Commissioners Hear from County Workers, Discuss School Budget
author: Tom McCall
content:
Caroline Commissioners hear from county workers, discuss school budget

 November 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 599

 DENTON — The Caroline County Commissioners convened on Tuesday and several topics were discussed, including the Employee Advisory Board's desire to attract and retain workers, approving changes to the fiscal year 2024 Caroline Board of Education budget and a restructuring of the Department of Public Works.BOARD OF EDUCATION BUDGETDerek Simmons, superintendent of Caroline County Public Schools, and Jill Hignutt, CFO of The Caroline Board of Education, requested amendments to the Board of Education's 2024 budget.
"We are here to share where the budget adjustments needed to take place in the operating budget and align those with the actuals at the end of the fiscal year," Simmons said.
Hignett gave the commissioners a copy of her short presentation, then began detailing the request.
"Starting with prescriptive revenues, there is a change of $6,389,071 related to our grant funding. Many of our grants cross fiscal years, so we must adjust the revenues to match the expenditures that were actually seen at year end," Hignutt said.
Then she shifted the attention to expenditures like driver salaries for transportation. Between fuel costs and bus driver salaries, the school system overspent about $39,000. She also mentioned parking lot repavement projects and classroom renovations.
There was a $5,782,498 surplus noted in the total budgeted revenues. According to Daniel Fox, deputy county administrator, the excess of revenue over expenditures is retained by the Board of Education to go to its fund balance.
The commissioners approved the amended budget.
EMPLOYEE ADVISORY BOARDNext up was the Employee Advisory Board, an authority that overlooks the corrections, emergency services, planning and codes, public works, recreation and parks, and administration departments. There is also a non-voting member department, the Department of Human Resources.
Todd Lord, chairman of the Advisory Board for Caroline County, thanked the commissioners for improving pensions for retirees and achieving competitive pay increases to help with recruitment and retention.
The board also wants cost of living adjustments due to the inflation following the pandemic.
Lord proposed an initiative to go forward as he hears from staff about pay and salaries.
"We recommend merit pay increases annually for step based off of employee evaluations. We want to get away from the bunching of salaries. Health care plans for retirees, that is another one of our initiatives being discussed heavily in departments," Lord said.
He said the goal was to increase retention and have attraction for the employees under the board's care.
"Right now we want to provide a health care plan that employees can take into retirement," Lord said. "Having their pension in retirement would be a huge benefit in retention for our staff."
Commissioner Frank Bartz responded, "Health care for retirees, that is a hard undertaking for the county."
Another commissioner said the same.
Porter said, "I don't foresee that we are going to be able to do health care benefits for people who are retiring at 55. The same inflation figures that you are using, we are facing as well."
President Travis Breeding said, "We have to find that balance — taking care of our employees and taking care of our tax payers and the constituents of the county."
PUBLIC WORKS REORGANIZATIONRobin Eaton, director of the Department of Public Works, asked the commissioners for the authority to reorganize the department to create a project manager position. He spoke of maintaining the 80 miles of dirt roads in the county.
"Our original structure had three crew leaders, so doing away with one of those crew leader positions and creating a project inspector slash utility locator," Eaton said.
"It is actually three crews. Two under crew leaders and one dirt road crew with four employees under the road superintendent," Kathleen Freeman, county administrator, said.
The commissioners approved the reorganization.

Newcomers win Talbot County Board of Education seats

 EASTON — Talbot County Public Schools is looking at new leadership, according to uncertified vote totals from the Maryland Board of Elections.Cynthia Marrah Jurrius, Karla Wieland-Cherry and Ann O'Connor, none of whom have prior experience on the Talbot County Board of Education, won seats for their districts.
The elected board members said they plan to bring their campaign priorities to the forefront of their terms, which begin Dec. 1 and will last for four years.
Talbot County's Board of Education is made up of seven members from different districts in the county and two student board members. Districts 2, 5 and 6 were on the ballot in the November election.
For district 2, O'Connor won with 52.7% of the vote, according to the State Board of Elections, beating out incumbent Board Member Candace Henry. O'Connor said her campaign provided the opportunity for her to get a better understanding of leading a campaign, school board responsibilities and Blueprint, Maryland's 10-year plan to improve the state's education system.
O'Connor said she has just skimmed the surface and is ready to learn more.
She said she will be prioritizing academics and discipline. With academics, she said she would like to see elementary students reading every night and working on more book reports, and for schools to provide summer reading lists.
For discipline, O'Connor said she has noticed a lack of consistency, or "different rules for different people."
"We need a plan for all the schools that this is the way we're going to, you know, this is the dress, this is the behavior when you walk in the building. If you veer from that, there's going to be this consequence, and you got to, I mean, it's the follow through," she said.
For District 5, Karla Wieland-Cherry won with 54.6% votes, according to the State Board of Elections. Wieland-Cherry, who defeated incumbent Board Member Anna Howie, said she appreciated the support she received from her campaign, though she did mention she "got a lot of negativity." She hopes she can work through any negative sentiments to have a productive four years on the board.
Wieland-Cherry said she will be prioritizing open communication for everyone she works with and promoting the Career and Technology Education Program, which offers job training in various fields.
She said it's important to encourage kids to look at career alternatives for those not interested in college, whether that be training to become a firefighter, plumber or welder.
"I think (the CTE program is) under encouraged, under utilized," Wieland-Cherry said. "And that's where jobs are."
For District 6, Jurrius won with 51.9% of the vote, defeating Kerry Gunshenan, according to the State Board of Elections. Current District 6 Board Member Mary Wheeler did not seek reelection.
Jurrius did not answer calls from reporters in time for publication.

title: Is Maryland’s ‘Blueprint’ the Path to Better Schools?
author: Marwa Barakat and Colin McNamara Capital News Service
content:
Is Maryland’s ‘Blueprint’ the path to better schools?

 October 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Marwa Barakat and Colin McNamara Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 1365
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A 10-year, $30 billion plan out of Annapolis, the Blueprint for Maryland's Future aims to dramatically improve the state's public schools by boosting teacher salaries, expanding pre-kindergarten and rewriting the curriculum — and school board candidates say the state's schools need that improvement."The Blueprint is Maryland's surest path to creating beyond great schools," said Phelton Moss, a school board candidate from Prince George's County.
But to hear other Maryland school board candidates tell it, the Blueprint is a budget-buster.
"The Blueprint sounds great on paper; however, funding it is a great challenge for every county in Maryland," St. Mary's County school board candidate Elena Brewer said.
That debate echoes across Maryland as voters in 20 of the state's 24 school districts prepare to go to the polls. The Local News Network at the University of Maryland sent a questionnaire to all 109 candidates, asking them, among other things, to name the state's top education issue.
Forty-two of the candidates who responded to the questionnaire expressed concerns about the costs and the mandates stemming from the Blueprint. In a school board election where there are no races in Baltimore City or County, a Prince George's County candidate, Zakyia Goins-McCants, summed up the views of a number of candidates from suburban and rural districts.
"The Blueprint for Maryland's Future is transformative legislation that reflects our state's commitment to equitable education," she said. "However, it was passed without a full funding plan, and the financial implications are significant."
'A transformational investment'Passed by the General Assembly in 2021 over the veto of then-Gov. Larry Hogan, a Republican, the Blueprint is built on five pillars. Under the Blueprint, school districts are mandated to:
Combat the teacher shortage by increasing the minimum teacher salary to $60,000 by July 2026 and build new "career ladders" for educators.Expand pre-kindergarten so that it's available free to low- and moderate-income families and available to all.Adjust the curriculum to ensure students are college- and career-ready by the end of 10th grade.Implement a "ninth-grade tracker" system to assess how the Blueprint is working for each student as part of a statewide accountability plan.Boost funding to match the state's lofty new goals.
Hearing all of that, many of the state's school board candidates said the Blueprint is a great but complex and pricey plan.
Tierney Davis, a board candidate from Cecil County, called the Blueprint "a transformational idea" but noted there are serious issues in implementing the plan. Veronica Lowe from Frederick County called it "a transformative investment in our education system" but expressed concerns about funding the effort.
Michael Shisler from Calvert County said the plan is a chance to "improve our common good."
"If we continue to see education as a cost, rather than as an investment, then folks will just wait for this latest reform to fade away," Shisler said. "The Blueprint is an opportunity to level the playing field for all kids in Maryland."
Several candidates said that the playing field needs leveling.
"The most important issue facing Anne Arundel County Public Schools is the existence of persistent gaps in opportunity and achievement between different subgroups of students," said Joanna Bache Tobin of Anne Arundel County.
Meanwhile, Julie Kaplan of Howard County said schools must improve to make sure every student leaves school prepared for college or a career.
"We must address the learning gaps created by the COVID-19 pandemic," she said.
A number of candidates cited stagnant or declining test scores in their school districts and beyond.
"Statewide, our student proficiency rates in math and English are suffering," said Laura McKenzie of Kent County.
But schools will improve if the Blueprint is implemented properly, its supporters said.
"The Blueprint offers us an opportunity to invest in our schools and ensure an excellent education for every student," said Meg Ricks, a candidate for the school board in Howard County.
'Unfunded'Support for the Blueprint was by no means uniform among the state's school board candidates, however. Many echoed the thoughts of Andre Gao, another Howard County school board candidate.
"The Blueprint for Maryland's Future sounds promising on paper with its goals, but the funding presents a significant problem," Gao said. "Without adequate financial support, implementing the Blueprint will be challenging."
The Blueprint lacks financial support at both the state and the district level.
The General Assembly approved the Blueprint without determining how it would be paid for, and as a result, the state is projected to run long-term deficits that largely track its increased education costs. A state Department of Legislative Services fiscal briefing released in January said that the deficit will appear in fiscal 2025 and hit nearly $2.93 billion in fiscal 2029 — a year when the Blueprint is set to cost the state $4 billion.
Rachel Hise, the executive director of the Blueprint's Accountability and Implementation Board, said she is hopeful the Maryland General Assembly will fully fund the Blueprint and is willing to make changes if necessary.
When asked whether state taxes will be raised to support the Blueprint, Hise said, "That is a decision for the governor and General Assembly."
Against that backdrop, Gov. Wes Moore — a longtime proponent of the Blueprint — has acknowledged that the plan may have to be altered.
"While I believe in making sure that we have a world-class education system, we've got to be able to work together to create an actual plan to be able to implement it because right now there are real challenges in being able to get that done and get it done in a way that the locals, and the state and every other partner who's involved sees that taking place," Moore told Fox45 News in Baltimore in July. "So, there have to be adjustments."
Meanwhile, school district candidates said the Blueprint is already putting pressure on local school budgets, given that school costs in Maryland are shared by the state and its 24 districts.
"While the Blueprint was touted as significantly increasing education funding, the reality is that the funding is not distributed equitably, and rural counties have been left out, by and large," said Cathy Allen, a school board candidate in St. Mary's County. "We did not receive increased funding from the state to cover mandates within the Blueprint."
'So many requirements'School board candidates said they worry not only about the Blueprint's costs, but also about the expensive edicts the plan imposes on local school districts. In some cases, they said, those mandates are already leading to unintended consequences.
Jon M. Andes, a candidate in Worcester County, said he fully supports the Blueprint's five pillars.
"However, without additional state funding, we will not be able to implement the Blueprint plan without making significant budget cuts to reallocate funds," Andes said. "As an example, to reach the $60,000 minimum (teacher) salary, we will need to significantly increase class size and reduce materials of instruction."
Such things are already happening in Howard County, Gao said.
"In our school district, we have not received sufficient funding from the state and county to fully implement the Blueprint," he said. "This has contributed to budget shortfalls, leading to staff cuts, program reductions and increased class sizes. Many teachers have already expressed concerns about the negative impact of staff shortages and increased class sizes."
Such issues stem from the fact that the Blueprint mandates that funding be redirected in a number of ways. For one thing, by mandating higher teacher salaries and a host of other changes, some school districts may be forced to cut other popular programs.
"The Blueprint for Maryland's Future mandates so many requirements that it's difficult for our local school system to continue programs it feels are successful," said Kerry Gunshenan, a school board candidate in Talbot County.
In addition, the Blueprint mandates that districts direct more funding to schools with larger numbers of high-need students, such as those that are performing poorly or where students are learning to speak English.
Mike Lukas, a board member who is running for re-election in Charles County, praised that change.
"Your ZIP code or household income should not define the quality of your education," he said.
Tom Woods, who is running for re-election to the board in Garrett County, neatly summed up the thoughts of many of the school board members across the state.
"The ideas and solutions presented by the Blueprint come with an awful lot of obstacles," Woods said.
Local News Network director Jerry Zremski contributed to this report.

title: Dorchester Ends Alternative Education Contract in Middle, Elementary Schools
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester ends alternative education contract in middle, elementary schools

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 448
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Cambridge — Four months since the Dorchester County Board of Education voted to terminate its more than three-year contract with an alternative education program for high schoolers, the board has decided to terminate its one-year contract with an alternative education program for elementary and middle school students.At a Board of Education meeting Thursday, the board unanimously voted to terminate its contract with Transforming Lives for convenience. The service provided alternative education for up to 48 Dorchester County Public Schools elementary and middle school students at one time.
Board members did not comment on the decision to terminate the contract at the meeting.
Review of the contract was not originally on Thursday's meeting agenda. The board voted to add it to the agenda after board member Chris Wheedleton made a motion to do so. Later in the meeting, Wheedleton made a motion to terminate the contract for convenience, which the board unanimously voted in favor of.
Wheedleton did not immediately respond for comment on the decision.
According to the contract, either party can terminate it for any or no reason with 60-days advance written notice.
The program, called Positive Change Academy-Dorchester, began this past summer and was set to end June 30, 2025. It is housed at The Judy Center at Sandy Hill Elementary School and at the New Directions Learning Academy. It cost the district $79,000 per month.
The board approved the contract at a special Board of Education meeting in July. At that meeting, district Superintendent Jymil Thompson said the district looked at this program as one stop in a student's education journey. He said it would be a place where students could remedy behavior and improve academics before going back into a "regular educational setting."
The district did not immediately respond for comment on the board's decision.
This is not the first time the board has terminated an alternative education contract in the past year.
In June, the Board of Education voted to terminate its more than three-year contract with Vision Quest, an alternative education program for district high schoolers that had been met with criticism from residents since the contract was approved in September 2023. The district had been paying Vision Quest $93,363 per month for services, which would have added up to over $3.3 million over three years.
The decision to terminate the Vision Quest contract was one of the reasons former Dorchester County Board of Education Vice President Susan Morgan resigned in June. She was the sole vote in favor of keeping the contract. In an interview with the Star Democrat in June, Morgan said the district needed an alternative program for the fall that would benefit the students as much as she witnessed first-hand with the success of Vision Quest.

title: Talbot Board of Ed Approves Funding for Capital Projects, Discusses Turf Field Status
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Ed approves funding for capital projects, discusses turf field status

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 700
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Following a lengthy discussion last month on the conditions of athletic fields in the district, the Talbot Board of Education moved forward Wednesday in deciding how to allocate available funds toward capital projects, including field improvements.Talbot County Public Schools has $1.5 million in fiscal year 2025 funding from the county meant to put toward capital projects, leaving the decision up to board members on which projects receive that money.
In past meetings, a list of potential projects — which total to $3.36 million — was set to vie for that $1.5 million. Those included Easton High School stadium lights, an Easton Elementary basketball court, a St. Michaels Elementary playground replacement, Easton High auditorium light replacements and an artificial turf field at the high school.
Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones told the board that the first three projects have been funded with grants. On Wednesday, Jones presented a modified list of potential capital projects. The auditorium lights and artificial turf field remained on that list.
Three projects were new to that list on Wednesday: HVAC unit replacements at Easton High for $1,100,000, LED lights at St. Michaels Middle High School for $566,000, and field improvements across the district for $200,000, the latter of which stemmed from concerns raised at a Sept. 18 board meeting about the safety and upkeep of high school fields in the county.
Board President Emily Jackson expressed concern that new projects would continue to usurp side projects, such as the artificial turf field, which is projected to cost around $1.8 million alone.
"Something's always going to take priority, which is why I'm saying (pull from our) fund balance, because that's what it's for, it's for those side projects that are never going to take priority," Jackson said.
Jackson and other board members recognized that the HVAC improvements and LED lights are necessary. Director of Operations Kevin Shafer said the district proposed HVAC improvements in a capital improvement plan to the state, and that the aging units can make it a couple more years before state funding may come through.
Shafer and Jones added that funds for field improvements could be sought through maintenance budget requests or adjustments. Shafer emphasized in order to increase field quality, his team needs better equipment "to do better maintenance."
The board unanimously approved a motion from Jackson to approve $817,321 for Easton High auditorium lights, $566,000 for LED lights at St. Michaels and the remaining $117,000 for athletic field projects in general. The projects will not begin until capital-enabling legislation is approved by the Talbot County Council.
ARTIFICIAL TURF FIELDMuch of Wednesday's back-and-forth between Shafer, Jones and the board centered on the potential of funding an artificial turf field at Easton High. It's a project that has received much community support, including from field hockey players and families.
Some board members suggested the board consider using extra funds the district has to save toward the $1.8 million projected price tag.
"I think we should begin to lay down our concrete plan if that's the way we're going to go, of how we're going to fund it in the future and what that's going to look like," Board Vice President Candace Henry said.
Shafer said that if a new turf field is agreed upon, he believes it should be placed at the current stadium field. Jackson disagreed, citing previous presentations to the board regarding football injury risks on artificial turf.
"We could look at maybe fencing off a different field to make it a more appropriate and safe field for our athletes to be on," Jackson said.
"I would urge the board to consider whether that would be the most equitable use of funds," Shafer responded, "… to just have a turf field for one sport, if it's going to be field hockey or whatever. I question whether that is a good investment in moving forward."
No official motions regarding funding for the turf project were made Wednesday, though Jackson keyed in on pushing the discussion forward.
"Safety for all of our athletes has to be the No. 1 priority," she said. "Number two, very closely following that, is opportunity for our athletes, and I want to make sure that we are giving the most amount of opportunity to the most amount of kids."

title: Queen Anne's County High School Gets School Security Grant
author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's County High School gets school security grant

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 308
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Queen Anne's County High School has recently been awarded $70,000 to pursue the hiring of the district's first School Security Employee (SSE), according to Joe Saboury, coordinator of school safety and security.As of August, the district received funding from the Maryland Center for School Safety School Resource Officer (SRO) Adequate Coverage Grant under the 2018 Maryland Safe to Learn Act, Saboury said.
This funding allows school districts to hire an employee to serve as a supplement to the SRO already in place, he said. Resource officers already serving the school district fall under the direction and budget of the county sheriff's office.
The statewide grant funding assists in supplementing law enforcement coverage for public schools with $10 to 15 million in FY26 and $20 million in FY27 and each year thereafter, he said.
As school security is considered a top state priority, a minimum three years of funding following this year is secured, according to Saboury.
"So really that's putting additional eyes and ears in our schools, which is a wonderful thing," he said.
As a member of the district, the SSE works more closely with school leaders on safety measures, often outside law enforcement scopes, and are more closely involved with student behavior, support and providing intervention to mitigate and prevent harm, he said.
As district employees, QACPS has the flexibility to utilize SSEs for after school sporting events or field trips Saboury said.
"It's a great resource that the school district has never had before," he said.
SSEs are held to the same standards and certification programs through the Maryland for School Safety Model training as SROs.
Training, uniforms, equipment and overtime are all budgeted into the grant with no cost the district, he said.
With the potential for increased funding down the road, Saboury was hopeful to be able to build the program and continually create a safe learning environment for students.

title: Easton Middle to Pilot Cell Phone Pouches in December
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Easton Middle to pilot cell phone pouches in December

 October 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 585
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County Public Schools is following the lead of other school districts across the nation and on the Mid-Shore in implementing student cell phone restrictions.Beginning Dec. 2, Easton Middle School will act as the pilot for the district, implementing a cell phone pouch system in which students must lock their phones in pouches during the school day.
Helga Einhorn, TCPS assistant superintendent for school leadership and student success, outlined the pilot plan to Talbot Board of Education members during a Monday work session.
"It should not be a battle in the classroom that our teachers have to engage in to monitor cell phone use, because that takes (away) their time and their expertise in instructing our students," Einhorn said. " … Cell phones seem to be one of the things that is the most problematic to enforce in our schools."
Einhorn noted the work of administrators and staff to research the impacts of cell phone use during school, as well as surveys collected to gauge parent and staff opinions on cell phone usage.
She said surveys conducted by the district showed 94% of parents/guardians and 96% of staff said there should be restrictions on cell phone use during the school day. 90% of parents/guardians and 95% of staff said students should not be allowed to have their phones "visible and usable" during class instruction.
Talbot County is engaging with the company Yondr, also used by the neighboring Caroline and Dorchester county districts, to provide the pouches.
The pouches will be assigned to each student at Easton Middle. Upon entering the school, students will place their phones in the pouches and use a Yondr magnet to lock the pouch. During dismissal, students will use the same magnetic device to unlock the pouches and retrieve their phones.
Einhorn said the district has talked to Yondr representatives about ensuring there are enough magnets in case of an emergency.
"They've been able to share with us some best practices, which include how many magnets you would need per student in the building to be able to effectively and efficiently get students out at the end of the day," Einhorn said.
Like Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons said prior to his district's rollout, Einhorn emphasized that cell phones can be a distraction during emergencies.
"We've had conversations and heard from national experts that during a real school emergency, it is actually greater safety risk for 800 students to be pulling out their phones and making phone calls instead of listening to the directions that will help keep them safe," she told board members.
Debbie Gardner, director of communications for Talbot County Public Schools, said each pouch costs about $27. In all, 975 pouches were purchased for a total just below $27,000, "paid for from the local FY24 materials of instruction budget," Gardner said.
Board Vice President Candace Henry asked how long it will take students to put their phones in pouches and retrieve them at the beginning and end of each day. Einhorn and Pepukayi said they expect it will take some time at first but that the process should become simple and streamlined over time.
Easton Middle families will receive more details from the district about the pouch program later this week, and a presentation will be given to students on Friday.
Board Member Deborah Bridges inquired if the pilot program may extend to other schools in the district this year if it is deemed successful.
"I do think we will need to see at least this year what our data is telling us about the impact," Einhorn said.

title: Karla Wieland-Cherry
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Karla Wieland-Cherry

 October 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 536
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Karla Wieland-Cherry, 55, is a resident of Trappe and is running for the District 5 seat on the Board of Education.She is a registered nurse and an associate real estate broker. She volunteers with many local organizations. Wieland-Cherry said she grew up in a home that kept up with and often interacted with politics, both local and national. She is married and has two children.
Why are you running for office?
I am running for the Talbot County Board of Education to work to improve our local school system for students, parents and our community.
Goals I hope to achieve will be to improve test scores by enticing more qualified teachers to teach in Talbot County and retaining current teachers; raising education benchmark standards; increase use of CTE programs; improve student discipline rules; improve school safety measures; improve open communication transparency between schools, teachers, administration and parents and the community.
What are your priorities if elected?
After speaking with teachers in different grades at local schools, the constant concern I hear is the lack of student discipline and their safety as teachers. Teachers can't teach and students can't learn… and test scores can't improve… and teachers won't want to come teach in a county… if they are in an environment where everyone feels unsafe.
Teachers have a distrust of the current board and feel that they don't listen to them and take their concerns seriously. I want to rebuild that trust by listening to teacher concerns and addressing those in a more supportive manner to make necessary changes.
What is the most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools faces and how do you think the board needs to address it?
Lack of teachers and staff seems to be the biggest issue. As I mentioned already in the prior questions, my priority will be to listen to teachers and rebuild the trust that is currently missing with the present board.
I will also work to improve communication between schools, teachers, parents and the community and work to create a more secure learning environment for everyone.
Talbot County residents have been receiving postcards in the mail criticizing education in the county. What are your thoughts on the postcards and how should these concerns be addressed?
Everyone should take their own initiative to investigate local school data from reliable resources. These postcards are one way of bringing awareness to the community and open communication channels amongst parents, teachers, administration and the board to ask questions about their authenticity.
In speaking with many parents of all grade levels of students, I consistently hear that there is no open communication, especially with the current board.
What are your thoughts on the Blueprint For Maryland's Future? What concerns or benefits do you see?
Teachers I've spoken with are frustrated and don't know Blueprint well, and what they do know is vague with no clear guidelines to how it's implemented. Funding Blueprint is based on inequities of and poverty levels of students for priority funding. Blueprint prioritizes equity learning.
We need to recognize every student's individuality and work to strengthen those individual skills for college/career readiness. We need to stop looking at certain groups as "minorities" and overlooking their skills as worthy individuals capable of learning instead of trying to make everyone "equal" to someone else.

We are making gains in our school district, and I want to continue to ensure that our students and teachers have access to high quality instructional materials that will have an impact on student achievement and success.
What are your priorities if elected?
My priorities align with the goals set by the members of the Board of Education and the superintendent, Dr. (Shraron) Pepukayi. My two main areas of focus are increasing student achievement in the areas of mathematics and reading, and recruiting and retaining quality teachers.
Having teachers that provide outstanding instruction to our students will ensure that our students will be academically successful.
What is the most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools faces, and how do you think the board needs to address it?
The most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools face right now is providing exceptional education opportunities for all students while being fiscally responsible.
Currently, the curriculum coordinating committee has brought high quality resources to the board for approval in the areas of reading and mathematics. These resources are paid for through educational grants. Utilizing grants is a responsible way of ensuring that we are providing our students with high quality instructional materials while being fiscally responsible.
Talbot County residents have been receiving postcards in the mail criticizing education in the county. What are your thoughts on the postcards and how should these concerns be addressed?
The postcards that have been mailed out focused on student test scores as well as other concerns. In terms of student test scores, we have purchased new high quality instructional materials. Our 2024 data reflects growth in all subgroups as well as certain subject areas and grades.
Student test scores are not just a concern for our district but across the State. Through the Governance and Accountability pillar of the Blueprint, expert review teams will be visiting schools across the state to review literacy and mathematics instruction in our classrooms and provide quality feedback for improvement.
What are your thoughts on the Blueprint For Maryland's Future? What concerns or benefits do you see?
I believe that the pillars of the Blueprint reflect the areas that all Maryland Schools want to address. Those pillars address early childhood education, high quality and diverse teachers, college and career readiness, more resources for students to be successful, and governance and accountability.
The Blueprint identifies and prioritizes the needs that we see in our district and across the state. In order for our students to be college and career ready by 10th grade, we need to start addressing their needs in pre-Kindergarten and ensure that they are receiving the resources they need to be successful in every grade.

title: Cynthia Marrah Jurrius
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Cynthia Marrah Jurris, 65, lives in Easton. She practices mediation law and is a director of conflict resolution programs. She is married and has three sons, all of whom graduated from Talbot County Public Schools.She is running for the District 6 seat on the Board of Education.
Why are you running for office?
Our public schools play a pivotal role in shaping our community's future, and we need board members who can help move (Talbot County Public Schools) forward to excellence. With a background in mediation and youth, school, family and community conflict resolution, I listen to all perspectives and value the richness in diversity of opinion.
I am a collaborative problem solver, skilled at helping people work together to solve complex community challenges. I want to ensure that our board continues to function effectively, advancing schools where every student can thrive. We have many strengths on which to build; together, we can solve any challenge.
What are your priorities if elected?
My priorities are interrelated: fostering academic excellence, supporting educators and creating a thriving school environment. I am committed to advancing student mastery of essential skills, improving academic proficiency and preparing students for college and careers.
Ensuring we recruit, retain and support outstanding teachers is key to this vision. Equally important is providing a positive, safe, effective and inclusive school climate where all learners can succeed and promoting strong family and student engagement to build a collaborative, supportive community around our schools. Together, these priorities create the foundation for a bright future for our students.
What is the most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools faces and how do you think the board needs to address it?
Advancing academic proficiency is a priority. Supporting a positive, safe, effective and inclusive learning environment is fundamental for student success, as well as teacher retention. Finding innovative ways to engage families, including non-English speakers, and students will support all aspects of student success.
The current board and superintendent are making progress toward addressing these issues despite many challenges, such as the COVID-19 learning gap. Through additional instructional support, expanding use of innovative community partnerships, strategic use of technology, targeted allocation of resources and engaging all sectors of our community, we can accelerate progress in these areas.
Talbot County residents have been receiving postcards in the mail criticizing education in the county. What are your thoughts on the postcards and how should these concerns be addressed?
I would like to see the sender of the mailers come forward for productive and honest dialogue. While improving academic proficiency is essential, the harmful attacks on our teachers, fueled by misleading and inflammatory rhetoric, seem aimed at undermining our public schools and inciting fear.
I would welcome an open, honest conversation about what this group seeks to accomplish, with accurate, relevant information. Let's work together to lift our Talbot County Public Schools to be the vibrant foundation of our community, where education is valued, everyone can belong and our teachers receive the support they need and deserve.
What are your thoughts on the Blueprint for Maryland's Future? What concerns or benefits do you see?
The creation of the Blueprint was the result of a comprehensive effort with input from many stakeholders. The five pillars are: Early Childhood Education; High Quality and Diverse Teachers and Leaders; College and Career Readiness; More Resources for Student Success; and Governance and Accountability.
The TCPS team has a detailed plan for managing the Blueprint and provides regular reports on progress for public view. There are many areas of the Blueprint that are positive, however, the most challenging aspects are mandates without sufficient funding. I support continued efforts to address the funding formula as it has been applied to Talbot County.

title: Ann O'Connor
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Ann O'Connor

 October 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Ann Oconnor

 Ann O'Connor, 55, is a resident of Easton. She is running for the District 2 seat on the Talbot County Board of Education.She is a former teacher and has six children.
Why are you running for office?
I am running for the school board because I am deeply passionate about children's education. As a former teacher and mother of six, I have dedicated my career to helping children reach their highest potential.
Having witnessed my six children go through (Talbot County Public School), I have observed a decline in academic rigor, expectations and accountability, both in behavior and academics. This experience drives my desire to make meaningful changes on the school board. The fact that our students are scoring 18% proficient in math and 55% in reading indicates a pressing need for new perspectives on our educational strategies.
What are your priorities if elected?
My priorities are the ABCs of education: advancing academics, boosting accountability and cultivating character. The focus is on the whole child. We cannot advance academics without discipline.
When students develop self-discipline, good character naturally emerges. This requires daily practice and consistent reinforcement of rules and clear expectations for all students across all buildings. Disruptive behavior must be addressed promptly and effectively.
Regarding academic accountability: A 95% graduation rate when less than ¼ of our students are proficient in math skills, and less than ½ are reading on grade level is inconsistent — something is broken here and we need to fix it.
What is the most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools faces and how do you think the board needs to address it?
The most important issue is the steady decline of academic rigor. We need to make sure we continue to implement early intervention in elementary schools to support those who need that extra push. It's essential to send home books and ensure that our children have access to/and are accountable for reading materials throughout elementary, middle and high school.
We should place greater emphasis on traditional learning — using pencils and paper, cursive writing, fostering reading and critical thinking skills, while reducing reliance on computers. We need to offer pathways for middle school students interested in college or the workforce, including advanced/honors classes.
Talbot County residents have been receiving postcards in the mail criticizing education in the county. What are your thoughts on the postcards and how should these concerns be addressed?
The postcards received in the mail are snapshots of where our schools stand. No one wants these scores, they are abysmal. It's a wake up call to attack the problem and change the way we have been doing education here in Talbot County.
We need to put our focus on reading, writing and math. Our students are distracted. Let's eliminate anything that detracts from our mission as educators and focus on what truly matters — educating the child. Let's get back to basics with my ABCs of education.
What are your thoughts on the Blueprint For Maryland's Future? What concerns or benefits do you see?
Simply changing a name doesn't lead to improvement. Over the last two decades, this initiative has gone through four name changes. Although there are many wonderful proposals in the Blueprint, I don't believe that top-down programs created by education experts would make our local schools better.
The Blueprint is a blanket principle mandated for all 24 counties in Maryland. The counties have no say in how it is implemented. It removes the schools from the control of locally elected school boards and puts control in the hands of unelected officials. I believe we want control over our local schools.

title: Candace Henry
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado

Candace Henry

 Candace Henry, 43, currently serves as the Talbot County Board of Education member for District 2 and is running for reelection. She lives in Easton with her family of four.Henry is the director of the Disability Resource Center at Salisbury University.
Why are you running for office?
I am running for reelection to the Board of Education to ensure that every student, regardless of ability, background or language, has equal access to quality education. My focus on accessibility, equity and belonging stems from a commitment to create inclusive learning environments where all students feel valued and supported.
I believe in breaking down barriers to success, advocating for diverse voices and fostering a sense of community in our schools. By addressing the unique needs of all learners, I aim to promote educational outcomes that empower every student to reach their full potential.
What are your priorities if elected?
My priorities are consistent with TCPS' current philosophy of "transforming and performing." I want the public to know that the Board of Education operates as a collective and is not driven by individual agendas.
I am committed to the collective goals to prioritize narrowing and closing the opportunity and achievement gaps, eliminating barriers to education, recruiting and retaining high-quality educators, enhancing special education services, continuous improvement in reading and math proficiency, enhancing our summer school offerings, and early access to college preparatory, dual enrollment, and CTE programs.
What is the most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools faces and how do you think the board needs to address it?
The most important issue facing (Talbot County Public Schools) is the opportunity gap, which directly affects reading and math proficiency for all students. To address this, the board must continue to prioritize equitable distribution of resources, ensuring that schools serving higher-need populations have access to targeted interventions.
Simultaneously, recruiting and retaining high-quality educators is vital, as teachers are the foundation of student success. By investing in professional development and creating supportive environments for educators, we can close the opportunity gap and improve outcomes and opportunities for all students.
Talbot County residents have been receiving postcards in the mail criticizing education in the county. What are your thoughts on the postcards and how should these concerns be addressed?
The postcards critical of Talbot County's education system are deeply troubling because they disparage the hard work of our educators. Much of the content includes outdated and inaccurate information, which undermines trust in our schools and the dedicated professionals working to support our students.
These types of messages are circulated with the intent to create division rather than foster productive dialogue. To address these concerns, we must continue to engage the community in open discussion, lead with facts — highlighting the progress being made and the work that still needs to be done, all while celebrating the efforts of our educators.
What are your thoughts on the Blueprint For Maryland's Future? What concerns or benefits do you see?
The Blueprint for Maryland's Future presents significant benefits by prioritizing equity, early childhood education and career readiness, which can help close the opportunity gap and enhance student success. It also aims to improve educator salaries and professional development, which are crucial for recruiting and retaining high-quality teachers.
My concern is ensuring that the funding remains sustainable and that implementation is equitable, especially for rural areas like Talbot County. It's essential that all schools receive the resources needed to meet these ambitious goals, with careful oversight to ensure progress and accountability across the state.

 Kerry Gunshenan is a regional sales director for Evoke Pharma. She lives in Easton and has served as chairman of the Talbot County Public Schools Advisory Council representing St. Michaels Elementary School and St. Michales Middle and Hight School. She has also served as president of the Advisory Board for St. Michaels YMCA.She has been married for 22 years and has five children ranging from 14 to 20 years old. She is running for the District 6 seat on the Board of Education.
Why are you running for office?
I'm running for office because I have seen a decline in education since my oldest child started in (Talbot County Public Schools). I believe all our children deserve better. No one is going to care more or be more passionate about solving issues that face our schools today than a mother with four children in the system. I care deeply about our schools, I pay attention, and I love our community. I'm a mom who wants to prioritize education and improve outcomes.
What are your priorities if elected?
My top priority is to ensure all students are college or career ready by the time they graduate. I want to see all students obtain critical thinking and problem-solving skills. Additionally, it's important for students to have personal responsibility, financial literacy, strong communication, and respect for themselves and others. With the combination of these skills, our children will have a bright future.
What is the most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools faces and how do you think the board needs to address it?
Candidate choose not to answer.
Talbot County residents have been receiving postcards in the mail criticizing education in the county. What are your thoughts on the postcards and how should these concerns be addressed?

 Colonel Richardson Middle School hosted this year's Homegrown School Lunch Week, a statewide initiative that showcases local farms and produce, along with dishes prepared by culinary school students at Caroline Career and Technology.Students, staff and guests tasted samples of everything from farm-to-tray pork to fresh applesauce, all made locally.
Farm to School tastings, facilitated by Caroline County Future Farmers of America students, CCTC Culinary students, and Food Services staff, included:
Zucchini bread made by Shore Gourmet using zucchini from Bartenfelder Farms. Bartenfelder Farms staff also assisted during the events.Maryland crab soup made by the Chesapeake Culinary Center using crab meat from JM Clayton Seafood in Cambridge.Watermelon slushie made by CCTC culinary students using watermelons from Bartenfelder Farms and Little Wagon Produce.Scrapple made by CCTC culinary students. Pigs were raised by CCTC Agriculture students and processed by Sudlersville Meat Market.Applesauce made by CCTC culinary students with apples from Blades Orchard.Cheddar cheese from Chapel Cheese.
Date Caramel dip made by Choptank Community Health served with Redemption Farms apples. Choptank Community Health attended the event as well.
Sliced cucumbers with ranch dip from Clayton Farms.Apple cider from Redemption Rarms.Hydroponics herbs from Red Acres. They also attended with a display showing how hydroponics are grown.Raspberry Yogurt from Nice Farms.
Students, staff and guests also enjoyed a farm-to-table lunch prepared by the Colonel Richardson Middle School Food Services team, which included cherry tomatoes, cucumbers and corn on the cob from Clayton Farms, apples from Blades Orchard, lettuce from Red Acres, bison burgers from Bow Tie Farms and catfish cakes from Tilghman Island Seafood. This menu was also served in all school cafeterias this week.
Simmons said, "Our Food Services staff have always understood the value of serving homegrown, fresh food that supports the health of our students and also supports our farming community. We are are privileged to benefit from our rich agricultural history and the thriving industry that exists today."
Guests at the event included Board of Education Members Chrissy Bartz, Troy Plutschak and Michele Wayman; Superintendent Derek Simmons; Cassie Shirk and Karen Fedor from the Maryland Department of Agriculture; Julie Fletcher from the Maryland State Department of Education Office of School and Community Nutrition Program; Megan D'Arcy from the Rural Maryland Council; and Madison Bryce, intergovernmental affairs liaison with Gov.
