title: Eastern Shore Delegation to Ask Governor for Cade Formula Restoration
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Eastern Shore Delegation to ask governor for Cade formula restoration

 January 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: General Assembly 
 
 482
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — At a meeting Friday, the Eastern Shore Delegation voted to send a letter to the governor's office asking that the Cade Funding Formula for community colleges be restored in a supplemental budget.Gov. Wes Moore's proposed fiscal year 2025 budget calls for the reduction of $22 million in Cade formula funding to community colleges in the state.
The Cade formula essentially ties state funding for community colleges to state funding for designated University System of Maryland institutions, according to the Maryland Association of Community Colleges.
Moore's proposal would reduce the Cade formula from 29% to 26.5%.
That percentage — the amount of funding community colleges receive from the state — is based on the funding given to public four-year institutions per full-time equivalent student.
At the Eastern Shore Delegation meeting, legislators were joined by the presidents of colleges that are located on the Eastern Shore, as well as MACC Executive Director Brad Phillips.
Phillips called rebasing the Cade formula a "budget word" for inequity.
"Look at it this way," he said. "If you're giving a student a dollar to go to a University System of Maryland or a four-year public institution, the policy goal is that 29 cents goes to community colleges. ... (with the reduction,) you're cutting community colleges out. You're still providing a dollar to our four-year friends."
Wor-Wic Community College President Deborah Casey told the delegation she had spent hours preparing a budget with an 11% cut.
"That's $1.5 million for Wor-Wic Community College," she said of the budget cut. "That doesn't work for us."
Casey said that she can't build infrastructure and carry Wor-Wic in the best direction with a budget reduction of this magnitude.
"And you're expecting and asking us, and holding us accountable to making sure we're meeting many needs of this community," she said. "Please help us get that full funding."
Phillips said Maryland's community colleges are up 8.3% in enrollment this year.
"So this is a cut that would actually stretch less funding to more students," he said.
During the meeting, both Casey and Chesapeake College President Cliff Coppersmith mentioned increases in enrollment at their schools.
Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-Dorchester, Wicomico) said this increased enrollment is one reason why this formula change is concerning.
Del. Jefferson Ghrist (R-36, Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline), who made the motion to send the letter, said the Maryland Department of Legislative Services had given the House Appropriations Committee, which he is a member of, a list of possible cuts that could be made in order to restore the Cade formula to 29%.
"There's a lot of places that we can go to find money to restore that," he said.
Ghrist said getting the Cade formula restored in a supplemental budget, however, would make the job of the House Appropriations Committee easier.
"That way it'll be done before we start really getting down to work on the budget," he said. "That would make our jobs a heck of a lot easier on the committee."

title: Superintendent Shares Schools' Budget Constraints with Commissioners
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Superintendent shares schools' budget constraints with Commissioners

 January 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 512
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline County Public Schools officials shared good news and bad news with the Caroline County Commissioners at a Jan. 16 meeting.The good news: Caroline County Public Schools ended the year with a $3.25 million surplus.
The not-so-good news: The Blueprint for Maryland's Future unfunded mandate puts the fiscal squeeze on the budget and pandemic-based grant funding disappears in fiscal year 2025, officials said.
Chief Finance Officer Erin Thornton and Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons shared with the commissioners what they need to prepare for as the school district's budget planning continues.
"We have always been good stewards of the money and we're fiscally conservative, trying not to just spend money just to spend it, so we were prepared to end the year with money on the books," Thornton said.
The unassigned fund balance is currently at $9.5 million, "which is approximately 8.4% of our current operating budget," she said. "Our target range for a fund balance is one to 10%. So, we are approaching a high, which is where we want to be."
Commissioner Frank Bartz asked about maintaining support services salaries, something that he said is not addressed in the Blueprint.
"A lot of people in the county work for support services," he said. "I just want to make sure that they're taken care of."
"You're spot on," Simmons said. "The Blueprint addresses teachers only and leaves out two-thirds of our workgroup, and (it) does not take into consideration any support staff or administration. Required increases to salaries are … for the most part, to classroom-based teachers with kids on the workload."
Simmons said the Supportive Services Association is a negotiated employee group.
"Their contract was ratified to be closed from 2012 until next year, so that has been a closed contract with a required 1% in step every year, and then it's 1% in addition to whatever the teachers get. Their contract comes open next year for us to negotiate."
Simmons said the "biggest challenge that we're going to see this year" is the Blueprint formula's increase of 1.7% over last year's budget "when inflation is currently still running over 3%, and that factors in no increases in health insurance, which is probably 5% to 7% right now, we're hearing."
That percentage does not factor in any pay increase. Blueprint requires first-year classroom teachers to be earning $60,000 by fiscal year 2027.
"After this year, the budget increases roughly 5%," Simmons said. "We're sitting in a different position in our county than some of our colleagues are in others. … A lot of the larger systems are looking at significant cuts of teaching positions because (of) that 1.7% increase. It's a regressive budget no matter how you cut it, when it's only that much of an increase, and the cost of living is definitely a lot higher."
When COVID funding and (Maryland) Leads funding "dries up in September at the same time as we're getting a 1.7% increase, that's the perfect storm," Simmons said. "And again, we'll weather it for our staff. We'll figure it out. I really, truly believe we will. It's just going to be a really tough year."

title: Moore Says Budget Will Balance, Protect School Funding
author: Kiersten Hacker Capital News Service
content:
Moore says budget will balance, protect school funding

 January 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KIERSTEN HACKER Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 930
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Gov. Wes Moore unveiled a budget proposal on Wednesday that would balance the books and protect the state's ambitious reform plan for Maryland public schools, without raising taxes in the fiscal year that begins in July.The $63.1 billion plan would balance the books where officials had projected a shortfall, in part by returning some programs to spending levels closer to those of the pre-pandemic era. The plan proposes leveraging state debt and dipping into rainy day funds.
The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's sweeping education plan of 2021, will be fully funded, state budget officials said Wednesday. Moore, a Democrat, said his administration crafted the budget plan in partnership with lawmakers, community leaders and other "village elders."
"We wanted to make sure that this proposed budget had everyone's fingerprints on it," Moore said in his public announcement of the new plan. "Because this budget is not just a reflection of an administration. This budget is a reflection of our shared aspiration."
Those aspirations will now go to the Maryland General Assembly for debate. Lawmakers have set a target of early April for passing a budget, and the state Constitution requires that it be balanced.
But the joint Republican Caucus will look closely at where funding transfers in the proposed budget are coming from, House Minority Leader Jason Buckel, R-Allegany, told Capital News Service.
While he said he is pleased that the Moore administration kept total spending similar to that of years past, he expressed concerns about the possibility of fees for certain businesses or tax hikes down the road. Buckel said he'll keep worrying about that possibility until the legislature adjourns.
"All in all, it's a mixed bag, I think, and we'll look forward to working with the governor and working with the Democratic leadership here to try to make the budget as good as possible," Buckel said.
Senate Minority Leader Stephen Hershey suggested he worries about the possibility of fee increases down the road.
"While it is a relief that the governor's budget spends less than last year and does not raise taxes, the number of fee increases proposed by his administration through legislation and the regulatory process is concerning," said Hershey, a Republican representing Kent, Cecil, Queen Anne's and Caroline, in an email release. He and other Republicans contend fee hikes are coming through the administrative pipeline.
"Taxes aren't the only way to raise revenue," Hershey said, "and state government should not be in the business of nickel and diming Maryland's families and small businesses."
The only fee increases currently in the budget plan are in the Department of the Environment, and those would generate roughly $3.5 million in revenue, according to a spokesman for the governor's office.
Working together to approve a balanced budget had been shaping up as no easy task. The state's spending had been projected to outpace revenues starting in the coming fiscal year, according to a recent report from the Department of Legislative Services.
But Moore has now proposed a plan that would instead balance the 2025 budget, saying it is a step in the right direction toward addressing the state's structural deficit in the years beyond that.
His budget flips the expected cash shortfall of $1.1 billion to a positive cash balance of $103 million in fiscal 2025, according to Helene Grady, Maryland's secretary of budget and management.
Moore said his budget prioritizes public safety, affordable housing, child care, education and public service. It also raises pay for state employees.
"We know that budgets, they're moral documents," Moore said. "Where we choose to invest actually defines our values. And it dictates the course of our future."
State budget officials said they avoided wide-ranging cuts across the board, hiring freezes or salary freezes. Rather, state agency heads went through an intense process and found areas to trim, and several agency budgets will be lower this year than they were the year before.
Moore said he proposed a record $127 million for local police agencies, citing the importance of supporting law enforcement and getting "more boots on the ground" to solve crimes and keep repeat offenders off the streets. Other investments would go toward the prevention of gun violence and support for crime victims.
While addressing public safety, Moore acknowledged the debates about juvenile justice likely to come during the legislative session, announcing an increase in funding to the Department of Juvenile Services. He didn't specifically discuss any cuts made to juvenile services programs.
Affordable housing and child care would receive significant funding under the proposal. Those are two areas Moore claimed are the biggest strains on Maryland residents. Access to housing and child care allow for increased participation in the workforce as Maryland tries to grow its economy, he argued.
"Access to child care doesn't just affect your child and your family," Moore said. "It changes the trajectory of our state's fiscal health."
Options for job training in innovative industries and public service were a priority. Through Moore's budget, the state is on track to increase the number of Service Year Option and Maryland Corps participants to 500, as required by law.
The Blueprint for Maryland's Future will be fully funded in the coming fiscal year, budget officials said, but its money problems are far from resolved. Prior to the beginning of the legislative session, the Department of Legislative Services report projected the state would exhaust the Blueprint balance in fiscal 2027.
"It's not inaccurate to say, 'Hey, we funded the Blueprint, or at least the state's portion of the Blueprint, for today,'" Buckel said. "But I also think it's completely honest to say the blueprint looming large over the next four or five years, blows billion-dollar holes into our state budget."

title: Blueprint Pillar Chairs Share Caroline's Progress
author: Connie Connolly
content:
DENTON — At the Jan. 9 meeting of the Caroline County Board of Education, several supervisors provided updates on progress towards meeting requirements of the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, a set of policies and dedicated funding seeking to transform several aspects of the state's public education system by 2026.Assistant Superintendent Dr. Tara Downes said the district has been receiving additional guidance from the Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) and Accountability and Implementation Board (AIB) since spring 2023.
As a result, required tasks have been "chunked out" over a more manageable timeline, and the pillar chairs are "actually ahead of schedule" with some aspects of the plan.
"The pillar chairs have been phenomenal in being proactive when it comes to the work," Downes said.
According to its website, "The Blueprint for Maryland's Future was passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021 to transform public education in the state into a world-class education system. The Blueprint will increase education funding by $3.8 billion each year over the next 10 years, enrich student experiences and accelerate student outcomes, as well as improve the quality of education for all children in Maryland, especially those who have been historically underserved."
"The Blueprint really involves everything that we're doing on a daily basis," said Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons.
According to the Blueprint website, "The bold work of the Blueprint for Maryland's Future is organized into five distinct pillars." Each pillar has a set of objectives to help administrators and educators align instruction and community support to them and determine needed resources.
Pillar 1: Early Childhood Education
The main focus of Pillar 1 is the expansion of pre-kindergarten for three-year-olds and four-year-olds, said CCPS Supervisor of Instruction Elizabeth Saylor, who serves as Pillar 1 chair.
Of the 375 pre-K students enrolled as of Sept. 30, 58 are in pre-K three and 317 are in pre-K four. The main focus currently are Tier One families who are "up to 300% of the federal poverty level, or 319 students. As of Jan. 9, 395 students were enrolled in pre-K," Saylor said.
A challenge is the need for private daycare providers, who must follow Blueprint's criteria. Providing more qualified and more certified staff is another challenge both for Pillar 1 compliance and workforce development, an objective of Pillar 2.
"Making sure families and students are ready for kindergarten" is ultimately the focus of the pillar, Saylor said.
Pillar 2: High Quality and Diverse Teachers and Leaders
CCPS Supervisor of Human Resources Dr. Rob Willoughby addressed four objectives of Pillar 2, which focuses on the recruitment of high quality and diverse teachers and leaders.
Chesapeake College has been "a fantastic partner with us through the Maryland Leads" grant initiative, he said. The district recently signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Mount St. Mary's University, which offers a fully online bachelor's degree in elementary education.
Willoughby's group is looking at other ways of providing staff and enhancing qualifications, including encouraging National Board Certified Teacher credentialing.
Forty-eight teachers are currently in the process of pursuing that certification. "That is 10% of our teaching staff pursuing a really rigorous national certification," he said.
A Pillar 2 challenge includes a starting teacher salary of $60,000 by Blueprint's July 1, 2026, deadline.
"Our starting teacher salary this year $53,167, and … we're about $6,800 to the end," Willoughby said. "If you divide that over the three fiscal years we have, that means it needs to go up at least $2,278 (per year)."
Pillar 3: College and Career Readiness
Blueprint's third pillar focuses on students' college and career readiness.
College and Career Readiness Director Lindsey McCormick explained the progress being made towards complying with Pillar 3 of the Blueprint as the district works under interim standards. Students are assessed at the end of their 10th grade year and can choose a career pathway. The district offers 16 Career and Technology Education (CTE) pathways.
In addition to pursuing a college track and taking advanced placement courses, students can receive career counseling. Students in AP courses are now required to sit for the exams in the spring; the tests are paid for by the district.
"I am very pleased to say that this year through our MOU with the (Upper Shore) Workforce Investment Board, we have added one high school and one middle school career coach that are in the buildings five days a week working with students," McCormick said.
She said the district is growing the youth apprenticeship program and modeling it for businesses.
If students are not college and career ready, the district is working on a pilot program to provide supports, including online study, to help them meet state standards, McCormick said. Chesapeake College supplied data from the past three years that showed students' learning online was just as successful as classroom learning.
Pillar 4: More Resources to Ensure that All Students are Successful
Pillar 4 of Blueprint seeks to provide students with more resources that could help them succeed.
Supervisor of Instruction Christal Harkowa, one of the co-chairs for Pillar 4, updated the school board on multilingual learners.
The district has hired two multilingual learner family coordinators to work with Spanish- and Haitian Creole-speaking constituents.
"We have really been able to improve our communication with our families," Harkowa said. "They are very dedicated; they stay after (school), they attend all kinds of after school events, parent conferences when we need them for 504 or IEP (Individualized Education Program) meetings to make sure our parents understand what the needs of their students are and to be able to advocate and ask questions."
She said her goal by the end of this school year is to "identify MLL families for parent leadership opportunities."
To support MLLs in instruction and language acquisition, the district is providing ongoing professional development for teachers and instructional assistants while "being respectful of their planning time," Harkowa said. Another focus is helping students develop English proficiency in elementary school.
Supervisor of Special Education Erica McDonald discussed the objective of closing the achievement gap for students with disabilities.
The leadership team created a mission statement at the beginning of the current school year, provided Goalbook toolkit training and additional training to help teachers and co-teachers meet objectives and monitor "disproportionate identification and disciplinary practices."
"Our special education teacher specialists have really taken on the role of educational diagnosticians," she said.
A Blueprint objective is to "establish or enhance Community Schools in areas of concentrated poverty." Three CCPS schools — Federalsbury Elementary, Greensboro Elementary and Colonel Richardson Middle School — meet the criteria and have district coordinators assigned to them.
Supervisor of Student Services Nicole Fisher reported the Pillar 4 team is committed to evidence-based practices, but challenges facing the district are providing adequate behavioral health staffing and transportation.
Simmons said "As Blueprint ratchets up, all nine of our schools are going to qualify for Concentration of Poverty funding due to the FARMS (Free and Reduced-Price Meals) rates in all of our schools … in about another two or three years."
Pillar 5: Governance and Accountability
"Pillar 5 is what pulls together all of the other pillars," Simmons said, explaining that the pillar focuses on governance and accountability.
Two main areas of focus are the "stakeholder engagement plan" and Blueprint funding and resources which require "money following the students."
"Pillars 1 through 4 have done an incredible job of reaching out to community members, and they've got strong, robust teams that are getting lots of feedback," Simmons said, elaborating on the stakeholder engagement objective.
"There are shifts — monumental shifts in some areas — for the way that we're doing (Blueprint)," he said. "But eventually we'll stop talking about Blueprint, and we'll just be talking about what it is that we're doing that connects to the strategic plan, because the overlap will be there when it's closer to full implementation."

title: Superintendent of Schools to Retire in 2024
author: Staff Writer
content:
Superintendent of schools to retire in 2024

 January 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 987
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL — Superintendent of Kent County Public Schools, Dr. Karen Couch will be retiring at the end of the current school year, effective June 30. The announcement came at this month's Board of Education meeting. Board President Joe Goetz and Vice President Francoise Sullivan were re-elected to their positions during the Jan. 8 meeting as well.Couch said it has been an honor to collaborate with the exceptional team of administrators, teachers, staff and board members.
"Our collective commitment to the students and families of this county has been profound," Couch said. "Throughout my tenure, we achieved significant milestones, a testament to our collective dedication to excellence in education. This commitment consistently drove us to adapt and innovate, ensuring our students receive the best education possible."
Upon the delivery of Couch's announcement, Goetz, described the meeting as a "heavy night" with the weight of the superintendent's decision in the air.
"But you're not gone," Goetz told Dr. Couch. "And we'll have time to celebrate and we'll have time to reflect on where we've been and where we're going."
Goetz said everyone is a link in the chain driving KCPS, with many having come before them and more to follow. He said they will all do the best they can to continue providing students with a top-quality education.
"Working with you has been an absolute joy," Goetz said to Couch. "There's been a lot of ups and downs, but we'll celebrate all that as we move forward."
As a first step in the KCPS leadership transition, the Board of Education is holding a special meeting at 5:30 p.m. Tuesday, Jan. 23 to discuss the search for the next superintendent. The meeting will be held at the KCPS Administrative Building, 5608 Boundary Ave., Rock Hall.
Couch is retiring in the back half of her third four-year term as the superintendent of KCPS. Her most recent contract renewal was approved in the spring of 2021 for four years.
She first came on board at KCPS on July 1, 2013, having led a candidate field of nearly 20 applicants.
Couch was named the Maryland Superintendent of the Year in 2021. She made her mark on KCPS early, launching a technological revolution by bringing computers and smartboards into classrooms, greatly expanding teachers' and students' access to educational resources.
She built a collaborative environment in schools through fostering professional learning communities, which brought teachers together to share best practices to help reach all students.
She also made KCPS one of the first school systems in Maryland to adopt universal all-day prekindergarten, giving children an important head start on their education. "Amidst numerous budgetary challenges, including declining enrollment and limited resources,
we remained committed to prioritizing organizational improvements and addressing the diverse needs of our students and staff," Couch said.
She improved the school buildings themselves through targeted renovations, enhanced safety features like security vestibules and launching the planning process for a new middle school.
"During my tenure, we also executed a comprehensive six-year Facilities Strategic Plan,
revitalizing educational facilities untouched for over 25 years," she said. "Moreover, we successfully fulfilled preliminary state requirements for the construction of a new middle school while advocating for legislation to increase state funding participation for the project."
Sullivan, praised Couch's professionalism in the face of myriad challenges including tight budgets, declining student enrollment and the COVID pandemic. "You have helped our schools accomplish so much in the time that you've been here and it hasn't been easy," Sullivan told Couch. "You have always been professional and represented our schools really well, and I can only imagine how tough that probably was for some things."
Hailing from New Mexico, Dr. Couch previously served from 2001 to 2013 as the superintendent of the Moriarty-Edgewood School District, about an hour east of Albuquerque. In 2010, she was honored as the New Mexico Superintendent of the Year.
Couch moved to Kent County with a reputation for having turned that rural school district into one of the top-achieving in the state through a focus of continuous school improvement and the incorporation of research-based education programming.
She has likewise implemented similar strategies at KCPS, increasing the visibility and participation in the Career and Technical Education (CTE) program at Kent County High School, encouraging the growth of Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) programs and training elementary school teachers in the renowned Orton-Gillingham method of English language arts instruction.
Trish McGee, the longest serving among the current Board of Education members, was first elected the year after Couch's hiring. McGee covered the search process that saw Dr. Couch come onboard as the associate editor of the Kent County News.
Speaking at the Jan. 8 Board meeting, McGee said Couch paid out of her own pocket for travel from New Mexico to Kent County for one of her first interview visits. McGee said that showed just how prepared Couch was willing to go the distance to address the challenges faced by KCPS.
"I think every decision she ever made personally and professionally was really about how to move our school district forward," McGee said. "And I can't think of a greater legacy than something like that."
Couch's tenure at KCPS caps off a career in education that began in 1980 when she became a kindergarten teacher in the Las Cruces Public Schools in southern New Mexico. She was then employed by the Alamogordo Public Schools and rose through the ranks in that district from teacher to principal and, ultimately associate superintendent.
Along the way, she earned her master's degree and later received her doctorate in educational administration from New Mexico State University.
Couch said she is confident that KCPS will continue to nurture and inspire every child who walks through its doors and she eagerly anticipates hearing all those future success stories.
"As I begin a new chapter, I know that our work has laid a strong foundation for continued student success," Couch said. "The legacy of our efforts is not in the programs we've started or the facilities we've renovated, but in the lives of the students we've touched."

title: Health department recommends making condoms available at local high school
author: LAURA TAYMAN
content:
Health department recommends making condoms available at local high school

 January 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LAURA TAYMAN | Section: News 
 
 643
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last month, Kent County Board of Education members were provided stark facts about the rise in sexually transmitted diseases (STD) in the community, the state, and the country at its recent monthly meeting.Ashley Minietta, communicable disease and family planning contact for the Kent County Department of Health, made a presentation to the board before the holiday break, saying the solution to reversing the trend is "to provide ground support, monitor trends, and turn data into action."
"While 20% of Marylanders have an STD, almost half of the cases are ages 15-24," Minietta said, citing the 2020 U.S. census map — putting Maryland in the South region of the country, "It's one of the highest rates in the region."
Minietta said the barriers to effectively preventing both STDs and teenage pregnancies in Kent County are lack of education, the cost of birth control, parental resistance to alternatives, lack of public transportation, the geographic barriers of the rural area and lack of health care options.
Teen pregnancy rates are down, Minietta said, because parents have been proactive with putting teenage daughters on birth control. But pills and IUDs do not allow the prevention of STDs that can lead to long-term health consequences.
"Research in 2020 shows only 9% of sexually active high school students used a condom," Minetta said. "That has only increased."
Minetta shared various ways local school systems are providing a condom availability program to meet the needs of their high school students, including those in Queen Anne's, Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot and Wicomico counties, and counties on the western shore.
While some have availability through the school's nurse's office, others provide a "brown bag" approach, where students can pick up a paper bag on an anonymous basis.
Board member Aretha Dorsey said that as a parent she was concerned that a program like that would encourage secrets among parents and their children.
"I feel like parents' rights are being taken away," Dorsey said. "I believe that kids might form a lack of respect for their parents and think they can do things their own way."
Board member Francois Sullivan said Kent County and its rural location is a valid argument for such a program.
"There is a difference between a nurse providing condoms and a cashier."
When asked to share her opinion, student board member Madison Messick said she couldn't even remember her sex education class.
"I think this is really important," she said. "There is a stigma. We can't go to Walgreens because we know the cashier. I know kids that would definitely benefit from this."
Vienna Walker, supervisor of student services for the Board, said she recommended the board adopt a policy where Kent County students can meet with a high school nurse and ask for information and guidance.
Superintendent Karen Couch said she had been asked by parents how students could be opted out of a program if they don't approve. Walker said she would need to check with the state's Department of Education to see how that could be handled.
"Some students have much more open communication with school nurses than their parents," Walker said. "Their office is much less threatening to students who then become comfortable enough to come back if they are not feeling great."
That is Walker's goal. She recommended the board consider approving a program that requires students to visit nurses who can provide education and guidance on condom use.
"Nurses also encourage students to be open and honest with their parents," Walker said.
Messick agreed.
"Students will participate not because kids don't trust their parents," she said. "The program encourages conversations between parents and their children. It's like therapy where they can't tell parents what their child is talking about. This actually helps to form a better relationship between students and parents."
School Board President Joe Goetz said he would like for Walker to get information from other districts on how they manage parent objections.
"I think real life examples would help," Goetz said.

title: TCPS Gives Update On Its Priorities At Board Meeting
author: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub. Com
content:
TCPS Gives Update On Its Priorities At Board Meeting

 December 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub. Com | Page: 2 | Section: News

 EASTON - At a Talbot County Board of Education meeting Wednesday, administrators gave an update on the school system's priorities.Talbot County Public Schools' three priorities, identified in the spring, are academic equity and achievement, fostering an engaging environment and hiring and retaining highly qualified and diverse staff.
Since sharing the priorities with the entire school system in August, Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said they have been working to "infuse" the priorities everywhere.
"In my roundtables, out in the community, in schools," she said. "We're constantly talking about those three priorities."
At the meeting, strategies and metrics associated with each priority were shared.
ACADEMIC EQUITY AND ACHIEVEMENT When it comes to academic equity and achievement, TCPS has six strategies, including implementing additional interventions for students in and outside the classroom, hiring additional math coaches and implementing more assessments to measure growth.
Assistant Superintendent for Curriculum and Instruction Helga Einhorn said that since improving math was identified as a priority by the board, the district has added the NWEA MAP Growth Assessment for mathematics.
"Prior to this year, we did not have a standardized assessment that would allow us to collect this type of data as we had with reading," Einhorn said. "We felt it was important, if we were going to make changes throughout the year, to progress monitor our students throughout the year."
Students in kindergarten through fifth grade took the beginning of the year MAP Growth Assessment for mathematics.
Einhorn said teachers were impressed with how well students performed.
Overall, 14% of those students were in the 80th percentile or higher, 19% were between the 61st and 80th percentile, 18% were between the 41st and 60th percentile, 21% were between the 21st and 40th percentile and 25% were between the 1st and 20th percentile.
Along with measuring growth through testing throughout the year, Einhorn said teachers are working very closely with the K-6 Math Curriculum Supervisor Daisy Bradwell.
"They are doing a deep dive into the curriculum," Einhorn said, adding that Bradwell is working with teachers to identify what things might be missing from the curriculum.
FOSTERING AN ENGAGING ENVIRONMENT Director of Student Services Darlene Spurrier started off her presentation by listing different strategies the district is employing to achieve fostering an engaging environment.
These strategies include school-based mental health services and substance abuse intervention and prevention; restorative practices training; and individual school wellness plans and wellness coaches.
"Many of (these strategies) are ongoing and will not ever really move to completed because they're things that we're just going to continue to do," she said.
When it came to data, Spurrier shared the results of three climate surveys - an internal survey from this year and the Maryland School Climate Surveys from last year and the year before that. Each of the surveys measure student and educator attitudes on four domains: community, environment, relationships and safety.
Comparing the student survey TCPS took this year to the state's survey from last year, within those four domains, students considered physical safety, physical environment and participation and engagement significantly better this year than the previous two years.
Comparing the teacher survey TCPS took this year to the state's survey from last year, teachers also ranked participation and engagement and physical safety significantly higher. They also ranked substance abuse higher than last year, meaning it is less of a concern in schools this year. Teachers ranked bullying lower on the scale this year compared to last year, meaning it is more of a concern.
HIGHLY QUALIFIED AND DIVERSE STAFF Assistant Superintendent for Administrative and Support Services Lynne Duncan presented data on new hires, recruitment and TCPS's Grow Your Own Teachers Scholarship Program.
Before she spoke, Pepukayi said that retaining, not just recruiting, is important to the district.
"With the shortages across our nation in education, we want to make sure the people who are here, we're tending to," she said.
According to Duncan's presentation, last school year, 197 out of 234 people, or 84%, accepted offers of employment.
This year, 90 out of 126 people, or 71%, accepted offers of employment.
Duncan said that, to date, four of those new hires this year have left employment.
In terms of demographics of new teaching staff this year, 32 teachers are white and two are Hawaiian.
TCPS attended seven recruitment fairs last school year. Duncan said it yielded one support staff employee.
The district plans to attend a total of eight recruiting events this school year. So far, it has visited three.
Of the five people enrolled in the district's Grow Your Own Teachers Scholarship Program last year, four have been hired. The program gives TCPS students enrolled in college a scholarship if they agree to teach in the district after they graduate. Duncan said that of the nine remaining students enrolled in the program, one will graduate this month, one will graduate in June of 2024, three will graduate in 2026 and four will graduate in 2027.
At the end of the meeting, board member Jymil Thompson said he could see that the administrative team has clear vision, alignment and transparency.
"I think you all do a fabulous, fabulous job of that," he said. "I want to see where the district's going to be in a couple years because I think it's definitely trickling in the right direction. So I'm anxious to be a part of that."

title: Superintendent Outlines Budget Priorities, Timeline
author: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub.Com
content:
Superintendent Outlines Budget Priorities, Timeline

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub.Com | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 785

 Read News Document

 DENTON - The conundrum of uncertain Blueprint demands coupled with a projected decrease in pandemic-related grant funding for Caroline County Public Schools is proving to be a challenge for Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons, school administrators and district staff as they build a budget for fiscal year 2025.And because the dilemma impacts the traditional budgeting timeline employed in previous years, at the Dec. 5 meeting of the Caroline County Board of Education, the Superintendent Simmons received more time to develop a more realistic budget.
The Board of Education approved Simmons's request to revise the traditional timeline and move his final budget proposal from February to April.
"We do not have a good idea of what state revenues look like until the General Assembly gets done doing their work, which is April," Simmons said.
While some demands of the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, a set of policies and spending for education in the state's public schools, are clear, others are still being modified. The "uncertainties" of the unfunded legislative mandate have created budgetary challenges for school administrators across the state.
One of the demands for school districts is funding dual enrollment for high school students who wish to take college courses. Blueprint's College and Career Readiness standards require school districts to pay for any student who meets the minimum requirements for dual enrollment. At roughly $1,000 per student per semester, CCPS spent $130,000 in 2023 for juniors and seniors to take courses at Chesapeake College. While "it's great for the kids," Simmons said, the Blueprint requirement presents a budget challenge.
Another "cost of doing Blueprint business" is meeting the mandated starting teacher salary of $60,000 by fiscal year 2027.
Grant funding "is kind of how Caroline County has survived," Simmons said.
But some of that funding will decrease or cease altogether in 2024.
Both American Rescue Plan and Maryland Leads grant funding will sunset in Sept. 2024. In addition, the funding formula for Blueprint shows a 1.7% increase in state funding from last year, the lowest per year increase in the formula, Simmons said.
The CCPS budget, typical of school systems across the state is 80% people, Simmons said.
"The rule of thumb is anywhere between 80% to 90% of your budget is people, and when you take people out and you take out paying for your electric and your fuel and heating your buildings and running your buses and those sorts of things, you're probably left with somewhere between the neighborhood of 5% to 7% every year that truly is discretionary," Simmons said.
And while "about 14% of our money comes from the county government, the rest of it comes from state and federal, which is also why those numbers are important," he said.
Most categories in Blueprint require financing at the school level, adding additional elements of complexity and compliance, and requiring full time accounting level position, Simmons said.
Besides Blueprint's requirements, budget pressures also include the rate of inflation at over 3.5%, multiyear contracts that will come up for renewal in 2024 that will likely be higher than the rate of inflation and global issues impacting the cost of goods, including fuel.
However, the budgeting challenge is not "all doom and gloom," Simmons said.
Caroline County has schools that qualify for "concentration of poverty" grant funding. While the funding is restricted to individual schools and can't support programs or positions at the district level, it helps take some pressure off the district to fund, for example, an afterschool program or reading intervention at a specific school.
Federalsburg and Greensboro elementary schools already qualify; Colonel Richardson Middle School received its first concentration of poverty grant in 2023.
"It's likely we will see multiple other schools added as the Free and Reduced Meals rates maintain or increase," Simmons said. Because the concentration of poverty funding formula relies on Free and Reduced Meals data, Simmons said, "I feel very confident all nine of our schools will get there."
As for the budgeting process, Simmons and his team will continue to work on the budget, try to find funding sources and work with the County finance office into 2024. Negotiating with the teachers' association will play a role, as well as a joint budget meeting with the Caroline County Commissioners.
"We also have a very good working relationship with the county commissioners," Simmons said. "We are not one of those counties that walks over to the county commissioners and drops an additional increase of $3, 4 or 5 million on them." The final CCPS budget is due to the county commissioners by the end of June.
Priorities in the fiscal year 2025 CCPS budget are competitive salaries and benefits for all employees, maintaining reasonable staffing levels across the district, maintaining high yield positions and programs that were included in pandemic-related grants and implementing the Blueprint as required.

title: School Principals Prepare for the Blueprint for Maryland's Future
author: Cait Kelley and Caley Fox Shannon
content:
School principals prepare for the Blueprint For Maryland's Future

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Cait Kelley And Caley Fox Shannon | Page: 12 | Section: News 
 
 777
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OCEAN CITY - As Maryland rolls out the 2021 landmark education reform law called the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, many school administrators are unsure what the plan means for their schools.At the annual School Leaders Conference held Nov. 2-4 in Ocean City, state officials and school principals reviewed the details of the Blueprint and discussed how it will be implemented in each school district.The wave of impending policy changes are meant to address the challenges facing educators and students across the state.The Blueprint is grounded in the analysis of a group of independent policy experts formed by the state in 2016 to establish a baseline for education reform.The group was commonly referred to as the Kirwan Commission after its chair, William E. Kirwan, chancellor emeritus of the University System of Maryland.By 2019, the Kirwan Commission had come to some sobering conclusions about Maryland's education system.Half of all teachers leave the profession within the first five years. Only two out of every five kindergarteners arrive in the classroom ready to learn. And just a third of students leave high school being "college and career ready" in English and math."That was pre-pandemic.So generally speaking, it's gotten worse," said Rachel Hise, a policy specialist who worked for the state in tandem with the Kirwan Commission.Explaining the commission's findings to school leaders in Ocean City, she said the independent body concluded that "ultimately, the status quo is unsustainable."The Maryland General Assembly passed the Blueprint for Maryland's Future in February 2021, overriding a veto by then-Gov.Larry Hogan, a Republican who had cost concerns about the plan.The Blueprint allocates $3.8 billion to schools over the next 10 years.Hise is now executive director of the Blueprint's Accountability and Implementation Board. She said the policy changes will make sure students are ready to learn in kindergarten and ready to succeed when they graduate high school.Because public schools lack the capacity to fulfill this mandate alone, the state will fund programming via private pre-K providers as well."The goal is a socioeconomically integrated pre-K system that is publicly funded, but that is provided by both public schools and private providers," Hise told administrators in Ocean City.The Blueprint will also mean big changes in high schools."What the Blueprint really envisions is we want kids to be college and career ready by 10th grade, so that the second two years of high school students can focus on the pathway that they're interested in pursuing," Hise said.The Blueprint aims to meet this goal through curriculum changes in English and math in addition to apprenticeships and technical education programs.Implementing the Blueprint at the school level falls squarely on school administrators, said Addie Kaufman, executive director of the Maryland Association of Secondary School Principals."There was no doubt that the Blueprint would be a part of this conference, and the understanding of the Blueprint is actually key," she said in an interview.After learning more about the Blueprint at the conference, some principals said they are hopeful that the reforms will address their schools' priorities.Teachers are struggling to make do with salaries in the current economy, said Principal Ryan Daniel of Fort Foote Elementary in Prince George's County."I know a lot of my teachers have to have after-school jobs or second jobs to compensate for their salary," she said.The Blueprint will raise the minimum salary for teachers to $60,000 across the state by 2026. And if teachers obtain National Board Certification, the Blueprint allows them to earn up to an additional $17,000 per year.Other schools have yet to feel the concrete impact of the Blueprint."Honestly, I'm still reading and learning, and I think that they're doing a really slow roll out intentionally for us, which is good," said Jamie Miller, the principal at Broadneck Elementary in Arnold. "We have people at the board level who are becoming sort of experts and then they're going to disseminate to us."Miller expressed a mix of excitement about the expansion of pre-K and trepidation about her school's capacity to meet the need.In March 2023, every school district submitted a detailed plan to the Accountability and Implementation Board for rolling out the Blueprint in their schools."The plans are fine, but they really are a baseline," Hise said. "There's a need for more innovative thinking."The Accountability and Implementation Board expects updated plans from every district in March 2024, and has offered every district a $100,000 grant to hire a strategic planning expert. All but Frederick and Worcester counties took the state up on that deal.

MCAP results show signs of recovery from pandemic learning loss - Science scores still show decline

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Aya Hussein; Capital News Service | Page: 27 | Section: News 
 
 840
 Words 

 Read News Document

 COLLEGE PARK - The results for the 2023 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program tests for grades 3 to 8 show that student proficiency in English Language Arts has surpassed the level it was at before the pandemic.Math scores have improved, but have yet to fully rebound from the pandemic, while science scores have declined, according to the Maryland State Department of Education.MCAP tests are administered annually in public schools to assist educators in understanding student progression so that they can better tailor their methods of instruction, according to MSDE.Students in grades 3 to 8 take tests in English and math, while students in grades 5 and 8 are given an additional science test.ENGLISH PROFICIENCY SURPASSES 2019According to data from MSDE, average English proficiency dropped from 44% in 2019 to 31% in 2021.Proficiency increased significantly in 2022 and by a smaller degree in 2023, with results showing an average passing rate of 47%, according to MSDE.Improvements can be seen across Maryland, as every county except Somerset had an increase in English proficiency between 2022 and 2023.MATH PROFICIENCY STILL BELOW PRE-PANDEMIC LEVELSThe 24% average passing rate for math in 2023 is still lower than the 31% in 2019, indicating that math scores have still not fully recovered from pandemic learning loss.Despite average passing rates in math still not being as high as in 2019, they have gone up since dropping to 15% in 2021. Proficiency increased by 6 percentage points from 2021 to 2022 and 3 percentage points from 2022 to 2023.Not every county had an improvement, as there are four counties that saw a decline in average math proficiency from 2022 to 2023: Baltimore, Kent, Somerset and Talbot.Baltimore County Public Schools Board of Education Member at Large Tiara Booker-Dwyer said that an explanation for the slower improvement in math scores is that the format of math questions in these tests have become more layered, which makes it difficult for parents, teachers and administrators trained in the traditional format to help students get accustomed.HISTORICALLY UNDERSERVED STUDENTS LAG BEHINDDespite making improvements over the last two years, average scores for historically underserved students in English and math still lag behind. The most recent scores of Black/African American, Hispanic/Latino and American Indian/Alaska Native students are still below those of white and Asian students.Booker-Dwyer said that it is important to build the cultural competency of educators so that they can connect better with students."When you look at the curriculum that was developed, it speaks to a certain demographic.There are certain people who just 'I'm not going to connect with this,' so it's going to go in one ear and out the other. Or when they try to connect to it, people recognize that it's inauthentic," Booker-Dwyer said.Booker-Dwyer states that another solution is encouraging more historically underserved students to take honors and AP classes, as well as providing resources to schools to give them these opportunities."What the research shows is that if you're placed in an advanced academic class or gifted class, even if you're earning C's in there, you're better off long term than if you're just in the standard class," Booker-Dwyer said."Sometimes it's just exposure to certain things, just being in a classroom, around students who are performing at a certain level will kind of unintentionally make you perform at a higher level," she said.GRADE 8 SCIENCE PROFICIENCY HITS FIVEYEAR LOWScience scores continue to lag, especially for grade 8.In grade 5, science proficiency in the last five years peaked in 2021 at 41%, a 12-percentage point increase from 2019. In 2022, the passing rate dropped to 31% before rising again to 35% in 2023, according to MSDE.Grade 8 scores have been on a steady decline since 2021, with the passing rate dropping from 35% in 2022 to 26% in 2023, the lowest it's been in the last five years.With the exception of Dorchester, every county had at least a 10% decline in grade 8 science proficiency from 2022 to 2023. Six counties had over a 30% decrease from 2022: Kent, Charles, Prince George's, Washington, Allegany and Queen Anne's.MSDE states that this decline is likely due to the grade 8 students being in grade 6 during the 2020-2021 school year, which was predominantly online. As a result, students missed key science instruction during their first year of middle school."The results on the grade 8 assessment make clear the impact of grade 6 and 7 disruptions on a cumulative grade 8 assessment," MSDE said in the press release.Booker-Dwyer stated that rollout for the new Next Generation Science Standards for K-12 education, which has lessons in engineering, technology, earth and space sciences in addition to traditional sciences, was delayed by the pandemic.She remains optimistic that scores will improve as curriculum continues to change."I do believe it will get better as people are getting more and more comfortable with the science standards and more teachers are getting trained and the resources are getting better, as far as the instructional material," Booker-Dwyer said. "But initially it was tough." The 2024 MCAP tests are set to begin in the spring.

title: Education Foundation Established in Caroline - Four Local Leaders Spearhead Funding Financial Literacy Opportunities for Students
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Education foundation established in Caroline - Four local leaders spearhead funding financial literacy opportunities for students

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 1A | Section: News 
 
 933
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - "Now we truly do have an education foundation in Caroline County, which is wonderful," Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons said at the Board of Education's Nov. 7 meeting.The announcement followed several months of work by four community leaders to establish the Caroline County Education Foundation, which was launched on Oct. 5.Tolbert Rowe, Robert Willey, Dr. James Orr Jr. and Wayne Cole spearheaded the effort.With the Blueprint for Maryland Education's unfunded mandate, school districts statewide are exploring funding streams beyond the traditional tax base.Other Mid-Shore counties with established education foundations are Kent and Talbot."The Caroline County Public Schools Education Foundation Fund is a subfund through the Mid-Shore Community Foundation," said Rowe, vice president of Bay Capital Mortgage based in Annapolis."Most importantly, I think it's a landing place that we can find philanthropic individuals and organizations we can solicit." A previous foundation was established in 1987, according to Willey, a Denton certified public accountant who took part in its inception."It was set up on a mini-grant system," Willey said. "The grants weren't supposed to be any more than $500, and they were to be awarded directly to classroom teachers to try to do projects that could not be funded through the school board's budget." "We started off great guns, and we operated for around 10 years, and then the board just got tired," Willey said. "We weren't able to recruit new blood and people with more energy and it just kind of died in the mid-90s." However, just over $8,000 remains in bank account once managed by the former foundation, an account which Willey still oversees.In a Nov. 18 interview, he said the new foundation will preserve the intent of the previous foundation's donors."Basically, it's the seed money that went into the educational fund that we've created with Mid-Shore Community Foundation," Rowe said in a Nov. 16 interview.During a conversation about Junior Achievement - a nonprofit providing financial literacy, work readiness and entrepreneurship education to K-12 students - Willey and Rowe decided it was time to reconstitute an education foundation with the Mid-Shore Community Foundation, of which Rowe is a director."We're focusing our efforts initially with financial literacy, career exploration (and) anything that will enhance children," Rowe said at the Nov. 7 meeting. "Much as Junior Achievement does, it's a shotgun approach. We want every kid to experience these things that will help them to make prudent economic career decisions." Orr said the group of four is currently working on bylaws. The purpose of the foundation "shall be to enhance, inspire and support educational opportunities in the area of financial literacy for all students attending Caroline County public schools," he said.On Nov. 16, Rowe said, "The four of us decided that, at least at this point, it would be more impactful to focus our efforts on a specific area like financial literacy, as opposed to everything, because we just don't have a lot of money.If we get more money, then we can expand the mission, but for right now we're going to hold pat with financial literacy." Rowe said the founders "will be setting up a meeting soon get our bylaws adopted and make decisions as to who could serve with us.If anyone knows of anyone in the community that would be good for this organization, we would love to have a conversation." "Times are changing, and this financial literacy piece is going to become so important and we're going to grow this fund," said Cole, chief financial officer of WIN Transport, Inc. in Federalsburg."Financial literacy obviously is very powerful," Simmons said."Caroline County is still one of the only systems in the state that requires all of our high schoolers to complete a full credit of a finance course before graduation, and I'm glad we have that, but at the same time, one only has to look at the current economic situation we're in to realize that one credit during your high school experience in one county on Maryland's Eastern Shore is not solving a fiscal issue that's in front of us everywhere.But financial literacy is a massive undertaking and needed." Simmons explained that CCPS was the first to sign a memorandum of understanding with Junior Achievement of the Eastern Shore regarding providing students opportunities at the organization's 25,000 square-foot regional facility under construction in Salisbury."It's a great center, but it's also a great program that they put together, working with businesses and communities across the Eastern Shore (and it's) great, strong curriculum coming in," Simmons said. The curriculum aligns with the Maryland State Department of Education's requirements.He said the foundation would be in a good position to help with costs associated with students getting to the facility."We are the furthest distance from the center and we have the highest degree of poverty," Simmons said. "We're the (school) system that has the most need with the least amount of funds to spend to get our kids there, and we have the greatest distance to drive to get there." He added that the Blueprint, which requires career exploration as well as dual enrollment, also requires counties to fund compliance with the legislation."We're required to pay for everybody's dual enrollment who are enrolled in our high schools," Simmons said. "The math in Blueprint doesn't add up. They did not take financial literacy." "That's where Blueprint stands right now, and we'll do our part," he said. He added that the foundation could "help support other things that we're trying to do."

Denton businessmen Bob Willey, at the lectern, and Tolbert Rowe on Nov. 7 explain how the Caroline County Education Foundation will fund financial literacy efforts for students.

title: Board of Education to Create Special Education Committee
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Board of Education to create Special Education Committee

 November 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 317
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Talbot County Board of Education has created a new committee to address updating, modernizing and funding special education in Talbot County Public Schools.In a unanimous vote, the board directed Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi to lead the charge in the creation of this new Special Education Committee. Board President Emily Jackson introduced the motion at Board of Education meeting Wednesday."I would like to create a committee focused on special education," she said. "As we all know, looking at Blueprint, the way that we are doing our budget and our funding is going to change."The Blueprint for Maryland's Future is a statewide plan to increase public education funding, improve student outcomes and improve the quality of public education. Jackson said this change in the way the budget is done means that there would not be a lot of specific line items "directly applicable to special education" in the budget."Combine that with the fact that our special education population has been growing rapidly," Jackson said to explain why she sees a need for this committee.Jackson said she would like the committee to do a holistic deep dive into what TCPS is currently doing regarding special education as well as what they could be doing. She said she would like the committee to look into modernizing the district's practices and come up with a full proposal for modernizing and funding special education in the county."I think that we all have talked a lot about how we need to approach special ed," she said.Jackson said she would like this committee to spend the year gathering information and come back next year, before budget season, with a proposal that includes what it would cost to modernize special education programming and how the district could fund it.

Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi will chair the new group, which will assess compliance with Maryland’s Blueprint for the Future and recommend policies to improve services for students with disabilities. The committee will meet monthly, gather input from parents, teachers and advocates, and deliver a report by summer 2024. Officials said the initiative aims to close gaps in staffing, resources, and outcomes identified in recent state audits.

title: Chapel District Elementary Renovation Design Plans Move to State for Review
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Chapel District Elementary renovation design plans move to state for review

 October 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 568
 Words

 EASTON - The Talbot County Board of Education approved the design development submission for the Chapel District Elementary School renovation and addition at a Board of Education meeting Wednesday evening.The design development plan needs to be submitted to the state for review by Nov. 1. TCPS Director of Operations Kevin Shafer said this submission is the next milestone in the design process.Before the board voted unanimously to submit the design development plan, Shafer and Adam McDonald, project manager and architect from design firm Hord Coplan Macht, gave a presentation to update the board on plans for the project, including the schedule and estimated project costs.McDonald explained that the project includes a full renovation of the existing building and 16,600 square feet of additions.Three total additions at different corners of the building will add additional learning space."The additions are also going to help us enhance the overall design of the building," McDonald said.Since the board's last update on project plans, McDonald said they have made changes to the addition on the north corner of the building to "work better with the existing utilities" during construction.A traffic pattern has been formalized, and a first submission has been made to the State Highway Administration to create an additional curb cut to separate the parent entry loop from the bus drop."To help alleviate some of the traffic concerns that come with a shared entrance," McDonald said.The design plans for outside also include an extension to the parking lot to provide more space for parents dropping off students.Inside the building, McDonald said that most spaces will remain in the same areas as they are pre-renovation.The main change, he said, is that the media center will move to the front of the building and the art classroom will take over where the current media center is.Currently, bidding for the project is expected to take place in April and May of 2024. Construction would begin in June of 2024 and is estimated to take about two years.The estimated cost of construction and site work is $25.18 million. State and county funding for this will come out of FY2025 and FY2026 budgets. With additional expenditures, for things like design costs, the project is expected to cost $29.97 million.Shafer said this estimated cost is $1 million less than the state projection for the project."So I feel like we're within where we want to be," he said, adding that this is still just a projection and the real numbers will come when they bid the project out.After the presentation, board members asked questions.Board Member Deborah Bridges asked about the plan for the school's roof."The slanted roofs really have me worried," she said, expressing concern about drainage.Shafer said the pitched roof is not near the courtyard."The architect will make sure that any kind of drainage that's coming off the roof, whether it's roof drain or exterior drain, is properly sized to accommodate that water shed," he said.

title: Carey Wright Appointed Interim State Superintendent
content:
Carey Wright appointed interim state superintendent

 October 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 540
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland State Board of Education voted unanimously on Wednesday evening to appoint Carey Wright as the interim State Superintendent of Schools for the remainder of the current term through June 30, 2024. Wright will begin her service as state superintendent by Oct. 23, 2023, pending the completion of onboarding logistics.Most recently, Wright served for nine years as the state superintendent of schools in Mississippi."I am honored to be appointed to this position and am excited to work on behalf of the teachers, leaders and students of Maryland. Maryland is well-positioned to provide a world-class education system for all its students and to ensure each student's success," Wright said. "I am confident that by establishing strong relationships and partnerships across the state we will witness strong, equitable educational outcomes for our students. I welcome the opportunity to be an active participant in this endeavor."Under Wright's leadership, Mississippi's Quality Counts grade for education improved from an F to a C, improving its ranking from 50th to 35th. Her work reform efforts to improve literacy instruction for children Pre-K through third grade produced significant improvements in literacy rates in Mississippi, with the largest gains in fourth grade literacy on the National Assessment for Educational Progress."I am thrilled to welcome Dr. Carey Wright as Maryland's Interim State Superintendent. She is an exceptional leader who will guide Maryland's education system into its new chapter," Gov. Wes Moore said. "Dr. Wright brings exemplary expertise to this role and I am confident that she will be a dedicated leader committed to transparency, accountability, and partnership to improve education outcomes in every corner of Maryland, just as this state deserves."Wright has long been an enthusiastic advocate for early childhood education and in Mississippi implemented the first publicly funded Early Learning Collaborative program, which earned the state recognition from the National Institute for Early Education Research as one of only seven states in the nation that meet all or most quality standards for early childhood education.Wright brings to the position decades of service as a Maryland educator with stints in Prince George's, Howard, and Montgomery County Public Schools as a teacher, principal, director of special education, and associate superintendent. Prior to serving as superintendent in Mississippi, Wright served as the chief academic officer in DC Public Schools. Wright obtained her bachelor's, master's and doctoral degrees from the University of Maryland, College Park."Dr. Wright is a Maryland educator and a national leader of education reform. She has the experience and expertise to lead Maryland through implementation of the Blueprint for Maryland's Future and through our state's commitment to educational equity and improving outcomes for all students," State Board President Clarence Crawford said. "We are confident in her ability to lead our school system through this transition period, to be focused on transparency and accountability, and to continue building towards the improvements in results in our schools that we all know are necessary."Wright will receive a salary at an annual rate of $350,000, which will be prorated to the amount of time she serves from now through June 30, 2024. The joint State Board and MSDE Transition Team will support Wright as she is onboarded, and the national search for a permanent state superintendent of schools will continue in the coming months.

title: Dorchester Schools Gain Proficiency on Tests
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester schools gain proficiency on tests

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 901
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Dorchester County Public Schools saw an increase in English language arts scores on the spring 2023 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program, or MCAP, assessments compared to the year before.Math data showed a few significant increases along with some slight changes in proficiency compared to the year before.During a Dorchester County Board of Education meeting, Jodi Colman, director of curriculum, instruction and assessment for Dorchester County Public Schools, shared data from the spring 2023 MCAP assessments.The MCAP assessments are statewide and administered to students starting in grade three through high school.Data broken down by individual schools is not yet available to the public.ENGLISH LANGUAGE ARTSFor grades three through six, there were significant increases in the percent of proficient learners in English language arts from the year before.The MCAP assessment uses four levels to measure student performance."Proficient learner" is the third of four levels. Level one is a "beginning learner," level two is a "developing learner," and level four is a "distinguished learner."Students who fall into levels 3 and 4 are considered proficient in the subject. In Dorchester County, the percent of students that fall into level 4 for the English language arts and math categories are between 0 and 5%.For the level three proficient learner category in English language arts, compared to Spring 2022 data:▪ Third graders increased to 31% from 26.4%.▪ Fourth graders increased to 32% from 27.6%.▪ Fifth graders increased to 33% from 26.8%▪ Sixth graders increased to 33% from 22.2% - a 10.8% increase.▪ Seventh graders decreased to 20% from 24.1%.▪ Eighth graders decreased to 27% from 29.2%.Along with seventh and eighth graders, there was a drop in the percent of proficient learners for the English 10 assessment compared to the previous year. The percentage dropped from 36.4% to 35%.Colman said the state average growth for English language arts was 2.9 percentage points.Dorchester County's average growth was 4.1 percentage points, she said."So we grew significantly, or doubled, the amount that the rest of the state did," she said. "It put us at the eleventh spot [in the state] as far as growth is concerned."Laura Aberg, DCPS supervisor of reading and English language arts for K through 12, spoke after Colman presented on the English language arts data."I'm excited to see all the growth for our younger students," she said."Our secondary students, we need to do some work to get back to the levels of growth that we like to see."Aberg said the district has implemented more diagnostics at the beginning of the year to identify those "reading gaps" so they can be addressed sooner for secondary students. She also talked about getting ready to enroll students in grades six through eight, as well as tenth graders, in MCAP tutorials.Aberg said she hopes to see even greater growth for younger students in the future since the district has implemented a foundational reading program that aligns with the science of reading, or the research behind how students learn to read.Board Member Theresa Stafford asked Aberg what the district did differently last year that might be attributed to the growth in proficiency for elementary students.Aberg mentioned multiple changes including the use of DIBELS test data to "help drive instruction" and getting teachers trained in the science of reading.MATHWhen it came to MCAP math assessments, grade seven and Algebra I saw significant increases in proficiency. The percentage of seventh graders that were considered proficient learners increased to 11% from less than 5% the year before. The percentage of Algebra I students that were considered proficient learners increased to 10% from less than 5% the year before.For grade six, there was a decrease in proficient learners, compared the year before, from 10% to less than 5%.For the other math assessments in the county, there was a mix of slight increases, slight decreases and constants in the percentage of proficient learners compared to the previous year. These include:▪ Third graders decreased to 20% from 20.3%▪ Fourth graders increased to 15% from 14.6%▪ Fifth graders increased to 14% from 12.2%▪ Eighth graders stayed at less than 5%▪ Geometry students stayed at 0%▪ Algebra II students decreased to 0% from less than 5%Colman said that while the state average growth for math was 2.5 percentage points, Dorchester County grew 2.0 percentage points.DCPS is focusing on improving math scores for third graders, sixth graders and Algebra I students this year, she said."Those were kind of the focus areas as far as the data," Colman said.She said there is a focus on third grade because it is the first group of students to take the MCAP assessments and there is a need for those students to gain a better understanding of the assessment.At the middle school level, Colman said the math coach is working with teachers and modeling lessons. The math coach is also working and planning with Algebra I teachers."So she's kind of targeted certain grade levels to try to impact some of this data," Colman said.After Colman's presentation on the math data, Board Member Chris Wheedleton talked about the importance of recognizing the data, good and bad, and talking about how the data can be improved for next year."I'm really pleased to see what you all are doing with this, how you've organized it," he said. "But then, it's really about the action."

title: Counties Ponder Money for College Building - Financial Commitment Worries Many of the County Officials
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Counties ponder money for college building - Financial commitment worries many of the county officials

 October 4, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 16 | Section: News 
 
 675
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Talbot and Queen Anne's counties came together virtually recently to discuss a $79 million project to build a new Technical Center at Chesapeake College?Each county must decide whether or not it wants to submit a letter of intent to the Maryland Higher Education Commission to provide local funds for the facility before a Sept. 28 meeting at the Department of Budget and Management. The meeting, according to Chesapeake College President Cliff Coppersmith, is an opportunity to get the project "to the next level" by getting it put on a state list of capital projects.The state has agreed to pay for 75% of the capital project. With these letters of intent, each county would agree to providing local funds for the other 25%. In an email, Coppersmith said that once state funding has been allocated and approved, each supporting county would need to pass appropriations to fund the local share of the capital project.The facility would be more than 90,000 square feet. Of that total, 52,000 square feet would be assignable space. Currently, construction is set for 2026. The center will be located next to the Eastern Shore Higher Education Center."Our problem right now is we've got so much equipment crammed in these spaces, there's not a lot of room for students," Coppersmith said of the current Queen Anne's Technical Building during the meeting.According to meeting documents from a Queen Anne's County Commissioners meeting Sept. 12, the new facility "will house programs such as electrical, welding, HVAC, culinary, skilled office/administrative support and marine and construction trades training."Kent County Commission President Ron Fithian chaired the meeting between counties Monday evening. Fithian said that while the new facility would be great to have on the Eastern Shore, Kent County does have concerns about the financial aspect of the project.Caroline County Commission Vice President Larry Porter said the cost of building the new facility is what strikes him most."I would really like to have a little bit more information about where that number is coming from," he said.Coppersmith said the estimated cost includes furnishing the building.
