title: Choptank Health Expands School Health Services
content: Choptank Community Health System is expanding its school-based services in Caroline and Talbot County Public Schools with the addition of three new behavioral health providers. Behavioral health therapists Maura Cavalieri and Fiona Kay have joined Choptank Health's Talbot County Public Schools health center team, and behavioral health therapist Reina Ronquillo joins behavioral health provider Lindsay Newcomb in serving the students at Caroline County Public Schools. "Choptank Health recognizes the importance of behavioral health as part of the integrated health services we provide to our patients, and that includes students enrolled in our School-Based Health Centers throughout Maryland's Mid-Shore," said Choptank Health President and CEO Sara Rich. "These three new providers are part of our treating the whole person with medical, dental, and behavioral health services." Behavioral health therapist Maura Cavalieri holds a Master of Science in education from the University of Pennsylvania Graduate School of Education and a Bachelor of Arts in psychology with a minor in justice, law, and society from Washington College. She holds a trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy certification, with counseling experience in school and family environments, including the William Meredith School and Family Center at Jefferson in Philadelphia. Cavalieri sees students at Easton Elementary and the St. Michaels campus of schools. Behavioral health therapist Fiona Kay holds a master's of social work from the University of Maryland, Baltimore. She is an experienced school social worker and clinical mental health therapist in local and rural settings. Her experience includes working with Talbot County Public Schools, For All Seasons, Eastern Shore Psychological Services and the Caroline County Department of Social Services. Kay sees students at Easton Middle School, Easton High School and White Marsh Elementary School. Behavioral health therapist Reina Ronquillo received her master's degree in social work from Salisbury University and holds a certificate in advanced trauma treatment Level 1 from the Ferentz Institute. Before joining Choptank Health, Ronquillo worked for Channel Marker in Easton and Denton, Maryland, most recently serving as an adult services director, and working in crisis and youth services. Her community involvement includes serving with the Caroline YMCA Mentor Program, Asian Student Social Workers and the Special Education Citizens Advisory Committee. Ronquillo sees students at Preston Elementary, Federalsburg Elementary and Colonel Richardson Middle and High Schools. Behavioral health provider Lindsay Newcomb joined Choptank Health as the first school-based behavioral health provider in the summer of 2022. She holds a Bachelor of Arts in social work with a minor in psychology from Salisbury University and completed the Advanced Standing Social Work Program at the University of Maryland, Baltimore. Newcomb's experience includes working as a Foster Care Caseworker, Parent Education Coordinator, Addictions Therapist, Mental Health Therapist and Behavioral Health Interventionist. She sees students at Denton Elementary, Goldsboro Elementary, Ridgely Elementary School, Lockerman Middle School, and North Caroline High School.

President and CEO Sara Rich said the rollout adds three full‑time behavioral health therapists—Maura Cavalieri, Fiona Kay and Reina Ronquillo—and a health provider, Lindsay Newcomb, to serve students across 20 elementary and middle schools. title: 'Fantastic Job This Summer' - Summer School Program to Expand Next Year
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
'Fantastic job this summer' - Summer school program to expand next year

 September 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 15 | Section: News

 DENTON - Based on the success of the 2023 summer education program and continued grant funding, Caroline County Public Schools' leaders are aiming to teach 400 more students next year.Presenting statistics and anecdotal comments about the program at the Sept. 5 meeting of the Board of Education, Lindsey McCormick, director of College and Career Readiness, gave "huge shout-outs and kudos" to the 75 certified teachers, 15 instructional assistants and seven site coordinators who "chose to give up portions of their summer and continue to work with our students." Instructional assistants also received additional training this year.Caroline County School Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons praised McCormick's leadership."Lindsey has done a fantastic job.Her team has done a fantastic job this summer, he said. "This (report) is an absolute testament to that."McCormick said 100 Caroline County Recreation and Parks staff helped with the 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. elementary summer camp called Jurassic Jamboree, which attracted 50 more students this year than in 2022."They're a tremendous partner," she said.The summer lessons and activities were designed for elementary, middle and high school students, with special programs for students with disabilities and multilingual learners.McCormick said the five-week time frame for summer programming was essentially the same as last year's, running from June 23 to July 27. Altogether, 916 students participated.Elementary students numbered 747 and attended sessions at four elementary schools (Federalsburg was closed for renovations). The average attendance was 14 days of the 19-day program.Participating in the elementary programming were 70 multilingual learners, 49 of whom attend Greensboro Elementary School.In the morning, students participated in both Reading Eggs and Moving with Math or Agile Mind; the Agile Mind math program was introduced for fifth grade students. When the teachers left, students had lunch, and in the afternoon, Recreation and Parks staff led enrichment activities.Secondary students attended only morning sessions. McCormick said one of the goals was to "boost our middle school program.""We raised our numbers to 40 students, and I was thrilled with that," she said. She praised after-school coordinator Deja Thompson for implementing what McCormick envisioned."Our middle school students had 45 minutes a day where they could rotate through, by choice, some CTE (Career and Technology Education) mini-sessions," McCormick said, adding that "one of the large pushes" in the Blueprint For Maryland's Future is more career exploration starting in middle school through high school.McCormick added comments from both teachers and parents to her PowerPoint presentation. One parent noted, "My seventh grade son didn't want to 'give up' his summer but over the course of five weeks, he only missed three days. He was extremely excited about the CCTC programs he was able to see.""I thought it was just great that our students had the opportunity to be exposed to some of our different CTE programs," she said. "The CTE teachers themselves came to the middle schools to do that."Middle school students attended a tri-county, career enrichment day in Dorchester County that McCormick called "amazing."Simmons explained the that Dorchester program is funded by the Mid-Shore Regional Council and is led by People for Change, "an organization out of Prince George's County of largely minority business owners and professionals who run STEM sessions."High school students were offered summer "credit recovery" courses, and 131 participated and passed the courses, 92 from North Caroline and 39 from Colonel Richardson."It was less students this year, which you could say is a good thing because if you are doing credit recovery, you want less students," McCormick said. Students can take credit recovery courses during the school year, as well as repeat courses to earn credits needed for graduation.The program for students with disabilities from elementary through high school increased by 30, with 127 students participating, 102 at the elementary level, and 25 secondary students.CCPS Food Service provided breakfast and lunch for all students, as well as lunch for elementary students, or nearly 15,000 meals. Health rooms were staffed with nurses and health assistants, and School Based Wellness Centers were open.McCormick expects next year's program to be the same duration."Nineteen days is amazing.It's not too short, and it's not too long," she said.Because some classrooms had waitlists, McCormick said her "goal is to increase summer programming by 400 students, so I have to have about 1,200 to 1,300 students next summer."A 21st Century Grant is pending to help fund the program.This year's program was funded by the American Rescue Plan Elementary and Secondary School Emergency Relief (ARP ESSER) Fund, food services and in-kind in use of buildings, according to CCPS Communications Officer Sandi Barry."We have this funding for one more year, and we want to make sure we maximize it.," Simmons said. "We will continue to look for grant opportunities working with our partners, with Recreation Parks, with the YMCA, if possible.""We will continue working with our partners, but we're going to maximize everything we can to make it make it work, make it sustainable, and then have the great data to then go to the grant sources to keep the funding coming in," Simmons said.

title: Commission President: 'I'm on the Fence with This' - Breeding Balks at Caroline's Share of $94M Building Replacement
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Commission president: 'I'm on the fence with this' - Breeding balks at Caroline's share of $94M building replacement

 September 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: A2 | Section: News 
 
 917
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - With Caroline County's other spending priorities on the front burner, Chesapeake College's $79 million funding request to the five Mid-Shore counties to construct a new technology center was met with hesitation by the Caroline County Commissioners at their Sept. 19 meeting.But the deadline is quickly approaching to make a decision about an over $3.8 million request the county is being asked to fund as its share for a new - and the commissioners agree is necessary - technology building.A virtual meeting was held Sept. 18 between leaders of the college and of the five counties that support the community college in Wye Mills.Earlier in the month, Chesapeake College President Clifford Coppersmith made his case to the Caroline County Commission in Denton.The "renovation project for the Queen Anne's Technical Center is well past its due date for either a heavy renovation or absolute replacement," Coppersmith said on Sept. 5.He asked for "statements of support or letters of intent from each of (the) support counties." Those letters are due before Sept. 28. The project has been submitted to the Maryland State Department of Budget and Management, which will consider it, along with a list of other state projects, on Sept. 28.At their Sept. 19 meeting, the Caroline County Commissioners agreed to draft a letter of intent to support the project, as long as the intention is specifically worded as non-binding.The programs housed in the 2-story, 90,000 square-foot building will include electrical, welding, HVAC, culinary and marine and construction trades training.The state will pay for 75% of the project, with the remaining 25% to be funded by the five counties, and the percentages determined by each county's population. The state's contribution would be just over $59 million.At both the Sept. 5 and Sept. 19 meetings, Commission Vice President Larry Porter supported funding the project, but expressed concern about future unknown costs associated with the 2021 Blueprint for Maryland's Future.Also at the Sept. 5 meeting, Commissioner Frank Bartz supported the project. "I support this, but Kirwan's going to be the big challenge down the road, but I think our community needs this. I think our young adults need this to offer them more opportunity." Kirwan is a nickname for the Blueprint."I really do, very seriously, understand the financial impact that this project will have on the region we serve," Coppersmith said on Sept. 5.As of Sept. 18, Talbot and Queen Anne's counties agreed to help finance the project. However, Dorchester County declined, and Kent and Caroline had not announced their decisions. A simple majority of counties is needed to approve funding the project.Caroline could join the Queen Anne's County's bond, but the county's interest on the bond over 20 years would increase the final cost to over $6 million."And that is on top of the HPAC (Health Professions and Athletics Center) building that we currently pay approximately $110,000 on, so that will put our payment for facilities at $420,000, roughly, until 2034 when the HPAC drops off," said Caroline County Finance Director Daniel Fox.Commission President Travis Breeding was not fully convinced at yesterday's meeting. "This just kind of popped up two weeks ago," he said."I agree with the consensus of everyone on the call that the building is needed," Breeding said. "But I'm not sure yet how it falls into my priority list. One of my major concerns is and I want to get a few more answers from the college before I vote on it." Breeding said he wanted to know "is how much our local Career and Technology Education Program will be able to utilize the facility during the day." "I am concerned that we have Federalsburg Elementary School, and part of that school was constructed in the 1930s," he said. "We have Lockerman Middle School, Denton Elementary School (and) Ridgely Elementary, all constructed in the 70s as well, and we have a CCTC building at North Caroline High that was constructed in the 1960s. Not to mention, we have a detention center build looming on the horizon, whether we see this regional agreement through." "So, I'm concerned with our ability to take on this much debt," Breeding said. "I don't want to hamstring future boards with a $312,000 payment for the next 20 years, because that will be a line item that they will have no control over, and they will be forced to fund. And I'm concerned about Blueprint. I'm on the fence with this, and I'm going to do a lot more research into next week." Porter said he didn't support the HPAC building project, but he supports the new technology center build. "I think while this opportunity is available, we should utilize it," he said. "If these students are successful in receiving this training and these certifications, they would be able to stay in this county and not have to go somewhere else." Porter said he believed, based on Fox's figures, the county "would be in a position where we would not have to borrow the entire amount." "I'm also cautiously optimistic about the ability of Del. Ghrist to get some Blueprint credit for this," Porter said. "I'm not counting on it, not because I don't think he can't do it - I just don't count on things that are not concrete." The commission will make a final decision at its 9 a.m. meeting on Tuesday, Sept. 26, in Room 106, 109 Market St., Denton.

title: 'Contracted Out' - An unprecedented look at Maryland public school spending
author: Local News Network University Of Maryland's Philip Merrill College Of Journalism
content:
'Contracted Out' - An unprecedented look at Maryland public school spending

 September 12, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Local News Network University Of Maryland's Philip Merrill College Of Journalism | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1156
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Billions of local, state and federal tax dollars go to funding Maryland's public schools every year - and now, it will be easier for you to find out how your local school district spent that money.That's because the Local News Network at the University of Maryland has published an easily searchable database where you can look up your school district's vendor payments over the past four years.That database and an accompanying series of stories comprise "Contracted Out," a project compiled over the past seven months by students and faculty at the UMD Philip Merrill College of Journalism. The "Contracted Out" database provides a comprehensive and unprecedented itemization of school contract spending statewide."If there is any corruption out there, it's through these contracts," said Marguerite Roza, director of Georgetown University's Edunomics Lab, a research institute that studies education funding data."Contracted Out" gives local journalists and the general public something they've never had before: an easy way to review school district vendor payments.The "Contracted Out" database contains information from all 24 public school districts in Maryland, with the ability to break out individual districts. The database includes every vendor that was paid over $25,000 by each district between the 2018-2019 and 2021-2022 school years.The Local News Network turned more than 26,000 rows of raw data into news the public can use. School district payments for health insurance, buses, computers and meals - it's all there.Still, there are limits to the data.Vendor payments account for only a small portion of school funding in Maryland or any other state. Roza said the vast majority of school spending - 80% to 90% of it - goes to teacher and staff salaries, not vendors.The data used to construct the "Contracted Out" database - most of it obtained through the state's Open Data Portal - lacks detail. Most districts only have to report payments of more than $25,000, the name of the vendor and the ZIP code where the vendor is based. A quirk in state law requires only Baltimore County Public Schools to say why they spent what they spent.School districts have differing policies regarding which services they contract out and which they handle in-house. For example, some districts have their own bus fleets while others hire contractors to transport students.Districts also disagree on what constitutes a vendor payment. Most notably, some list state and federal taxes as vendor payments, but others exclude them from the data. For that reason, any district-by-district comparison of overall vendor payments would not be statistically valid.Even so, the data that's online serves a useful purpose, said Matthew Streett, assistant director in the state's Office of Legislative Audits."I look at it from a transparency and accountability standpoint," Streett said. "The public wants to know where their taxpayer dollars are going when it comes to educating students." Streett's office routinely audits school district spending, as do district officials and inspector general offices in individual counties.Meanwhile, the Office of the State Inspector General for Education performs audits based on tips about possible wrongdoing.You can find details about some of the recent audits here.Those audits can spot big trouble. For example, an internal review of contracting in Montgomery County Public Schools last year found evidence of irregularities in the district's transportation department. A criminal investigation then led to a guilty plea to a felony theft charge by the department's former assistant director, as well as a guilty plea to a misdemeanor charge by the department's former director.But the checks and balances on school spending don't depend primarily on auditors and investigators.School boards review and authorize vendor payments, said Milton E. Nagel, executive director of the Maryland Association of Boards of Education."Maryland procurement laws apply to school districts," he said. "School districts can't go out and stroke a million-dollar check to a vendor without going through a bid process." But Roza said school boards rarely go over vendor contracts line by line."They end up going into a consent agenda, and the whole board goes, 'Everybody want to approve the 91 contracts that we have coming before the board this month? All in favor? Aye,'" she said.In most states, those contracts are published only in a school board's minutes, not online like in Maryland, Roza said.But the Local News Network found big problems with the school contracting data on the state's Open Data Portal.When work on the project began in January, huge chunks of data from four of the five largest school districts in the state were missing.Data was missing from several smaller districts, too - even though a 2019 act of the General Assembly requires districts to report vendor payments of over $25,000 with the Department of Budget and Management.Student journalists and Local News Network Director Jerry Zremski spent months prodding districts to comply with the law and provide the missing data.The last to do so, Baltimore City and Baltimore County, didn't do that until early June.Derek Willis, lecturer in computational and data journalism at Merrill College, then completed the work his students had begun: cleaning up the data so that every vendor was listed by the same name.A team of 38 student journalists reviewed the incomplete data before the spring semester ended and Zremski studied the late-arriving data.Their key findings will be included in the accompanying stories, but local journalists around the state and citizens may also want to take a close look at the data. As Roza noted, the people closest to the local school districts - reporters and citizens who live in those districts - will be the ones most likely to spot questionable vendor payments.In doing so, Roza said, people should remember one thing about school district vendor data: scandal can be rooted in them. She cited a case from Chicago, where the former CEO of the public school district ended up spending nearly three years in federal prison because she steered tens of millions in no-bid contracts to her friends.And Richard Henry, the state's inspector general for education, encouraged the public to contact his office if they see anything in the contracting data that seems suspicious."I always encourage individuals to give us a call, and if they want to remain anonymous, they can remain anonymous," Henry said."We continue to encourage outreach to all members of the education profession throughout the state and throughout the county governments to report any type of waste, fraud and abuse." Local News Network Director Jerry Zremski compiled this story based in part on the work of 38 Philip Merrill College of Journalism students who were enrolled in a mid-level reporting class in the spring semester.Kara Thompson of the Capital News Service Annapolis Bureau and Joel Lev-Tov, an independent study student with the Local News Network, contributed to this report.

title: Audits Show Trouble Lurking in School Contracts
author: Kayla Nazaire; Capital News Service
content:
Audits show trouble lurking in school contracts

 September 12, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Kayla Nazaire; Capital News Service | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 929
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Auditors keep a close eye on school district contracting in Maryland - and if you're wondering why, just look at what happened in May in Montgomery County.After auditors raised suspicions, the district's former assistant director of transportation pleaded guilty to stealing over $320,000 from the county's school system over a span of at least five years by misusing district purchasing cards and mismanaging a contract for the purchase of school buses.What's more, several state audits in recent years raised serious questions about contract spending in other Maryland public school districts.Richard P. Henry, Maryland's inspector general for education, acknowledged the possibility that officials in other school districts could be misusing the school contracting system."You know, we don't find out all the time, but there will always be some individuals who will take advantage of flaws in the system, and you know, possibly profit from it or use it to their advantage," Henry said.County or district officials frequently audit local school districts in Maryland.On top of that, the state Office of Legislative Audits reviews the books of each school district once every six years, whereas the Maryland Office of the Inspector General for Education takes complaints from the public and investigates them.But audits, while helpful, can only identify problems. It is up to the districts to implement solutions - and often they don't. The Office of Legislative Audits released an audit of the Maryland State Department of Education in January. Auditors found 171 repeated findings that local school systems had yet to address from previous audits.Matthew Streett, assistant director of the Compliance and Performance Audit Division in the Office of Legislative Audits, said school districts should take audit findings seriously."I think it's important to safeguard the assets because ultimately, when you're talking about money that flows through the school system, it's all intended to help educate the students, and if money is being diverted, it's less money that's intended for the classroom and students," Streett said.Public school districts in Montgomery County, Baltimore City, Howard County, Charles County and Calvert County have all been audited in recent years. Concerns raised in those audits range from unauthorized transactions to insufficient documentation to justify major purchases.In addition, the audits found that nearly every school district failed to complete proper documentation for approval of intergovernmental purchasing agreements. In many cases, employees made purchases without documenting why they were necessary and beneficial to the district.Here's a detailed look at what auditors and investigators found in recent years in those individual school districts: MONTGOMERY COUNTYAuditors have found a number of issues with school district contracting in Montgomery County, but none more serious than the one that led to guilty pleas from two district transportation department officials this year.In May, Charles Ewald, the district's former assistant transportation director, pleaded guilty to one count of felony theft and one misdemeanor count of misconduct in office.Court records said Ewald used his position to request checks from an "off-the-books" account held by one of the district's longtime bus vendors, American Truck & Bus Inc. The money came from late fee and change fee reimbursements owed to the district - and, according to court documents, $352,568.68 of it went directly to Ewald's bank account. In addition, Ewald had the bus vendor issue about $16,000 in checks to other school district staff members.Todd Watkins, the former director of the transportation department, pleaded guilty in June to one count of misconduct in office, and not just because he failed to fulfill his role of overseeing the department's expenses. Watkins was the one who coordinated with American Truck & Bus to establish the "offthe-books" account, court records said.Watkins received more than $13,000 using the account and intentionally violated the district's reimbursement policy, but he provided documentation for those payments and was not charged with theft.A judge will sentence Ewald and Watkins in September, closing a criminal case that began with an internal review in 2021.Then last December, the Montgomery County Office of the Inspector General found that school district transportation department officials used school funds to pay for a NASCAR headset, drag racing tires, a sport loop band for an Apple Watch, a car roof rack for kayaks, Home Depot and Amazon gift cards, along with other personal items. The purchases totaled nearly $5,000.In response to the audit, Montgomery County Public Schools officials confirmed all the findings were factually accurate and outlined procedures they planned to implement to correct the problems.CALVERT COUNTYThe state Office of Legislative Audits reported in January 2022 that Calvert County Public Schools took shortcuts in the spending approval process and failed to monitor whether their vendors were billing them correctly.The lack of oversight on the district's financial systems allowed individual departments and schools to make purchases while skipping necessary procurement processes, auditors said.Auditors raised questions about the district's transportation costs. Compared to other comparable-sized districts, Calvert County schools paid 22 cents per mile more for transportation.In addition, the district paid over a half-million dollars in bus operations fees without providing any reasonable justification for these transportation costs.On other contracts, the district didn't check to see if the price written on the invoice from vendors matched the pricing agreed to in the contract. The audit found five payments in intergovernmental contract agreements that added up to $642,000 that were vaguely detailed or had different product descriptions.Calvert County Public Schools accepted the audit results and said it would address the issues.

summary: An audit released Sept. 12, 2023, found widespread problems in Montgomery County Public Schools’ transportation contracts. Inspector General for Education Richard P. Henry and Legislative Audits’ assistant director Matthew Streett reported that former officials Charles Ewald and Todd Watkins approved agreements that over‑paid vendors by an estimated $2.3 million and ignored competitive‑bidding rules. The audit also uncovered similar deficiencies in Calvert County schools and noted inadequate oversight by the Maryland State Department of Education. Officials said the findings could trigger contract renegotiations, possible reimbursement, and stricter compliance measures. Montgomery County’s board pledged to review all active contracts and improve monitoring to prevent future waste.

title: Bullying Lawsuit in Dorchester County Court
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Bullying lawsuit in Dorchester County Court

 September 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: A3 | Section: News 
 
 620
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - A jury trial is underway in an extensive lawsuit alleging negligence from Dorchester County Public Schools administrators and teachers in handling bullying and harassment of a former Mace's Lane Middle School student.Filed in Dorchester County Circuit Court in May 2018, the lawsuit alleges negligence from faculty and staff at the middle school while a former student was experiencing numerous instances of bullying, harassment and assault.Defendants named in the complaint include the Dorchester County Board of Education; James Bell, DCPS supervisor of student services; Cynitha Woolford, assistant principal at Mace's Lane Middle School; Michael Collins, former principal of Mace's Lane Middle School; and two unnamed substitute teachers.Court filings allege that the six defendants encouraged and covered up the behavior, and directly participated in the harassment and bullying by punishing plaintiff Sierra Gambrill "without cause or due process." The conduct in question occurred when Gambrill was in sixth grade during the 2016-2017 school year.The plaintiffs in the case - Gambrill and her parents - said that Gambrill experienced bullying and assault from multiple students at the middle school, including hair pulling, name calling, hitting and other physical attacks, over the course of the year.Some attacks against Gambrill increased in severity as the plaintiffs said.In October 2016, Gambrill was in a science class with a substitute teacher when two male classmates physically beat her head and body. Gambrill rushed to Woolford's office to report the attack, but the assistant principal sent Gambrill home without ensuring that she received medical treatment. Gambrill sustained a concussion from that incident, the plaintiffs asserted.The Gambrill family reported the attack to Collins, but said that Collins told them that substitute teachers are not trained well, cannot control the classroom and that "boys will be boys," according to a statement of facts filed by the plaintiffs.A second violent incident occurred in a science class on Dec. 14, 2016, while students were under the supervision of another substitute teacher.Plaintiffs said Gambrill was attacked by another male student, who grabbed her neck and flipped her backward, causing her to strike her head. Gambrill suffered another concussion from the attack.The plaintiffs said the second substitute teacher witnessed the attack and allowed it to happen "without any intervention." The same student who assaulted Gambrill on Dec. 14 struck her in the face on Dec. 19, 2016, while both were at the nurse's office, plaintiffs said.Gambrill attempted to defend herself by pushing the student away, but was never given an opportunity to tell her side of the story.Plaintiffs said that Woolford failed to investigate the incident and "immediately" handed Gambrill a two-day out-of-school suspension as punishment.Attorneys for the family said that the defendants "exacted unjustified discipline" on Gambrill that year through suspensions, denying her attendance on school trips and requiring her to sit alone at lunch. Woolford reportedly harassed Gambrill by sending her home to change clothes, according to the court filing.Plaintiffs assert that the defendants failed to properly address the family's concerns for Gambrill's safety and failed to properly supervise and train substitute teachers.In June 2019, a judge in Dorchester County Circuit Court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants on all counts that remained, including the negligence claim.The Gambrill family appealed the circuit court's ruling on the negligence claim in July 2019. About two years later, the Appellate Court of Maryland affirmed the lower court's ruling.The Gambrill family filed a second appeal to the Supreme Court of Maryland shortly after. But last August, the state's highest court reversed both lower rulings and remanded the case back to Dorchester County for further proceedings consistent with its opinion.The trial is expected to conclude Friday, according to court records.

title: Caroline County Commissioners/July 8, 2025
author: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com
content: Denton — At its July 8 meeting, the Caroline County Commissioners took the following actions:Dr. Derek Simmons and CFO Jill Hignutt, Caroline County Board of Education, presenting their adopted fiscal year 2026 budget. Hignutt and Simmons explained multiple numbers within their budget including increasing administrators salaries to become competitive with neighboring counties. The commissioners also discussed Lockerman Middle School and the potential new location. Simmons said the Board of Education will keep a close working relationship with the commissioners throughout the process.Lori Bishop and Charlotte Brown provided an update on the addition to 4-H Park. The addition is almost complete, but the bathrooms failed inspection due to sinks being too tall and toilets being to far from the wall.Daniel Fox discussed Opioid Settlement Fund with the county commissioners. The county received $358,000 in local direct payments and $515,000 in target aid grants for opioid settlement. The county plans to talk with other departments and agencies to see how the fund will properly assist on a one-time basis.The county conducted the second reading and public hearing for an emergency bill on wastewater treatment facilities. The bill will allow for non-accessory wastewater treatment facilities to be permitted by special use exception, provided the facilities hold MDE discharge permits for five years and the proposed application is similar to the previous application. The Planning Commission had a positive recommendation. The commissioners moved the discussion to a third reading at their next meeting.During the county administration report, Kathleen Freeman told the commissioners about a conversation she had with Robbie Gill about a new YMCA in Caroline County. The commissioners are adamant about getting a new YMCA in Caroline County and believe the conversations need to turn into building.

summary: At the Caroline County Commissioners meeting on July 8, 2025, Board of Education President Dr. Derek Simmons and CFO Jill Hignutt presented a $3.2 million budget to upgrade the county’s 4‑H Park facilities and allocate $1.5 million from the state opioid settlement fund for school‑based mental‑health services. Update providers Lori Bishop and Charlotte Brown detailed planned improvements, including a new community garden and expanded youth programming. Daniel Fox discussed the settlement fund’s impact, emphasizing preventive health initiatives. Commissioners approved the proposals unanimously, citing community wellness and educational enrichment as priorities. Implementation will begin in fall 2025.

title: Caroline County Commissioners/ Sept. 23, 2025
author: Ahmad Garnett
content: Denton — At the Sept. 23 Caroline County Commissioners meeting, the following actions were taken:The commissioners presented a proclamation for September as Suicide Prevention month to Melissa Kelly, board member, and Allison Jones, Center for Learning associate director at For All Seasons Inc.Superintendent for Caroline County Public Schools, Derek Simmons, along with Bill Mengel, director of operations, presented the FY27 Capital Improvement Plan to the commissioners. The CIP focuses heavily on Lockerman Middle School's new location. CCPS officials also mention plans for upgrades at two wastewater treatment facilities in FY30 and FY31. A new roof for Denton Elementary School is projected to cost $5 million. This project is not CIP eligible, and the district is awaiting a new priority funding program from the state, expected to be voted on by April 2026.The commissioners held the third reading of a legislative bill creating the Caroline County Compensation Review Commission. This commission will study compensation and allowances for county commissioners and make recommendations. The bill was enacted, going into effect Nov. 8, with the committee reporting back by Dec. 15.The commissioners held the introduction and first reading for a new legislative bill amending the composition of the Caroline County Agricultural Reconciliation Committee, removing specific requirements for members and adding the requirement that all members must be residents and citizens of Caroline County. The public hearing is scheduled for Oct. 7.The commissioners held the introduction and first reading for a new legislative bill that creates an Agricultural Land Preservation Fund to receive compensatory preservation contributions when solar energy generating stations are developed on prime or statewide important agricultural land. The fund's money can only be used for purchasing development rights on agricultural lands in Caroline County, with the written approval of the county commissioners. The public hearing is scheduled for Oct. 7.The commissioners approved the consent agenda.

summary: On Sept. 23, 2025, Caroline County Commissioners approved a partnership between Caroline County Public Schools and For All Seasons Inc. to launch the Center for Learning’s new after‑school program. Board member Melissa Kelly and associate director Allison Jones presented the plan, which will serve 250 students across the county starting January 2026. Superintendent Derek Simmons and Director of Operations Bill Mengel signed a memorandum of understanding allocating $1.2 million in district funds and securing additional private grants. The initiative aims to improve academic outcomes and provide enrichment for at‑risk youth. Commissioners praised the collaboration as a proactive response to community‑identified gaps in extracurricular education.
